questions.text: Which of the following is a correct sequence of the content of the cubital fossa from medial to lateral side?
questions.solution:
Cubital fossa:

  • It is a triangular depression in front of the elbow joint.
  • Boundaries:
    • Laterally: Medial border of the brachioradialis
    • Medially: Lateral border of the pronator teres
  • Base:
    • It is directed upwards.
    • It is represented by an imaginary line joining the front of two epicondyles of the humerus.
  • Apex:
    • It is directed downwards.
    • It is formed by the area where brachioradialis crosses the pronator teres muscle.
  • Roof:
    • Skin
    • Superficial fascia containing the median cubital vein joining the cephalic & basilic veins and lateral & medial cutaneous nerves of the forearm
    • Deep fascia with bicipital aponeurosis
  • Floor:
    • Brachialis & supinator muscles
    • Capsule of elbow joint
  • Content: Medial to laterally (M B B R)
    • Median nerve
    • Brachial artery
    • Biceps brachi tendon
    • Radial nerve

Topic: Cubital fossa

Key Points:

  • Content of cubital fossa: Medial to laterally (M B B R)
    • Median nerve
    • Brachial artery
    • Biceps brachi tendon
    • Radial nerve

questions.text: 60 years old male patient was diagnosed with the injury to the superior gluteal nerve. Which of the following muscle is not affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Superior gluteal nerve:

  • The superior gluteal nerve arises from the sacral plexus in the pelvis.
  • It is formed by the dorsal branches of the ventral rami of L4, L5, S1.
  • Course:
    • It enters the gluteal region through the greater sciatic notch above the piriformis in company with superior gluteal artery.
    • Here it curves upward and forward, runs between the gluteus medius and the minimus, and supplies both of them.
    • It then comes out by passing between the anterior borders of these muscles and supplies the tensor fasciae latae from its deep surface.
  • It also provides an articular twig to the hip joint.

Topic: Gluteal region

Key Points:

Branches of the superior gluteal nerve

  • Muscular branches:
    • Gluteus minimus
    • Gluteus medius
    • Tensor fascia latae
  • Articular branch:
    • Hip joint

questions.text: According to relation from before backwards, which of the following is a true about the structures in the root of the right lung?
questions.solution:
Root of the Lung:

  • Root of the lung is a short, broad pedicle which connects the medial surface of the lung to the mediastinum.
  • It is formed by structures which either enter or come out of the lung at the hilum.
  • The roots of the lungs lie opposite the bodies of the 5th, 6th and 7th thoracic vertebrae.
  • Contents
    • Principal bronchus on the left side and eparterial & hyparterial bronchi on the right side
    • One pulmonary artery in middle part
    • Two pulmonary veins, superior and inferior, in anterior part
    • Bronchial arteries-one on the right side and two on the left side.
    • Bronchial veins
    • Anterior and posterior pulmonary plexuses of nerves
    • Lymphatics of the lung
    • Bronchopulmonary lymph nodes
    • Areolar tissue

The arrangement of structures in the roots of the lungs is as follows:

  • From before backwards (it is more or less similar on both sides):
    • Pulmonary vein (superior)
    • Pulmonary artery
    • Bronchus (left principal bronchus on the left side and hyparterial bronchus on the right side)
    • Mnemonic: VAB (Vein, Artery, and Bronchus).
  • From above downwards (it differs on two sides):

Topic: Root of the lungs

Key Points:

Arrangement of structures in the roots of the right lungs

From before backwards:

  • Superior pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Hypaterial bronchus
  • Mnemonic: VAB (Vein, Artery, and Bronchus)

From above downwards (it differs on two sides):

The sphincter ani externus and the superficial transverse perineal muscles

questions.text: Which of the following muscles are forming the urogenital diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Urogenital diaphragm:

  • The urogenital diaphragm is a triangular muscle sheet formed by
    • The sphincter urethrae muscle
    • The deep transverse perineal muscle
  • On the deeper aspect it is covered by a thin layer of endopelvic fascia called superior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm.
  • On the superficial aspect it is covered by the perineal membrane called inferior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm.
  • This triangular diaphragm occupies the urogenital triangle with its apex behind the pubic symphysis and its sides attached to the ischiopubic rami.
  • It is pierced by the urethra in male and by the urethra and vagina in female
  • It contains bulbourethral glands within it in male.

Topic: Urogenital diaphragm

Key Points:

  • The urogenital diaphragm is a triangular muscle sheet formed by
    • The sphincter urethrae muscle
    • The deep transverse perineal muscle
  • The pelvic diaphragm is a diamond muscle sheet formed by
    • The levator ani (iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus) muscle
    • The ischiococcygeus muscle

questions.text: Which of the following layer of anterior abdominal wall does not continue into the scrotum?
questions.solution:
The scrotum:

  • It is a large pendulous sac of skin located below and behind the penis.
  • It is considered as an out-pouching of the lower part of the anterior abdominal wall.
  • The transversus abdominis muscle does not continue into the scrotum
  • It contains the following structures:
    • Testes, epididymis and lower parts of the spermatic cords
  • Layers (outer to inner side)
    • Skin
    • Dartos muscle (which replaces the superficial fascia)
    • External spermatic fascia (derived from external oblique muscle)
    • Cremasteric muscle and fascia (derived from internal oblique muscle)
    • Internal spermatic fascia (derived from fascia transversalis)
  • Blood supply:
    • Superficial external pudendal artery
    • Deep external pudendal artery
    • Scrotal branches of the internal pudendal artery
    • Cremasteric artery, a branch of the inferior epigastric artery
  • Nerve supply:
    • Anterior one-third of the scrotum is supplied by ilioinguinal nerve (L1) and genital branch of genitofemoral nerve (L1).
    • Posterior two-third of the scrotum is supplied by posterior scrotal branches of the perineal nerve (S3) and perineal branch of the posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh (S3).
    • The involuntary dartos muscle is supplied by the sympathetic fibres through genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.
  • Lymphatic drainage:
    • The lymph vessels from the scrotum drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

Topic: Scrotum

Key Points:

The comparison between the layers of the anterior abdominal wall and the scrotum

choices.text: To facilitate calcium ion storage in the sarcoplasmic reticulum
To provide structural stability to muscle fibres during contraction
To enhance ATP production in mitochondria
To mediate neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex in muscle cells?
questions.solution:
Option b: The dystrophin-glycoprotein complex anchors the cytoskeleton of muscle fibres to the extracellular matrix through the sarcolemma.

This provides mechanical stability during muscle contraction and prevents damage caused by the stress of repeated contractions. This is the correct answer.

Damage to this complex can result in several muscle dystrophies.

Option a: This is not the function of the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex.

Calcium storage and release are mediated by the sarcoplasmic reticulum, specifically via proteins like ryanodine receptors and calsequestrin.

Option c: ATP production occurs in mitochondria via oxidative phosphorylation and glycolysis, which are independent of the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex.

Option d: Neurotransmitter release is mediated by synaptic vesicles and voltage-gated calcium channels at the presynaptic terminal, not by the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex.

questions.text: Which among following fibers generate inhibitory postsynaptic potential in the motor neurons that supply the muscle from which the fibers arise?
questions.solution:
Option b: These fibers arise from Golgi tendon organs and provide feedback about muscle tension.

Function: Type Ib fibers synapse on inhibitory interneurons in the spinal cord, which, in turn, inhibit alpha motor neurons (by IPSP) supplying the same muscle. This mechanism is called the Golgi tendon reflex.

Type Ib fibers inhibit motor neurons of the same muscle to prevent excessive tension and potential damage.

Option a: These are afferent fibers originating from muscle spindles, specifically the annulospiral endings.

Function: They generate excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) in alpha motor neurons via the monosynaptic stretch reflex.

Option c: These are afferent fibers from secondary endings (flower spray) of muscle spindles.

Function: They are involved in signaling sustained muscle stretch via static response.

Option d: These are efferent fibers that innervate intrafusal muscle fibers to maintain spindle sensitivity during muscle contraction.

Function: Gamma fibers modulate the sensitivity of muscle spindles but do not directly generate inhibitory postsynaptic potentials in motor neurons.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the primary care physician, who was later referred to neuro-physician. On detailed examination doctor put the probable diagnosis as Horner syndrome. Which of the following is not a symptom of it?
questions.solution:
Option b: Exophthalmos, or forward displacement of the eyeball, is typically seen in conditions like Grave's disease (thyroid eye disease). This is NOT a feature of Horner syndrome. In contrast, Horner syndrome can cause an apparent enophthalmos (sunken eye) due to ptosis.

Option a: Loss of sweating occurs on the affected side of the face due to disruption of sympathetic innervation to sweat glands. It is known as anhidrosis. It is a hallmark feature of Horner syndrome.

Option c: Ptosis (drooping of eyelid) occurs due to paralysis of eyelid muscle, which is supplied by sympathetic fibers. It is a hallmark feature of Horner syndrome.

Option d: Miosis (constricted pupil) is caused by unopposed parasympathetic activity due to loss of sympathetic innervation to the dilator pupillae muscle. It is a hallmark feature of Horner syndrome.

Triad of classical symptoms of anhidrosis, miosis and ptosis is seen in Horne syndrome.

questions.text: A 56-year-old right-handed man is brought to the clinic by his family due to difficulty understanding spoken language for the past few weeks. He frequently answers questions inappropriately and appears frustrated when trying to communicate. He is unable to repeat spoken words or follow simple verbal commands. His ability to comprehend written language is also impaired. MRI reveals a lesion in the left superior temporal gyrus. The symptoms in this patient are most likely due to dysfunction of which of the following brain areas?
questions.solution:
Option b: Wernicke's area, located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus, is critical for processing auditory signals related to speech and languagecomprehension.

  • Lesions here cause Wernicke's aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech, poor comprehension, and inability to repeat words.

Option a: Broca's area, located in the inferior frontal gyrus, is responsible for speech production and motor aspects of language.

  • Lesions here cause Broca's aphasia, characterized by non-fluent, effortful speech with relatively preserved comprehension.

Option c: The arcuate fasciculus is a white matter tract connecting Broca's and Wernicke's areas.

  • Damage to this pathway results in conduction aphasia, characterized by relatively preserved comprehension and fluent speech but impaired repetition.

Option d: The primary auditory cortex, located in the superior temporal lobe, processes basic auditory information such as sound frequency and intensity. It does not directly interpret speech.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male has hypocalcaemia. Doctor examined the patient and tried to rule out latent tetany. By tapping over the facial nerve doctor found contraction of ipsilateral facial muscles. Doctor has this testing to evaluate tetany, What is the name of the test described in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Option c: Chvostek's sign is a clinical test for latent tetany seen in hypocalcemia. It is performed by tapping the facial nerve at its exit point near the ear. A positive sign is indicated by twitching of the ipsilateral facial muscles.

  • This occurs due to increased neuromuscular excitability caused by hypocalcemia.

Option a: Trousseau's sign is another clinical test for latent tetany in hypocalcemia. It involves inflating a blood pressure cuff on the upper arm above systolic pressure for 3-5 minutes, leading to carpopedal spasm (flexion of the wrist and metacarpophalangeal joints, with extension of the fingers).

Option b: The Babinski sign is a neurological test where stimulation of the sole of the foot leads to dorsiflexion of the big toe and fanning of the other toes. It is used to assess upper motor neuron lesions.

Option d: As option c is true, d cannot be correct.

questions.text: Phosphotidylinositol 4-5 bis phosphate cleavage by Phopholipase C results in formation of second messengers
questions.solution:
Phosphoinositides including Inositol containing Phospholipids PIP2 &PIP3 undergoes dephosphorylation by Phosphatases.

Action of phosphoinositide Specific Phospholipase C Isoenzymes on PIP2 leads to formation of two second messengers called as Diacylglycerol and Inositol Triphosphate (IP3).

Diacylglycerol activates protein kinase C and IP3 acts through release of intracellular Ca2 from endoplasmic Reticulum.

questions.text: Marker enzyme for Peroxisomes is
questions.solution:
Peroxisomes are membrane bound organelles found in cytoplasm. It involved in oxidative reactions and contain enzyme that transfer hydrogen atoms from organic substances to molecular oxygen which generates Hydrogen Peroxide - neutralise by Catalase. Involved in metabolism of Fatty acids, other lipids, purines, Amino acid and H2O2.

Catalase and urate oxidase are marker enzyme for Peroxisomes activity. Urate oxidase (also called uricase) is a key enzyme localized in peroxisomes, particularly in organisms that produce it. It plays a role in the metabolism of purines by converting uric acid into allantoin.

Superoxide dismutase - This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of superoxide radicals into hydrogen peroxide and oxygen. It is found in various cellular compartments, including the cytoplasm, mitochondria, and extracellular space. It is not specific to peroxisomes and thus cannot serve as a marker enzyme for them.

NADH Oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of NADH to NAD+, present in various cellular organelles, including mitochondria and plasma membranes, but is not specific to peroxisomes.

Lyase broad class of enzymes not specific for Peroxisomes.

questions.text: Red blood cells are more vulnerable in Patient suffering from G-6 PD Deficiency due to all except
questions.solution:
In hexose Monophosphate Shunt, conversion of Glucose 6 Phosphate to 6-phosphogluconolactone. NAD+ acts as coenzyme & forms NADPH. So in RBC HMP shunt pathway is only pathway which generates NADPH. This reactions are irreversible reaction of pathway.

In deficiency of NADPH, there is no alternative source or mechanism available in RBC for generation of NADPH like other tissues (NADP dependent malate dehydrogenase ). Free Radicals and peroxides formed in RBC during biochemical reactions require Reduced Glutathione (G-SH) for its detoxification. NADPH is essential for maintenance of G-SH Pool. Free Radicals taken up by Glutathione in presence of Glutathione Peroxidase enzyme and forms Oxidized Glutathione which in Presence of NADPH converted back into Reduced Glutahione and available for removal of Free radical.

Thus it helps to maintain the reduced state of sulfhydryl group of protein including hemoglobin. Oxidation of this leads to formation of denatured proteins that forms insoluble masses (Heinz Bodies). Rbc becomes rigid and removed from circulation by Macrophages.

questions.text: Principal chain breaking anti oxidant is
questions.solution:
Antioxidant falls into two different classes.

  1. Preventive Antioxidants - which reduces the rate of chain initiation and
  2. Chain Breaking Antioxidants - which interfere with chain propagation.

The principal chain breaking anti oxidants are Superoxide Dismutase, which acts in the aqueous phase to trap superoxide free radicals, urate and vitamin E which acts in the lipid phase to trap ROO - radicals.

Preventive antioxidants include catalase and other peroxidases such as glutathione Peroxidase that Reacts with ROOH.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the gross and histological features of clear cell renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT ANSWER

Gross Appearance:

  • Yellow-white tumor
  • Hemorrhagic areas
  • Well-circumscribed
  • Lobulated surface

Histological Features:

  • Clear cells with abundant cytoplasm
  • Rich in glycogen and lipids
  • Classic "clear cell" appearance
  • Most common RCC subtype (70-80%)
  • Associated with VHL gene mutation

B) Red-brown solid mass with necrotic regions, spindle-shaped cells

Describes sarcomatoid RCC variant

More aggressive subtype

Spindle cell morphology

Poor prognosis

C) Multiloculated cystic lesion with papillary architecture

Represents papillary RCC

Papillary architectural pattern

Type 1 and Type 2 subtypes

Less common variant

D) Pale gray tumor with fibrous bands, uniform small cells

Suggests chromophobe RCC

Uniform small cells

Less aggressive subtype

Rare variant

Key Takeaways:

  1. Clear cell RCC is the most common subtype
  2. Characterized by clear cells with abundant lipids/glycogen
  3. Yellow-white, hemorrhagic gross appearance
  4. Associated with VHL gene mutation
  5. Good surgical candidacy if detected early

Distinguishing Features:

Clear cell: Yellow-white, abundant lipids

Papillary: Papillary architecture

Chromophobe: Uniform small cells

Sarcomatoid: Spindle cell morphology

choices.text: Coagulative necrosis with contraction band necrosis

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with chest pain and is diagnosed with an acute myocardial infarction. A myocardial biopsy is performed, and the microscopic picture shows:
questions.solution:
1. Coagulative necrosis with contraction band necrosis: This is the typical microscopic picture of myocardial infarction.
  2. Caseous necrosis with granulomatous inflammation: This is more typical of tuberculosis or other granulomatous diseases.
  3. Fatty change with glycogen depletion: This is more typical of fatty liver disease or other conditions with fatty change.
  4. Myocyte vacuolization with mitochondrial damage:While myocyte vacuolization and mitochondrial damage can occur in myocardial infarction, they are not the primary features of the microscopic picture.

Key takeaway:

  • The microscopic picture of myocardial infarction typically shows coagulative necrosis, which is characterized by the preservation of the outline of dead myocytes, with contraction band necrosis, which is characterized by the presence of dense, eosinophilic bands within the myocytes.

questions.text: An infant is born at 34 week's gestation to a 28-year-old woman, G3, P2. At birth, the infant is observed to be markedly hydropic and icteric. A cord blood sample is taken, and direct Coombs test result is positive for the infant's RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism for the findings in this infant?
questions.solution:
A) Hemolysis of antibody-coated cells: The infant's presentation with marked hydrops and jaundice at birth, combined with a positive direct Coombs test, is consistent with hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN).

  • HDN occurs when maternal antibodies against fetal red blood cell antigens cross the placenta and bind to the fetal red blood cells, leading to their destruction.
  • The positive direct Coombs test indicates that the infant's red blood cells are coated with antibodies, which is consistent with HDN.
  • The most likely mechanism for the findings in this infant is therefore hemolysis of antibody-coated cells.

B) Hematopoietic stem cell defect: While hematopoietic stem cell defects can cause anemia and other hematological abnormalities, they do not typically present with the acute hemolysis and jaundice seen in this infant.

C) Impaired globin synthesis: Impaired globin synthesis can cause anemia and other hematological abnormalities, but it does not typically present with the acute hemolysis and jaundice seen in this infant.

  1. Mechanical fragmentation of RBCs: Mechanical fragmentation of RBCs can cause hemolysis, but it is not typically associated with a positive direct Coombs test.

Not E, option D

Key takeaway:

  • A fetalmaternal hemorrhage in utero or at the time of delivery in a previous pregnancy (or with previous transfusion of incompatible blood) can sensitize the mother, resulting in production of irregular IgG antibodies.
  • In subsequent pregnancies, these antibodies (in contrast to the naturally occurring IgM antibodies) can cross the placenta to attach to fetal cells, leading to hemolysis.
  • In the past, most cases were caused by Rh incompatibility (e.g., Rh-negative mother, Rh-positive infant), but the use of RhoGAM administered at birth to Rh negative mothers has eliminated almost all such cases when recognized.

choices.text: Activation of the extrinsic coagulation pathway
Release of tissue factor from damaged endothelial cells

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with sepsis and multiple organ dysfunction. Laboratory tests reveal:
- Prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
- Low fibrinogen level
- Elevated D-dimer level
- Thrombocytopenia
Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for the development of DIC in this patient?
questions.solution:
1. Inhibition of fibrinolysis: Inhibition of fibrinolysis can contribute to the development of thrombosis, but it is not the primary mechanism underlying DIC.
  2. Activation of the extrinsic coagulation pathway: While the extrinsic coagulation pathway is activated in DIC, this is a consequence of the release of tissue factor from damaged endothelial cells, rather than the primary cause.
  3. DIC is a complex condition characterized by the simultaneous activation of the coagulation and fibrinolytic pathways, leading to the formation of microthrombi in small blood vessels. The release of tissue factor from damaged endothelial cells is a key event in the initiation of DIC. Tissue factor is a transmembrane receptor that activates the extrinsic coagulation pathway, leading to the generation of thrombin and the formation of fibrin clots.
  4. Inhibition of thrombin generation: Inhibition of thrombin generation would actually prevent the formation of fibrin clots, rather than contributing to the development of DIC.

Key takeaway:

The release of tissue factor from damaged endothelial cells is a key event in the initiation of DIC, leading to the activation of the extrinsic coagulation pathway and the formation of microthrombi in small blood vessels.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman has had multiple episodes of aspiration of food associated with difficulty swallowing during the past year. On auscultation of her chest, crackles are heard at the base of the right lung. A barium swallow shows marked esophageal dilation above the level of the lower esophageal sphincter. A biopsy specimen from the lower esophagus shows an absence of the myenteric ganglia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of all options:

  1. Achalasia: The patient's symptoms of difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) and aspiration of food, combined with the radiographic findings of esophageal dilation and the biopsy results showing an absence of the myenteric ganglia, are consistent with achalasia.
    • Achalasia is a rare disorder of the esophagus characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax, leading to a functional obstruction of the esophagus.
    • The absence of the myenteric ganglia, which are responsible for regulating the contractions of the esophagus, is a hallmark of achalasia.
  2. Barrett esophagus: Barrett esophagus is a condition in which the lining of the esophagus is replaced by intestinal-type epithelium, often as a result of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). While Barrett esophagus can cause dysphagia, it is not associated with the absence of the myenteric ganglia.
  3. Plummer-Vinson syndrome: Plummer-Vinson syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by dysphagia, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. While it can cause dysphagia, it is not associated with the absence of the myenteric ganglia.
  4. Sliding hiatal hernia: A sliding hiatal hernia is a type of hernia in which the stomach slides up into the chest through the esophageal hiatus. While it can cause dysphagia, it is not associated with the absence of the myenteric ganglia.

Key takeaway:

  • In achalasia, there is incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter with lack of peristalsis.
  • Most cases are "primary" or of unknown origin.
  • They may be caused by degenerative changes in neural innervation; the myenteric ganglia are usually absent from the body of the esophagus.
  • There is a long-term risk of development of squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary organ or structure affected by the Rubella virus in the fetus during congenital rubella syndrome (CRS)?
questions.solution:
Explanation of All 4 Options:

  1. Brain: The Rubella virus can cause neurological complications, but it is not the primary organ that it targets in the fetus. Congenital rubella syndrome can affect the brain, leading to conditions like microcephaly, but this occurs as a result of the infection, not as the main target of the virus.
  2. Heart: While rubella infection can lead to congenital heart defects (such as patent ductus arteriosus), the primary site of the Rubella virus infection in the fetus is the placenta, not the heart. Heart defects are one of the complications, not the primary invasion point.
  3. Placenta: The Rubella virus primarily affects the placenta, which is the interface between the fetus and the mother. The infection leads to fetal malformations and can cause miscarriage or birth defects. The virus is transmitted across the placenta, leading to congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).
  4. Liver: The liver is not the primary site affected by Rubella infection. Hepatitis B or other viruses affect the liver, but Rubella predominantly targets the placenta and can cause congenital malformations, including hearing loss, heart defects, and brain damage.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rubella virus primarily invades the placenta during pregnancy, leading to congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).
  • CRS can result in severe fetal defects, including microcephaly, hearing loss, heart defects, and vision problems.
  • Vaccination against Rubella is crucial to prevent congenital rubella syndrome. The Rubella vaccine is part of the MMR vaccine (measles, mumps, rubella).

Additional Information:

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2023). Rubella (German Measles) and Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS). CDC Website.
  • World Health Organization (WHO). (2022). Rubella. WHO Website

questions.text: Which type of infection is characterized by a persistent infection with intermittent shedding, where the microbe persists in an infectious form over time and sheds periodically?
questions.solution:
1. Herpes simplex virus: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) typically causes persistent latent infection, where the virus remains dormant in nerve cells and reactivates occasionally. It does not fit the pattern of persistent shedding as described.
  2. Rotavirus: is a classic example of acute self limited infection.
  3. Epstein-Barr virus: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is a classic example of a persistent infection with shedding. The virus remains in the body, and although it may not cause symptoms continuously, it can shed intermittently, especially during periods of reactivation.
  4. HIV: HIV causes a persistent infection, but it does not have the characteristic intermittent shedding seen in infections like Epstein-Barr virus. HIV replicates constantly and leads to immune system dysfunction without discrete shedding periods.

Key Takeaways:

  • Persistent infection with shedding involves the continuous or intermittent shedding of the pathogen, even when the host may not exhibit symptoms. Epstein-Barr virus is a prime example of this infection type.
  • Latent infections like herpes simplex virus remain dormant and reactivate intermittently without consistent shedding.
  • HIV and other persistent infections often involve continuous replication and do not exhibit the same shedding pattern as Epstein-Barr virus.

questions.text: Which of the following opportunistic infections in AIDS is primarily associated with disseminated infection, including the central nervous system (CNS)?
questions.solution:
• A) Toxoplasma gondii: Toxoplasma gondii is a protozoan that can cause disseminated infection, including in the CNS (e.g., encephalitis). It is a common opportunistic infection in AIDS patients with a compromised immune system.
  • B) Kaposi's sarcoma: Kaposi's sarcoma is a tumor associated with HHV-8, not an infection. It often manifests as skin lesions or internal organ involvement but is not primarily characterized by dissemination in the CNS.
  • C) Salmonella: Salmonella infections in AIDS patients typically cause recurrent, disseminated septicaemia, but it is not specifically known for CNS involvement, unlike Toxoplasma gondii.
  • D) Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8): HHV-8 is associated with Kaposi's sarcoma, a tumor, and although it can affect various organs, it is not primarily associated with dissemination to the CNS as Toxoplasma gondii is.

Key Takeaways:

  • Toxoplasma gondii is a protozoan responsible for disseminated infections, including in the CNS, in individuals with advanced HIV/AIDS.
  • Kaposi's sarcoma is caused by HHV-8 and is a tumor, not an infection, and typically affects skin and internal organs rather than the CNS.
  • Salmonella and Mycobacteria can cause disseminated infections, but they do not typically affect the CNS directly.

Additional Information on Opportunistic Infections:

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2023). Opportunistic Infections in HIV/AIDS. CDC Website.
  • World Health Organization (WHO). (2022). Opportunistic Infections and Tumors in AIDS. WHO Website.

choices.text: RV5 contains one live attenuated rotavirus strain, while RV1 contains five reassortant rotaviruses from human and bovine parent strains.
RV5 offers 74-87% efficacy against any rotavirus gastroenteritis and 85-98% protection against severe gastroenteritis.
RV1 provides protection against severe gastroenteritis only, but does not protect against any rotavirus gastroenteritis.
The earlier rotavirus vaccine, which caused intussusception, was more effective than RV5 and RV1.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the two live oral rotavirus vaccines, RV5 (RotaTeq™) and RV1 (Rotarix™)?
questions.solution:
• A) RV5 contains one live attenuated rotavirus strain, while RV1 contains five reassortant rotaviruses from human and bovine parent strains.
    This is incorrect. RV5 contains five reassortant rotaviruses derived from both human and bovine strains, while RV1 contains one live attenuated human rotavirus strain.
  • B) RV5 offers 74-87% efficacy against any rotavirus gastroenteritis and 85-98% protection against severe gastroenteritis.
    This is correct. The RV5 vaccine provides 74-87% efficacy against any rotavirus gastroenteritis and 85-98% efficacy against severe forms of gastroenteritis.
  • C) RV1 provides protection against severe gastroenteritis only, but does not protect against any rotavirus gastroenteritis.
    This is incorrect. RV1 offers protection against both severe rotavirus gastroenteritis and general rotavirus gastroenteritis, though its protection might be slightly lower compared to RV5.
  • D) The earlier rotavirus vaccine, which caused intussusception, was more effective than RV5 and RV1.
    This is incorrect. The earlier rotavirus vaccine was withdrawn due to its association with intussusception, and its efficacy was lower compared to the newer vaccines like RV5 and RV1.

Key Takeaways:

  • The RV5 vaccine (RotaTeq™) contains five reassortant rotaviruses and provides 74-87% protection against rotavirus gastroenteritis and 85-98% protection against severe cases.
  • The RV1 vaccine (Rotarix™) contains one live attenuated rotavirus strain and also offers high protection against severe gastroenteritis.
  • The newer rotavirus vaccines have demonstrated a significant reduction in hospitalizations and GP visits for gastroenteritis in children.

Additional Information:

  • World Health Organization (WHO). (2022). Rotavirus Vaccines. WHO Website.
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2023). Rotavirus Vaccine Information. CDC Website.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is not associated with a carrier state and does not lead to liver cancer?
questions.solution:
• A) Hepatitis A (HAV): Correct. Hepatitis A is transmitted via the faecal-oral route and has a relatively short incubation period of 2-4 weeks. It does not cause a carrier state and is not linked to liver cancer. Infected individuals typically recover fully without long-term complications.
  • B) Hepatitis B (HBV): Hepatitis B is transmitted through blood-borne routes and sexual contact. It has a long incubation period of 6 weeks to 6 months, and individuals can become chronic carriers of the virus. Chronic infection is associated with liver cancer.
  • C) Hepatitis C (HCV): Hepatitis C is also transmitted via blood-borne routes and has an incubation period of about 2 months. It can lead to chronic infection and is a major risk factor for liver cancer.
  • D) Hepatitis D (HDV): Hepatitis D requires concurrent infection with Hepatitis B. It shares similar transmission routes as HBV and is associated with liver cancer. It also has a similar incubation period of 2-12 weeks.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hepatitis A does not have a chronic carrier state and is not linked to liver cancer, unlike Hepatitis B, C, and D, which can result in chronic infections and increase the risk of liver cancer.
  • Hepatitis B, C, and D are primarily transmitted through blood-borne or sexual routes, whereas Hepatitis A and E are transmitted through the faecal-oral
  • The incubation period for Hepatitis viruses can vary significantly, from 2-4 weeks (HAV) to several months (HBV, HCV, and HDV).
  • World Health Organization (WHO). (2023). Hepatitis Overview. WHO Website.
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2022). Viral Hepatitis. CDC Website.

questions.text: What is true about the otic ganglion?
questions.solution:
Otic ganglion:

  • It is a small parasympathetic ganglion connected to the mandibular division of trigeminal nerve and provides a relay station to the secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland.
  • Topographically it is intimately related to the mandibular nerve but functionally it is related to glossopharyngeal nerve.

Roots or connections

  • Parasympathetic motor (secretomotor):
    • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibres arise from inferior salivatory nucleus
    • Passes successively through glossopharyngeal nerve, tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson's nerve), tympanic plexus and lesser petrosal nerve to relay in the ganglion.
  • Sympathetic:
    • From sympathetic plexus around the middle meningeal artery.
    • Preganglionic sympathetic fibres arise from T1 and T2 spinal segments, enter the cervical sympathetic chain at the level of its inferior ganglion and then ascend to relay in the superior cervical sympathetic ganglion.
    • The postganglionic fibres arise from this ganglion and form plexus around the middle meningeal artery.
    • They then pass through the ganglion without relay to reach the parotid gland via auriculotemporal nerve.
  • Sensory:
    • From auriculotemporal nerve.
  • Somatic motor:
    • Nerve to medial pterygoid.
    • It passes through ganglion to supply medial pterygoid, tensor palati, and tensor tympani muscles.

Branches:

  • All supply parotid gland through auriculotemporal nerve.
  • Postganglionic parasympathetic: Secretomotor to paratod gland.
  • Postganglionic sympathetic: They are vasomotor in nature and responsible for thick salivary secretion.
  • Sensory

Topic: Otic ganglion

questions.text: Which of the following is a safety muscle of the larynx?
questions.solution:
Intrinsic muscles of the larynx:

  • There are two types of the muscles - Intrinsic and extrinsic
  • Intricsic muscles are attached to the laryngeal cartilages
  • They are responsible for their movements of the larynx.
  • Their main functions are to:
    • Open or close the laryngeal inlet
    • Adduct and abduct the vocal cords
    • Increase or decrease the tension of the vocal cords
  • Thus according to their actions, intrinsic muscles of the larynx are arranged into the following groups:
    • Closes the inlet of larynx:
      • Oblique arytenoids
      • Aryepiglotticus
    • Opens the inlet of larynx:
      • Thyroepiglotticus
    • Abduct the vocal cords:
      • Posterior cricoarytenoids
    • Adduct the vocal cords:
      • Lateral cricoarytenoids
      • Transverse arytenoid
    • Tenses the vocal cords:
      • Cricothyroid
      • Vocalis
    • Relaxes the vocal cords:
      • Thyroarytenoid
    • Nerve supply:
      • All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx are supplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve except cricothyroid.
      • Cricothyroid is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

Topic: The Larynx

Key Points:

Safety muscles of larynx:

  • The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the only intrinsic muscles of the larynx, which abduct the vocal cords to allow entry of air through rima glottidis in the respiratory tract below it.
  • When posterior cricoarytenoids contract, muscular processes of both the arytenoid cartilages rotate medially. As a result, the vocal processes rotate laterally (abducting vocal cords) providing wide diamond-shaped opening of the glottis.
  • If posterior cricoarytenoids are paralyzed, the adductor muscles (of vocal cords) take the upper hand and the person might die due to lack of air. Hence the posterior circoarytenoid muscles are called safety muscles of the larynx.

questions.text: 70 years old male patient was admitted to hospital. He was diagnosed with the stroke. MRI Shows blockage of the basilar artery. All of the following arteries are affected in the patient, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Basilar artery:

  • It is formed by the union of two vertebral arteries at the lower border of the pons.
  • It ascends in the basilar sulcus on the ventral aspect of the pons in the cis-terna pontis and terminates at the upper border of the pons by dividing into right and left posterior cerebral arteries.

Branches of basilar artery

  • Pontine branches:
    • They are numerous short slender paramedian vessels which pierce the pons to supply it.
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery:
    • It arises close to the lower border of the pons and runs backwards and laterally.
    • Then it forms a loop over the flocculus of the cerebellum and peeps into the internal acoustic meatus for a variable distance.
    • After exit from the meatus it supplies the anterolateral portion of the inferior surface of the cerebellum.
  • Labyrinthine artery:
    • It is a long slender branch which arises either from basilar artery or from anterior inferior cere-bellar artery.
    • It accompanies the vestibulocochlear nerve and enters the internal auditory meatus to supply the internal ear.
    • It is an end artery.
  • Superior cerebellar artery:
    • It arises close to the superior border of the pons, runs laterally below the oculomotor nerve (which is interposed between this artery and the posterior cerebral artery), and winds round the cerebral peduncle below the trochlear nerve to reach the superior surface of the cerebellum which it supplies.
  • Posterior cerebral artery:
    • It passes laterally parallel to the superior cerebellar artery, curves around the midbrain to reach the medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere, beneath the splenium of corpus callosum
    • The artery gives off temporal branches which ramify over the inferior surface of the temporal lobe, calcarine branches and parieto-occipital branches which run along the corresponding sulci.

Topic: Blood supply of the brain

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath, dry cough, and chest tightness that has worsened over the past several weeks. Patient worked in a construction industry for many years. On evaluation patient is found to have reduced lung compliance.
Which among the following disease least likely to cause reduced lung compliance?
questions.solution:
Option c: COPD, particularly emphysema, is associated with increased lung compliance due to the destruction of alveolar walls and loss of elastic recoil.

  • Although patient's working condition is a risk factor for both COPD and other lung diseases, COPD does not cause reduced compliance.

Option a: Pulmonary fibrosis involves excessive deposition of collagen and fibrotic tissue in the lungs, making the lungs stiff and reducing their compliance.

  • The patient's occupational exposure makes this a likely cause of reduced compliance.

Option b: Pulmonary edema results from the accumulation of fluid in the alveoli, increasing surface tension and reducing the lung's ability to expand.

  • This condition decreases lung compliance, especially in cases of cardiogenic pulmonary edema or ARDS.

Option d: ARDS is characterized by widespread inflammation, surfactant dysfunction, and alveolar damage, all of which significantly reduce lung compliance.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the primary care physician for a neurological examination. Sensory evaluation reveals a diminished ability to perceive vibration. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Option a: Chronic poorly controlled diabetes can lead to diabetic peripheral neuropathy, which affects the small and large fibers of peripheral nerves.

  • Large fiber neuropathy often impairs vibration sense and proprioception. The loss of vibration sense is due to damage to large myelinated fibers of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord and peripheral nerves.

Option b: Pernicious anemia results from vitamin B12 deficiency, often caused by autoimmune destruction of gastric parietal cells (leading to intrinsic factor deficiency). Vitamin B12 is essential for maintaining myelin integrity.

  • Its deficiency leads to subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the dorsal and lateral columns of the spinal cord. This results in impaired proprioception and vibration sense due to dorsal column dysfunction.

Option c: Tabes dorsalis is a late manifestation of neurosyphilis.

  • It involves degeneration of the dorsal columns and dorsal root ganglia of the spinal cord, leading to sensory ataxia, impaired proprioception, and vibration sense. It suggests involvement of dorsal column.

Option d: Each of these conditions can cause damage to the dorsal columns or  peripheral large fibers, leading to an increased threshold to vibration sense.

  • Therefore, all of the listed conditions are plausible explanations for the observed sensory deficit.
  • Option d is correct.

choices.text: Defective reabsorption of bile acid in distal ileum

questions.text: A 23-year-old male visited the physician for severe weight loss inspite of adequate dietary intake. On investigation physician found that patient has steatorrhoea. Which among the following could be a reason for steatorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Option a: Chronic pancreatitis leads to insufficient secretion of pancreatic enzymes, including lipase, which is critical for fat digestion.

  • Without adequate lipase, dietary fats cannot be broken down and absorbed, resulting in steatorrhea. This condition is a common cause of fat malabsorption.

Option b: Excessive gastric acid (as seen in conditions like Zollinger-Ellison syndrome) can lower the pH of the duodenum.

  • This acidic environment inactivates pancreatic enzymes (e.g., lipase) and precipitates bile salts, both of which are essential for fat digestion and absorption. The resulting enzymatic inactivation leads to steatorrhea.

Option c: Bile acids are reabsorbed in the distal ileum as part of the enterohepatic circulation. Normally more than 90% of bile is reabsorbed in the ileum.

  • If this reabsorption is impaired (e.g., in Crohn's disease, ileal resection, or other ileal pathologies), bile salt deficiency occurs, leading to inadequate fat emulsification and subsequent steatorrhea.

Option d: Each of these conditions affects a different aspect of fat digestion or absorption leading to steatorrhoea, hence the option d is correct.

choices.text: Choroidal epithelial cells form tight junctions
The capillaries in the brain are fenestrated capillaries
Tight junction between endothelial cells limit the transport via paracellular route
Facilitated diffusion of glucose occurs through GLUT1 transporters.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding transport across cerebral capillaries is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Option b: Brain capillaries are non-fenestrated and have continuous tight junctions, forming the blood-brain barrier.

  • The BBB's continuous capillaries restrict paracellular transport and tightly regulate the movement of substances.
  • Fenestrated capillaries are found in tissues like the kidney and endocrine glands, where more permeability is needed.

Option a: The choroidal epithelial cells, part of the blood-CSF barrier, form tight junctions to regulate the exchange of substances between the blood and cerebrospinal fluid. This barrier plays a critical role in maintaining the brain’s environment.

Option c: The tight junctions between endothelial cells in cerebral capillaries are a hallmark of the blood brain barrier, preventing paracellular transport of most substances.

  • This ensures that only selective transport mechanisms allow substances into the brain.

Option d: The brain relies on glucose as its primary energy source. GLUT1 transporters facilitate the movement of glucose across the barrier to supply the brain with this vital nutrient, ensuring adequate energy for neuronal function.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of dizziness and mild chest discomfort during physical exertion. He is known case of hypertension and is on antihypertensive medication. On examination, his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and his heart rate is 80 bpm. Further tests reveal no significant coronary artery blockage but a slightly elevated serum lactate level. Which of the following factors is most likely contributing to the autoregulatory adjustment of arteriolar caliber in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option a: Elevated CO2 is a key metabolic factor in autoregulation, particularly during increased tissue activity. In this patient, exertion likely increased CO2 production, leading to arteriolar dilation to enhance blood flow and oxygen delivery to metabolically active tissues.

Option b: Endothelin-1 is a potent vasoconstrictor, not a vasodilator. It is released by endothelial cells under certain conditions, such as hypoxia or vascular stress, and contributes to increased vascular tone.

Option c: Nitric oxide is a vasodilator. It is produced by endothelial cells in response to shear stress and other stimuli, promoting smooth muscle relaxation and increased blood flow.

Option d: Increased extracellular potassium levels, commonly seen in metabolically active tissues, cause vasodilation through effects on vascular smooth muscle membrane potential. Reduced potassium does not typically cause arteriolar constriction in autoregulation.

questions.text: A 8 Month old boy presented with acute onset of Vomiting, Lethargy, growth retardation. Blood Investigation shows low blood sugar level, High Lactic acid level and Uric Acid level. Mother had stop breast feeding and started Honey & fruits daily in his diet. Identify the Correct Sentence
questions.solution:
08 year old child with history of weaning with fruits and honey, presented with vomiting, Low sugar level and high lactic acid level is more likely suggestive of Hereditary Fructose Intolerance where deficiency of enzyme aldolase B is present. This enzyme acts on Fructose 1 phosphate & converts it into glyceraldehyde in fructose metabolism.

As Fructose 1 phosphate accumulated in blood, leading to drop in inorganic Phosphate and lesser ATP production. Increase level of AMP in blood later on degraded and more production of Uric Acid leading to Hyper uricemia.

Decreased level of ATP , decreased Gluconeogenesis leading to Hypoglycemia and low blood sugar level.

Yes Adenosine Deaminase Deficiency leads to SCID but it is not related to case given above.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with sweating and flushing over the cheek during meals, several months after undergoing parotidectomy. Based on the image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Frey's syndrome, or gustatory sweating, occurs after parotid surgery when severed cholinergic fibres regenerate and innervate sweat glands, causing facial sweating while eating. It affects about 10% of patients, typically appearing within weeks to months post-surgery. Diagnosis is confirmed with Minor's starch-iodine test, where the affected skin is coated with iodine, dusted with starch, and after eating a lemon sweet, the sweating area turns deep blue or purple. Preventive methods include raising thick skin flaps or rotating various tissue flaps. For persistent cases, botulinum toxin type A injections are the most effective treatment.
  • First bite syndrome is characterized by intense pain in the parotid gland just before eating, which subsides after starting. It results from loss of sympathetic innervation, leading to denervation super sensitivity and parasympathetic hyperactivation causing exaggerated myoepithelial contractions. It is usually self-limiting, other treatment options include pregabalin, carbamazepine, amitriptyline, botulinum toxin type A and in severe cases, total parotidectomy.

Pompe disease is only Glycogen Storage Disease that is a lysosomal storage disease. In Pompe Disease, Lysosomal Alpha 1-4 Glucosidase enzyme deficiency is present leading to accumulation of Glycogen in Lysosomes primarily affecting Heart, Liver and muscle.

Vongierke disease is due to deficiency of Glucose 6 Phosphatase mainly affecting liver and kidney. Fasting hypoglycemia, fatty liver and hepatomegaly is seen. Lactic Acidemia, Hyperlipidemia and Hyper uricemia is seen.

Cori Disease,deficiency of 4:4 Transferase and/or amylo Glucosidase (Debranching Enzyme) is seen with abnormal glycogen structure and fasting Hypoglycemia.
