questions.text: Vascular Ehlers Danlos Syndrome is having Gene Defect
questions.solution:
Ehlers-Danlos syndrome comprises a group of inherited-disorders whose

principal clinical features are

  • hyperextensibility of the skin,
  • abnormal tissue fragility, and
  • increased joint mobility.

The clinical picture is variable, reflecting underlying extensive genetic heterogeneity.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man has had increasing shortness of breath for the past year. On physical examination, he is afebrile and normotensive. Breath sounds are decreased in all lung fields. His medical history indicates that he developed marked icterus as a neonate, but he has been healthy since then. There is a family history of liver disease. A liver biopsy is performed, and the figure shows the microscopic appearance stained with PAS. This patient is most likely at a very high risk for development of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• The patient's history of neonatal jaundice and family history of liver disease, combined with the liver biopsy findings, suggest that the patient has alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD).
  • The PAS-positive globules in the liver seen here are characteristic of α1-antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. A) Acute fulminant hepatitis B: While AATD can cause liver disease, acute fulminant hepatitis B is not a typical complication.

Option A) Ulcerative colitis is strongly associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, a condition in which there is inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of bile ducts.

Option B) Diabetes mellitus: Diabetes mellitus and heart failure are features of hemochromatosis, a condition of iron overload. Iron deposition in liver is detected by the Prussian blue stain.

Option C) Pulmonary emphysema: Approximately 10% of individuals with the homozygous deficiency (PiZZ phenotype) of AAT deficiency develop significant liver disease, including neonatal hepatitis and progressive cirrhosis.

  • Deficiency of AAT also allows unchecked action of elastases in the lung, which destroys the elastic tissue and causes emphysema.
  • AAT can produce a picture of chronic hepatitis in adults; it can lead to neonatal hepatitis with acute but often transient liver injury.

D) Systemic lupus erythematosus: Systemic lupus erythematosus is an immune complex disease that may affect many organs. Liver involvement is uncommon, however.

Key takeaway:

  • AATD is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the SERPINA1 gene, which encodes the alpha-1 antitrypsin protein.
  • This protein is produced in the liver and helps protect the lungs from damage caused by the enzyme neutrophil elastase.
  • The liver biopsy findings, which show PAS-positive globules in the hepatocytes, are characteristic of AATD. These globules represent accumulated alpha-1 antitrypsin protein that is not being properly secreted from the liver.
  • Individuals with AATD are at increased risk of developing pulmonary emphysema, particularly if they smoke or have other lung disease.
  • Emphysema is a type of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) characterized by damage to the air sacs in the lungs, leading to breathlessness and other respiratory symptoms.

questions.text: Adult patients with bilateral renal cystic disease are found to have defects in renal tubular function. Their kidneys are markedly increased in size. They have ciliopathy, with reduced mechanosensing of tubular fluid flow. Mutations are found in a gene encoding for a protein component of these cilia. What is this protein most likely to be?
questions.solution:
• The patient's presentation with bilateral renal cystic disease, defects in renal tubular function, and enlarged kidneys is consistent with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).

Option A) Elongin: Elongin is a protein involved in transcriptional elongation, but it is not related to ciliopathy or renal cystic disease.

Option B) Fibrocystin: Fibrocystin is a protein involved in the function of primary cilia, but it is more commonly associated with Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD).

Option C) Nephrocystin: Nephrocystin is a protein involved in the function of primary cilia, but it is more commonly associated with Nephronophthisis, a different type of renal cystic disease.

Option D) Polycystin: The presence of ciliopathy, with reduced mechanosensing of tubular fluid flow, suggests that the protein defect is related to the function of primary cilia. Polycystin is the protein most likely to be involved, given its role in the structure and function of primary cilia in renal tubular cells.

Key takeaway:

  • ADPKD is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the PKD1 or PKD2 genes, which encode the proteins polycystin-1 (PC1) and polycystin-2 (PC2), respectively. These proteins are components of the primary cilia in renal tubular cells and play a crucial role in mechanosensing of tubular fluid flow.

questions.text: A 41-year-old G5, P5 woman has noticed lower abdominal pain with fever for the past 2 days. She delivered a normal term infant 1 week ago. On examination, she has a temperature of 37.4° C. There is a foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Which of the following pathologic findings is she most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Option A) Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia: This is a precancerous condition of the cervix, and is not typically associated with postpartum fever and abdominal pain.

Option B) Endometrial neutrophilic infiltrates: The patient's symptoms of lower abdominal pain, fever, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge, occurring 1 week postpartum, are consistent with endometritis.

  • Endometritis is an inflammation of the endometrium, typically caused by bacterial infection.
  • It is a common complication of childbirth, especially if there were any complications during delivery or if the patient had a prolonged labor.
  • The pathologic finding most likely to be associated with endometritis is the presence of neutrophilic infiltrates in the endometrium. Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that are typically present in response to bacterial infection.

Option C) Myometrial smooth muscle neoplasm: This refers to a type of tumor that arises from the smooth muscle of the uterus, and is not typically associated with postpartum fever and abdominal pain.

Option D) Ovarian endometrioma: This is a type of ovarian cyst that is associated with endometriosis, and is not typically associated with postpartum fever and abdominal pain.

Key takeaway:

  • Endometritis is a common complication of childbirth, and is typically characterized by the presence of neutrophilic infiltrates in the endometrium.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman undergoes a mammogram as part of her routine screening. The mammogram reveals a small, irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. A biopsy is performed, and the histopathology report shows:
"Proliferation of small, rounded glands with a characteristic 'suck-and-collapse' appearance, surrounded by a dense, sclerotic stroma."
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A) Fibroadenoma: This is a common benign breast tumor, but it typically has a distinct border and a uniform, glandular architecture.

Option B) Phyllodes tumor: This is a rare, fibroepithelial tumor of the breast that can be benign, borderline, or malignant. It typically has a leaf-like architecture and a cellular stroma.

Option C) Sclerosing adenosis: This is a benign proliferative lesion of the breast, characterized by the formation of small, rounded glands with a 'suck-and-collapse' appearance, surrounded by a dense, sclerotic stroma. This lesion can mimic cancer on mammography and clinical examination, but the histopathology is distinctive.

Option D) Invasive ductal carcinoma: This is the most common type of breast cancer, but it typically has a more disorganized, infiltrative architecture and lacks the characteristic 'suck-and-collapse' appearance of sclerosing adenosis.

Key takeaway:

  • Adenosis or lobulocentric processes with increase in glandular elements of terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU) with stromal fibrosis / sclerosis that distorts and compresses glands
  • Preserved 2 cell layer (inner epithelial and outer myoepithelial cells)

questions.text: 47-year-old woman noticed a lump in her neck 1 week ago. On physical examination, there is a 2-cm nodule in the right lobe of the thyroid gland. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is performed, and microscopic examination of the specimen shows cells consistent with a follicular neoplasm. She undergoes a subtotal thyroidectomy. Which of the following laboratory tests should be performed on this patient in the immediate postoperative period?
questions.solution:
Option A) Antithyroglobulin antibody: This test is used to diagnose autoimmune thyroid diseases, such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis. It is not relevant in the immediate postoperative period after a subtotal thyroidectomy.

Option B) Calcitonin: This hormone is produced by the thyroid gland and helps regulate calcium levels. However, measuring calcitonin levels is not necessary in the immediate postoperative period after a subtotal thyroidectomy.

Option C) After a subtotal thyroidectomy, the patient is at risk for hypocalcemia (low calcium levels) due to damage to the parathyroid glands, which are located near the thyroid gland and regulate calcium levels. Hypocalcemia can lead to symptoms such as muscle cramps, numbness, and tingling.

  • Monitoring calcium levels in the immediate postoperative period is crucial to detect and manage hypocalcemia promptly. This can help prevent complications and ensure the patient's safety.

Option D) Parathyroid hormone (PTH): While PTH is important for regulating calcium levels, measuring PTH levels is not as critical as measuring calcium levels in the immediate postoperative period.

Key takeaway:

After a subtotal thyroidectomy, monitoring calcium levels is crucial to detect and manage hypocalcemia promptly.

choices.text: HBsAg (+), HB core antibody (total) (+), HB core IgM (+), HBe antibody (-), HBe antigen (+), HB surface antibody (-)
HBsAg (+), HB core antibody (total) (+), HB core IgM (-), HBe antibody (+), HBe antigen (-), HB surface antibody (-)
HBsAg (-), HB core antibody (total) (+), HB core IgM (-), HBe antibody (-), HBe antigen (-), HB surface antibody (+)
HBsAg (+), HB core antibody (total) (+), HB core IgM (-), HBe antibody (-), HBe antigen (-), HB surface antibody (-)

questions.text: Which of the following serological patterns indicates acute hepatitis B infection?
questions.solution:
Option A) HBsAg (+), HB core antibody (total) (+), HB core IgM (+), HBe antibody (+), HBe antigen (+), HB surface antibody (−): Correct. This pattern is characteristic of acute hepatitis B infection. The presence of HBsAg, HB core antibody, and HB core IgM suggests an active infection, with HB core IgM indicating an acute phase. HBe antigen is positive, indicating high infectivity, and HB surface antibody is absent, showing that immunity has not yet developed.

Option B) HBsAg (+), HB core antibody (total) (+), HB core IgM (−), HBe antibody (+), HBe antigen (−), HB surface antibody (−): This pattern is more likely to represent a Hepatitis B carrier state rather than acute infection. The absence of HB core IgM and HBe antigen suggests a chronic infection with lower infectivity.

Option C) HBsAg (−), HB core antibody (total) (+), HB core IgM (−), HBe antibody (−), HBe antigen (−), HB surface antibody (+): This represents a person who has had past hepatitis B infection and has developed immunity. The presence of HB surface antibody indicates previous exposure to the virus or vaccination.

Option D) HBsAg (+), HB core antibody (total) (+), HB core IgM (−), HBe antibody (−), HBe antigen (−), HB surface antibody (−): This pattern suggests a Hepatitis B carrier state or chronic infection, without active inflammation or acute infection. HB core IgM is absent, indicating that it is not in the acute phase.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acute hepatitis B is marked by the presence of HBsAg, HB core antibody, and HB core IgM. HB core IgM is a key marker for acute infection.
  • Hepatitis B carriers will show positive HBsAg, total HB core antibody, and HBe antigen, but not HB core IgM or HB surface antibody.
  • Past infection is identified by the presence of HB surface antibody without ongoing infection markers such as HBsAg or HBe antigen.
  • Hepatitis B vaccination response is indicated by the presence of HB surface antibody

Reference:

  • World Health Organization (WHO). (2023). Hepatitis B Overview. WHO Website.
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2022). Hepatitis B Serology Interpretation. CDC Website.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with inclusion conjunctivitis, often transmitted to newborns via the birth canal?
questions.solution:
• A) Adenovirus:
    While Adenovirus (especially types 8 and 19) is a very common cause of conjunctivitis, it is not typically associated with inclusion conjunctivitis in newborns. Adenovirus usually causes acute viral conjunctivitis.
  • B) Chlamydia trachomatis (Types D-K):
    Correct Answer. Chlamydia trachomatis (Types D-K) is a leading cause of inclusion conjunctivitis, particularly in neonates, where the infection is transmitted via the birth canal. It can also cause sticky eye in infants and is common in sexually transmitted infections in adults.
  • C) Herpes simplex virus:
    Herpes simplex virus can cause conjunctivitis, particularly through reactivation in the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal ganglia, leading to corneal lesions like dendritic ulcers, but it is not typically the cause of inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • D) Streptococcus pneumoniae:
    While Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause conjunctivitis, especially in neonates (resulting in sticky eye or eyelid infection), it is not responsible for inclusion conjunctivitis. It is more commonly associated with bacterial conjunctivitis.

Key Points to Remember:

  • Chlamydia trachomatis (Types D-K) can cause inclusion conjunctivitis, particularly in neonates during birth, resulting in sticky eyes and potential complications.
  • Adenovirus (Types 8 and 19) is common in viral conjunctivitis.
  • Herpes simplex virus causes corneal lesions in the form of dendritic ulcers, not inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae can cause conjunctivitis in newborns via the birth canal.

Reference:

  • World Health Organization (WHO). (2023). Conjunctivitis and Its Causes.
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2022). Chlamydia and Neonatal Infections.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic abnormalities is commonly associated with synovial sarcoma?
questions.solution:
Option A) t(11;22)(q24;q12): This translocation is associated with Ewing's sarcoma.

Option B) t(X;18)(p11.2;q11.2): Synovial sarcoma is characterized by a specific genetic abnormality, namely the t(X;18)(p11.2;q11.2) translocation. This translocation results in the fusion of the SSX genes (SSX1, SSX2, or SSX4) with the SS18 (SYT) gene, leading to the formation of an oncogenic fusion protein.

Option C) t(9;22)(q34;q11): This translocation is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

Option D) t(12;15)(p13;q25): This translocation is associated with congenital fibrosarcoma.

Key takeaway:

Synovial sarcoma is characterized by a specific genetic abnormality, namely the t(X;18)(p11.2;q11.2) translocation, which results in the formation of an oncogenic fusion protein.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has had unilateral headaches on the right for the past 5 months. Physical examination yields no remarkable findings. The representative gross appearance of the lesion seen on CT scan of the head is shown in the figure. The mass is surgically removed and microscopic examination shows elongated cells with pale, oblong nuclei and pink cytoplasm with occasional psammoma bodies. Cytogenetic analysis shows 22q-. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A) Astrocytoma: Astrocytomas are a type of glioma that can present with a variety of symptoms, including headaches. However, they typically have a more infiltrative appearance on imaging and lack the characteristic psammoma bodies seen in meningiomas.

Option B) Ependymoma: Ependymomas are a type of glioma that arise from the ependymal cells lining the ventricles and central canal of the spinal cord. They can present with headaches, but typically have a different appearance on imaging and lack the psammoma bodies seen in meningiomas.

Option C) The clinical presentation of unilateral headaches, combined with the gross appearance of the lesion on CT scan and the microscopic findings, strongly suggests a diagnosis of meningioma.

  • Meningiomas are typically slow-growing, benign tumors that arise from the meninges, the protective membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord.
  • They are more common in women and often present with headaches, seizures, or other neurological symptoms.
  • The microscopic findings of elongated cells with pale, oblong nuclei and pink cytoplasm, along with the presence of psammoma bodies, are characteristic of meningiomas. Psammoma bodies are small, round collections of calcium that are often seen in meningiomas.
  • The cytogenetic finding of 22q- is also consistent with meningioma, as many meningiomas have been found to have deletions or mutations involving chromosome 22.

Option D) Metastasis: Metastatic tumors to the brain can present with a variety of symptoms, including headaches. However, they typically have a more irregular appearance on imaging and lack the characteristic psammoma bodies seen in meningiomas.

Key takeaway:

  • Meningiomas are slow-growing, benign tumors that arise from the meninges and can present with headaches, seizures, or other neurological symptoms. They are characterized by elongated cells with pale, oblong nuclei and pink cytoplasm, along with the presence of psammoma bodies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a butterfly-shaped rash on her face, joint pain, and kidney problems. Her laboratory tests reveal a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test. Which of the following staining patterns is most commonly associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms, including the butterfly-shaped rash, joint pain, and kidney problems, are consistent with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).
  • The homogeneous staining pattern of ANA is shown in the figure.:

Option A) Homogeneous: SLE

Option B) Speckled: Sjögren's Syndrome

  • while speckled pattern can be seen in SLE, it's more commonly associated with Sjögren's Syndrome

Option C) Nucleolar: Scleroderma

  • The nucleolar pattern is classically seen in systemic sclerosis (scleroderma).
  • It's due to antibodies like anti-Scl-70 (topoisomerase I) or anti-RNA polymerase.

Option D) Peripheral (rim): SLE

  • while peripheral pattern can be seen in SLE, homogeneous pattern is more specific

Key takeaway:

The homogeneous staining pattern of ANA is most commonly associated with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).

choices.text: To cleave the target DNA sequence

questions.text: What is the main function of the Cas9 enzyme in the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing system?
questions.solution:
Option A) To design guide RNAs: Guide RNAs are designed using software and are used to guide the Cas9 enzyme to the target DNA sequence.

Option B) To cleave the target DNA sequence: The Cas9 enzyme is an endonuclease that cleaves the target DNA sequence at a specific location, creating a double-strand break. This break is then repaired through one of two main pathways: non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) or homologous recombination (HR).

Option C) To repair the double-strand break: While Cas9 creates the double-strand break, the repair process is carried out by cellular machinery.

Option D) To synthesize new DNA strands: DNA synthesis is carried out by cellular machinery during the repair process.

Key takeaway:

  • CRISPR stands for Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats
  • Repetitive DNA sequences, called CRISPR, were observed in bacteria with “spacer” DNA sequences in between the repeats that exactly match viral sequences.
  • It was subsequently discovered that bacteria transcribe these DNA elements to RNA upon viral infection.
  • The RNA guides a nuclease (a protein that cleaves DNA) to the viral DNA to cut it, providing protection against the virus.
  • The nucleases are named “Cas,” for “CRISPR-associated.”
  • There are clinical applicationsin human trials now, including for engineering T cells outside of the body for CAR-T cancer therapy and for editing retinal cells for leber’s congenital amaurosis 10, an inherited form of blindness.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman has noticed an enlarging mass in her left breast for the past 2 years. The physician palpates a 4-cm firm mass. Following biopsy, a simple mastectomy is performed with axillary lymph node sampling. On gross sectioning, the mass has a soft, tan, fleshy surface. Histologically, the mass is composed of large cells with vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. There is a marked lymphocytic infiltrate within the tumor, and the tumor has a discrete, noninfiltrative border. No axillary node metastases are present. The tumor cells are triple negative, for HER2, estrogen receptor (ER), and progesterone receptor (PR). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A) Colloid carcinoma (also known as mucinous carcinoma) is characterized by the presence of abundant extracellular mucin, which is not mentioned in the description.

Option B) Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer, but it typically has a more infiltrative growth pattern and may have a more variable receptor status.

Option C) Infiltrating lobular carcinoma is characterized by a more diffuse, infiltrative growth pattern, and often has a positive receptor status.

Option D) Medullary carcinoma is a rare subtype of breast cancer that typically presents as a well-circumscribed, firm mass. The tumor cells are large and have vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. A distinctive feature of medullary carcinoma is the presence of a marked lymphocytic infiltrate within the tumor.

Other characteristic features of medullary carcinoma include:

- A discrete, non-infiltrative border

- Triple-negative receptor status (i.e., negative for HER2, estrogen receptor, and progesterone receptor)

- Absence of axillary node metastases

Key takeaways:

  • Medullary carcinomas account for about 1% to 5% of all breast carcinomas. They tend to occur in women at younger ages than do most other breast cancers.
  • Despite poor prognostic indicators (such as absence of HER2, ER, and PR), medullary carcinomas have a better prognosis than most other breast cancers.
  • Perhaps the infiltrating lymphocytes are a helpful immune response.

questions.text: Which of the following is most associated with the formation of foam cells in atherosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Option A) While macrophage migration is a key part of atherosclerosis, it is the uptake of oxidized LDL by these macrophages that results in foam cell formation.

Option B) Foam cells are macrophages that have taken up oxidized low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol. This is a central feature of the atherosclerotic process.

Option C) Fibrin deposition can occur in advanced plaques but is not directly related to foam cell formation.

Option D) Smooth muscle proliferation occurs in the later stages of atherosclerosis, contributing to plaque stability but is not related to foam cell formation.

Key Takeaway:

  • Foam cell formation is triggered by a number of factors including the uncontrolled uptake of modified low density lipoproteins(LDL), the upregulation of cholesterol esterification and the impairment of mechanisms associated with cholesterol release.
  • Foam cells are a significant component of atherosclerotic lesions, which are formed when circulating monocyte-derived cells are recruited to the atherosclerotic lesion site or fat deposits in the blood vessel walls.
  • Recruitment is facilitated by the molecules P-selectinand E-selectin, intercellular adhesion molecule 1 (ICAM-1) and vascular cell adhesion molecule 1 (VCAM-1)

choices.text: Anterior dislocation is the most common joint dislocation overall
Recurrence is the most common complication of an anterior shoulder dislocation
Bony Bankart's lesion can be managed by Latarjet procedure
Hill-Sachs defect occurs in the postero-medial quadrant of the humeral head

questions.text: Which of the following statements about a Bankart lesion is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Shoulder Dislocation and Related Lesions

Overview

  • Shoulder Dislocation: The shoulder is the most commonly dislocated joint in the human body, occurring more frequently in adults and rarely in children.
  • Anterior Dislocation: It is significantly more common than posterior dislocation and is the leading type of shoulder dislocation overall.

Common Complications

  • Recurrent Dislocation: This is the most common complication of an anterior shoulder dislocation.

Associated Lesions

  1. Bankart Lesion
    • Cause: Recurrent dislocations lead to stripping of the glenoidal labrum and periosteum from the antero-inferior surface of the glenoid and scapular neck.
    • Management:
      • Bankart’s Operation: Reattaches the glenoid labrum and capsule to the glenoid rim using fixation devices like anchors.
      • Bony Bankart: Managed with the Latarjet procedure.
  2. Hill-Sachs Lesion
    • Cause: A depression in the postero-lateral quadrant of the humeral head due to impingement by the anterior edge of the glenoid during dislocation.
    • Management:
      • Remplissage Procedure: Fills the defect with the joint capsule, making the defect extra-articular.

Mnemonic for Shoulder Dislocation

TUBHS

  • T: Traumatic anterior dislocation
  • U: Unilateral
  • B: Bankart’s lesion (anterior-inferior labrum)
  • H: Hill-Sachs lesion (postero-lateral humeral head)
  • S: Surgery is often mandatory

choices.text: Elevate the limb above the level of the heart
Administer analgesics and observe for 24 hours

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with severe pain in the forearm following a crush injury. The pain increases with passive stretching of the fingers, and there is swelling and tense compartment palpation. Peripheral pulses are intact. What is the most appropriate initial management step?
questions.solution:
Compartment Syndrome: Management

Definition

A surgical emergency caused by increased pressure within a closed muscle compartment, leading to impaired circulation and ischemia.

Key Clinical Signs (5 P's)

  1. Pain: Out of proportion, worsens with passive stretch.
  2. Paralysis: Loss of motor function.
  3. Paresthesias: Abnormal sensations.
  4. Pallor: Pale limb appearance.
  5. Pulselessness: Rare in early stages.

Diagnosis

  • Anterior Compartment Pressure Measurement: Confirmatory test.
  • Delta P:
    • Formula: Diastolic blood pressure - Intracompartmental pressure.
    • Threshold: Delta P < 30 mm Hg requires fasciotomy.

Management

  1. Immediate Fasciotomy: Release pressure in all affected compartments.
  2. Fracture Stabilization: Use external fixation if fractures are present.
  3. Avoid: Elevating the limb above the heart or using compression bandages.
  4. Observation: Not recommended due to risk of permanent damage (e.g., Volkmann’s contracture).

Complications of Delay

  • Muscle necrosis
  • Volkmann’s ischemic contracture
  • Nerve damage

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with shortness of breath, confusion, and petechial rash 48 hours after sustaining a long bone fracture. Chest X-ray shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fat Embolism

Fat embolism is a serious complication that typically presents 12-48 hours after a femur fracture or polytrauma. Improper handling, such as frequent shifting of the patient without proper fracture splintage, should be avoided to prevent fat embolism.

Pathophysiology

The essential feature of fat embolism is the occlusion of small blood vessels by fat globules, which can occur via two main mechanisms:

  1. Release of free fatty acids: Lipases act on neutral fat, releasing free fatty acids that induce toxic vasculitis, leading to platelet-fibrin thrombosis.
  2. Obstruction of small pulmonary vessels: Fat globules physically block small blood vessels in the lungs.

Consequences

  1. Cerebral Type:
    • Symptoms: Drowsiness, restlessness, disorientation, and gradual progression to coma.
  2. Pulmonary Type:
    • Symptoms: Tachypnea (rapid breathing) and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are the prominent features.

Common Features

  • Petechial Rash: A characteristic petechial rash may appear, typically on the front of the neck, anterior axillary folds, chest, or conjunctiva.
  • Respiratory Failure: If untreated, or in severe cases despite treatment, the patient may develop respiratory failure, which can lead to death.

Treatment

  • Oxygen support to manage respiratory distress.
  • Low molecular weight (LMW) heparin to prevent thromboembolism.
  • Steroids to reduce inflammation.

questions.text: A 6 year old male patient presented with small hypopigmented macules on cheek. There was xerosis over face. Most probable diagnosis is_
questions.solution:
P. Alba

  • Type of dermatitis
  • Occurs predominantly in children (3-16 years). Both sexes are equally susceptible.
  • C/f: Lesion is rounded, oval or irregular plaque, which is red, pink or skin- coloured and has fine lamellar or branny scaling.
  • persistent fine scaling with hypopigmentation.
  • History of atopy present.
  • Sensation intact.

Option A : P. Rosea

  • Reactive condition
  • Herald patch
  • Collarette scaling
  • Fir tree pattern of back
  • Recurrent in crops

Option B: P. Versicolor

  • Superficial fungal infection
  • Scaly macule show both hyper- and hypo- pigmentation
  • Seen on upper trunk and shoulders

Option C: Leprosy

  • Epidermal atrophy, wrinkling
  • Slight erythema or hypo pigmentation
  • Hypoesthesia

Key Takeaway

Pityriasis alba is the most likely diagnosis, characterized by small hypopigmented macules on the face, often seen in children with a history of atopy and associated with xerosis. The lesions are typically rounded or oval and may show fine scaling.

Tag:

Pityriasis alba

questions.text: A 2.5 yr old Child presents with sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet as shown in the image below. Similar history was present in elder sibling a few days back. What is the causative organism for it?
questions.solution:
The case given here is Hand foot and mouth disease . Causative agents are Coxsackievirus A16 virus and enterovirus 71. It Presents with Vesicular lesions on palms & soles, buttocks & oral cavity.

Option B : Pox virus causes molluscum contagiosum, present with asymptomatic papules with central umbilication.

Option C : Herpes virus manifests as

  • Herpes labialis
  • Herpetic gingivostomatitis
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Encephalitis

Option D : HPV virus manifest as Anogenital warts.

Key Takeaway :

Hand Foot Mouth disease :

  • Etiology : Coxsackie A16, Enterovirus 71.
  • Vesicular lesions on palms & soles, buttocks & oral cavity.

questions.text: A 32 year old female presented with a history of intense hair fall for the past 4 months. She had COVID 8 months ago. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Telogen effluvium occurs after significant systemic stress (eg. Malaria, dengue, typhoid, major illness or surgery)

It lead to premature follicular transition from anagen to telogen lead to diffuse hair fall.

Telogen hair start to shed after 3 months leading to diffuse hair fall after 3-4 months.

COVID induced telogen effluvium

  • Cytokine storm IL-6, IL-4
  • Induction of catagen
  • keratinocyte apoptosis

Option A: Female pattern hair loss is progressive gradual hair loss with widening of the central part.

Option C: Anagen effluvium

  • Anagen effluvium results from disturbance in the anagen phase of hair.
  • Cancer chemotherapy, radiation, toxins lead to sudden hair loss within 15 days.
  • Anagen hair has a pigmented hair bulb.
  • Hair regrows after the etiological factor is removed.

Option D: Trichotillomania patient present with patchy hair loss over accessible areas

  • Trichotillomania (TTM) also known as hair-pulling disorder,
  • Classical tonsular appearance (Friar tuck appearance)
  • Trichoscopy of trichotillomania is characterized by presence of hairs broken at different length, black dots, trichoptilosis, coiled hairs, flame hairs, V-sign and tulip hairs.

Key takeaway:

  • Telogen effluvium occurs after significant systemic stress (eg. Malaria, dengue,typhoid, major illness or surgery)
  • Telogen hair start to shed after 3 months leading to diffuse hair fall after 3-4 months.

Tags:

  • Telogen effluvium
  • NEET PG 2022

Reference: Mieczkowska K, Deutsch A, Borok J, Guzman AK, Fruchter R, Patel P, Wind O, McLellan BN, Mann RE, Halverstam CP. Telogen effluvium: a sequela of COVID-19. International journal of dermatology. 2021 Jan;60(1):122.

questions.solution:
• Patch test is the gold standard test for diagnosis of Allergic contact dermatitis.

  • Allergens are applied over back of patient. First reading is done after 48 hours. Next reading should be done at 96 hours. (Best reading at 96 hrs).
  • Phytophotodermatitis is an air borne contact dermatitis, most common cause of ACD in india. Cause is plant - parthenium hysterophorus (Congress grass)
  • Antigen is Sesquiterpene lactone
  • Sites involved are exposed area of body
  • Photopatch test is useful test in photoallergic dermatitis, here UVA is used

Option A: Serum IgE is minor criteria in diagnosis of Atopic dermatitis

Option B: Radioallergosorbent test measures specific IgE

Option D: Immunoturbidimetry use to estimate serum protein.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a radiological parameter used to diagnose DDH?
questions.solution:
Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH):

  • Involves:
    • Subluxation: Partial dislocation of the femoral head.
    • Complete dislocation: The femoral head is completely dislocated from the true acetabulum.
    • Acetabular dysplasia: Poorly formed acetabulum.

Acetabular Index: Option C

  • Angle formed by Hilgenreiner's line and a line from the lateral triradiate cartilage to the lateral margin of the acetabulum.
  • Normal value: less than 25° in children older than 6 months.
  • Seen on X-ray.

Alpha Angle: Option B

  • Created by lines along the bony acetabulum and the ilium.
  • Normal value: greater than 60°.
  • Seen on ultrasound (USG).

Beta Angle: Option A

  • Formed by lines along the labrum and the ilium.
  • Normal value: less than 55°.
  • Seen on ultrasound (USG).

Kite’s Angle: Option D

  • Also known as the talo-calcaneal angle.
  • Normal value: between 20-40 degrees.
  • In congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), it is less than 20 degrees.
  • Not used in diagnosing DDH.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with pain and swelling at the base of his thumb after a skiing accident where he fell with his thumb extended and caught on a ski pole. MRI shows tear of the UCL of MCP joint. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Skier’s Thumb / Gamekeeper’s Thumb

Definition: Option B
Skier's thumb (also known as Gamekeeper’s thumb) is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the metacarpo-phalangeal joint of the thumb.

Causes of Injury:

  • Activities:
    • Skiing
    • Holding a catch
    • Twisting the neck of small animals

Types of Injuries:

  1. Acute Injuries (Skier’s Thumb)
  2. Chronic Injuries (Gamekeeper’s Thumb)

Mechanism of Injury:

  • Forceful thumb hyperextension and/or hyperabduction.
  • Occurs through supination of the proximal phalanx around an intact radial collateral ligament (RCL).

Clinical Considerations:

  • UCL Function: Critical for strong and effective pinch.
  • Tears: Difficult to differentiate between complete and partial tears based on physical examination alone.

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging:
    • Stress radiographs
    • MRI

Treatment Options:

  • Incomplete Rupture:
    • Conservative treatment with a thumb spica cast or functional cast brace.
  • Complete Rupture:
    • Surgical repair is necessary.
  • Stener Lesion:
    • Occurs in approximately 85% of complete injuries when the adductor pollicis aponeurosis becomes interposed between the retracted ligament, hindering healing.
    • Requires surgical reattachment of the ligament through drill holes, suture anchor, or interference screw.
  • Large Displaced Avulsion Fracture:
    • Requires Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF).

questions.text: What is the required duration for the symptoms of ADHD to be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD):

  • Diagnosis Criteria:
    • Symptoms must persist for ≥6 months and be present before age 12.
    • Symptoms include inattention (e.g., poor attention to detail, forgetfulness) and hyperactivity/impulsivity (e.g., fidgeting, difficulty waiting turns).
    • ≥6 symptoms are needed for children; ≥5 symptoms for those aged 17+.
    • Symptoms must occur in >1 setting and cause functional impairment.
  • Subtypes of ADHD:
    • Combined presentation: Both inattention and hyperactivity/impulsivity.
    • Predominantly inattentive presentation.
    • Predominantly hyperactive/impulsive presentation.
  • Exclusions:
    • Symptoms cannot be explained by another mental illness or conditions like conduct disorder.
    • ADHD can coexist with other disorders like anxiety, oppositional defiant disorder, or learning disabilities.
  • Course & Prognosis:
    • 60-85% of children with ADHD will continue symptoms into adolescence, and about 60% will have symptoms into adulthood.
    • Hyperactivity often remits first, but inattention and impulsivity may persist.
    • Comorbid psychiatric disorders (e.g., conduct disorder, depression, anxiety) significantly affect long-term outcomes.
    • Children with ADHD are at higher risk for substance use and conduct disorders if ADHD persists.
  • Risk Factors for Poor Outcome:
    • Family history of ADHD, comorbid disorders, and chaotic family environments predict persistence and severity of symptoms.
    • Social difficulties and academic challenges are common, requiring early intervention to improve outcomes.

Tags:

Topic: ADHD, Diagnostic criteria

choices.text: Eggs in feces have a characteristic operculum (lid).
Acquired through consumption of undercooked beef.
Often associated with vitamin B1 deficiency.
Treatment involves the use of amoxicillin and mebendazole.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Diphyllobothrium latum, the fish tapeworm, based on its transmission, pathology, and diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A) Eggs in feces have a characteristic operculum (lid): This is the correct answer. Diphyllobothrium latum, also known as the fish tapeworm, produces eggs that have a characteristic operculum, which can be identified in fecal samples using concentration techniques. This feature helps in diagnosing the infection.
  • Option B) Acquired through consumption of undercooked beef: This statement is incorrect. Diphyllobothrium latum is acquired through the consumption of undercooked or raw freshwater fish, not beef. The larvae of the tapeworm are present in the flesh of the fish, and ingestion of these larvae causes infection.
  • Option C) Often associated with vitamin B1 deficiency: This is also incorrect. The main nutritional deficiency associated with Diphyllobothrium latum infection is vitamin B12, not B1. The tapeworm absorbs vitamin B12 from the host, potentially leading to a deficiency and associated symptoms like anemia.
  • Option D) Treatment involves the use of amoxicillin and mebendazole: This option is incorrect. The treatment for Diphyllobothrium latum infection usually involves anthelmintic drugs like niclosamide or praziquantel. Amoxicillin is an antibiotic and is not effective for helminthic infections, and mebendazole is generally used for other types of worms.

Key Takeaways:

  • Diphyllobothrium latum is a tapeworm that can be acquired from eating raw or undercooked freshwater fish.
  • The eggs of Diphyllobothrium latum have a distinct operculum (lid), which is a key diagnostic feature.
  • The infection is usually harmless but can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency, causing symptoms like anemia.
  • The primary treatment options include niclosamide and praziquantel.
  • Prevention involves proper cooking or freezing of fish to kill the larval stages of the worm.

Table: Characteristics of Diphyllobothrium latum

References:

  • WHO (2018). Diphyllobothrium latum - Fish Tapeworm. World Health Organization. WHO Website
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2020). Diphyllobothrium latum (Fish Tapeworm). CDC Website

choices.text: Prion diseases are caused by viruses that replicate rapidly and have a short incubation period.
Prions cause spongiform encephalopathies and are highly resistant to heat, chemical agents, and irradiation.
Prion diseases are usually caused by bacterial infections in the central nervous system.
The transmission of prion diseases primarily occurs through direct bacterial contact with the nervous system.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding prion diseases?
questions.solution:
• Option A) Prion diseases are caused by viruses that replicate rapidly and have a short incubation period: This is incorrect. Prion diseases are not caused by viruses, but by transmissible proteins (prions). They have very slow replication and long incubation periods, often up to 20 years in humans.
  • Option B) Prions cause spongiform encephalopathies and are highly resistant to heat, chemical agents, and irradiation: This is the correct answer. Prions are proteins that cause progressive neurodegenerative diseases known as spongiform encephalopathies. They are highly resistant to standard sterilization procedures, including heat, chemicals, and irradiation.
  • Option C) Prion diseases are usually caused by bacterial infections in the central nervous system: This is incorrect. Prion diseases are not caused by bacteria, but by misfolded proteins (prions) that cause damage to brain tissue, resulting in spongiform changes
  • Option D) The transmission of prion diseases primarily occurs through direct bacterial contact with the nervous system: This is incorrect. Prion diseases are transmitted through ingestion of infected tissue, not by bacterial contact. They are caused by the misfolding of prion proteins.

Key Takeaways:

  • Prions are misfolded proteins that cause spongiform encephalopathies (neurodegenerative diseases).
  • Prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), Gerstmann-Straüssler-Scheinker syndrome (GSS), and fatal familial insomnia (FFI), are slow-developing, have long incubation periods, and are transmissible.
  • Prions are resistant to heat, chemicals, and irradiation, making them difficult to destroy.
  • These diseases are typically transmitted through ingestion of contaminated tissue, and in some cases, by inheritance due to genetic mutations in the prion protein gene.

References:

  • National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS). (2021). Prion Diseases. NINDS Website
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2021). Prion Diseases. CDC Website

choices.text: Staphylococcus epidermidis is a common cause of foodborne infections and gastroenteritis.
It is an opportunistic pathogen that is commonly associated with device-related sepsis and prosthetic valve endocarditis.
Staphylococcus epidermidis typically ferments mannitol on mannitol salt agar.
This bacterium is always sensitive to methicillin and is rarely antibiotic-resistant.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Staphylococcus epidermidis?
questions.solution:
• A) Staphylococcus epidermidis is a common cause of foodborne infections and gastroenteritis: This is incorrect. epidermidis is an opportunistic pathogen primarily associated with infections related to medical devices, such as catheters and prostheses, not foodborne infections.
  • B) It is an opportunistic pathogen that is commonly associated with device-related sepsis and prosthetic valve endocarditis: This is the correct answer. Staphylococcus epidermidis is primarily an opportunistic pathogen that causes infections related to medical devices, such as catheters, prosthetic heart valves, artificial joints, and shunts.
  • C) Staphylococcus epidermidis typically ferments mannitol on mannitol salt agar: This is incorrect. Unlike Staphylococcus aureus, epidermidis does not ferment mannitol and usually results in a negative reaction on mannitol salt agar.
  • D) This bacterium is always sensitive to methicillin and is rarely antibiotic-resistant: This is incorrect. epidermidis is often methicillin-resistant and can be multi-drug resistant, which complicates treatment options.

Key Takeaways:

  • Staphylococcus epidermidis is part of the normal human skin flora, and it is commonly encountered as an opportunistic pathogen in hospital settings, particularly in patients with implanted medical devices.
  • It can cause infections such as device-related sepsis, prosthetic valve endocarditis, and urinary tract infections.
  • The bacterium is coagulase-negative and typically does not ferment mannitol on agar.
  • epidermidis is often resistant to multiple antibiotics, including methicillin.

References:

  • National Institutes of Health (NIH). (2021). Staphylococcus epidermidis NIH Website
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2021). Staphylococcus epidermidis CDC Website

questions.text: A 34-year-old gardener presents with an ulcerative lesion on his hand that began as a small nodule after a thorn puncture. Over the next few weeks, the lesion has spread along the lymphatic tract, developing multiple small bumps that eventually ulcerated. Upon examination, the lesion is found to have surrounding erythema and swelling. A fungal culture is performed, revealing budding cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A) Sporotrichosis: This is the correct answer. Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus commonly associated with gardening and other activities involving plant matter. It enters the body through broken skin, typically via thorns, and causes a localized infection that can spread along the lymphatics, resulting in an ulcerative lesion and sometimes multiple draining bumps (lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis). Budding yeast cells in exudate or culture confirm the diagnosis.
  • B) Candidiasis: This is incorrect. Candidiasis is caused by Candida species, which are opportunistic fungi, typically affecting mucosal surfaces, skin, and nails. It does not present with the same characteristic ulcerative lesions or lymphatic spread as seen in sporotrichosis.
  • C) Blastomycosis: This is incorrect. Blastomycosis is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, a dimorphic fungus that can cause pulmonary and disseminated disease, often presenting with respiratory symptoms and systemic involvement. It does not cause localized lymphocutaneous infection after a skin injury.
  • D) Histoplasmosis: This is incorrect. Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, which is primarily associated with inhalation of fungal spores from contaminated bird or bat droppings. It presents with pulmonary symptoms and may disseminate, but does not cause the characteristic skin lesions seen in sporotrichosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sporotrichosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, a dimorphic fungus. It is often contracted through skin punctures with contaminated plant material (thorns).
  • The infection typically spreads along the lymphatics, resulting in multiple ulcerative lesions, a feature known as lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying budding yeast cells in tissue exudate or culture.
  • First-line treatment is itraconazole, although other antifungals like potassium iodide may also be used in some cases.

Additional Notes:

  • Although the condition is often self-limited, it may cause significant morbidity if left untreated or in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Prevention involves wearing protective gloves when handling plants or soil that may contain the fungus.

References:

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2020). Sporotrichosis. CDC Website

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the clinic with a sore throat, fever, and a bright red rash that has a sandpaper-like texture. The child's mother reports that the rash appeared after the sore throat. Upon examination, the child also has swollen lymph nodes and a "strawberry tongue". A throat culture confirms the presence of Streptococcus pyogenes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A) Scarlet fever: This is the correct answer. Scarlet fever is a condition caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) and is characterized by a sore throat, fever, a characteristic red "sandpaper-like" rash, and "strawberry tongue". It often occurs in children and follows a throat infection with the bacteria that produces erythrogenic toxins.
  • B) Rheumatic fever: This is incorrect. Rheumatic fever is a complication that can develop after a throat infection with Streptococcus pyogenes. It involves the heart, joints, and nervous system, but it does not present with the acute symptoms of sore throat, rash, and strawberry tongue seen in scarlet fever.
  • C) Tonsillitis: This is incorrect. Tonsillitis involves inflammation of the tonsils, typically accompanied by sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing, but it does not have the characteristic rash or "strawberry tongue" that is seen in scarlet fever.
  • D) Chickenpox: This is incorrect. Chickenpox causes a different type of rash, with fluid-filled vesicles that crust over. It is caused by the varicella-zoster virus, not Streptococcus pyogenes, and does not present with the same clinical features like sore throat and strawberry tongue.

Key Takeaways:

  • Scarlet fever is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, which produces erythrogenic toxin responsible for the characteristic rash and symptoms such as sore throat, fever, strawberry tongue, and lymphadenopathy.
  • The condition typically follows a throat infection (e.g., pharyngitis) and is most common in children.
  • Penicillin is the first-line treatment for Streptococcus pyogenes infections, including scarlet fever.
  • Complications of untreated Streptococcus pyogenes infections include rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis.

Additional Notes:

  • Scarlet fever is typically diagnosed based on clinical features and confirmed with throat culture for Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • The rash in scarlet fever starts on the neck, chest, and underarms, then spreads to the trunk and limbs.

References:

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2020). Scarlet Fever. CDC Website

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient visited psychiatric outpatient department to get rid of her long term smoking addiction. Which of the following drug should be prescribed to her so that she can get rid of her smoking addiction problem?
questions.solution:
Varenicline

  • This α4β2 subtype NR selective partial agonist has been marketed as oral tablets in many countries, and recently in India, to help smoking cessation.
  • Evidence has shown that the reward (reinforcing) action of nicotine is exerted through the α4β2 subtype of neuronal Nicotinic Receptors which are mainly localized in nucleus accumbens and other mesolimbic areas.
  • Activation of these Nicotinic Receptors by nicotine induces DA release which produces feelings of satisfaction/reward and has reinforcing effect.
  • Since varenicline is a partial agonist at these receptors, it provides some level of nicotine substitution, but blocks the reward effect of smoking.
  • Clinically it has been found to reduce craving as well as nicotine withdrawal symptoms in those who stop smoking

Option A: Naloxone is helpful in opioids poisoning

Option B: Disulfiram can be used in psychologically dependent persons who are motivated to quit alcohol. It is contraindicated in physically dependent individuals.

Disulfiram produces severe distressing symptoms (like flushing, headache, vomiting, visual disturbances and mental confusion) after intake of alcohol

Option C: Flumazenil is a specific antagonist of benzodiazepine receptors. It can be used to treat BZD poisoning but not barbiturate poisoning

Key Takeaway:

  • Varenicline is used for smoking cessation.

Tag: Varenicline

questions.text: A 49 year old anxious male is a hypertensive patient has heart rate of 90 beats/min and taking tablet metoprolol 300 mg/day in divided doses. After receiving anesthesia, his heart rate fell down to 40 beats/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment during anaesthesia to improve his heart rate?
questions.solution:
• The most prominent effect of atropine is tachycardia.
  • It is due to blockade of M2 receptors on the SA node through which vagal tone decreases Heart Rate.
  • Atropine abbreviates refractory period of A-V node and facilitates A-V conduction, especially if it has been depressed by high vagal tone. P-R interval is shortened.

Option A, C & D: Dobutamine, adrenaline and isoprenaline act by stimulating b1 receptors in heart. As patient has b-blocker overdose, these are likely to be ineffective

Key Takeaway:

  • Atropine can increase heart rate in this person by blocking parasympathetic action on heart.

Tag: Atropine

questions.text: Which of the following drug is a PCSK-9 inhibitor approved for familial hypercholesterolemia?
questions.solution:
• PCSK9 Inhibitors Proprotein convertase subtilisin kexin type 9 (PCSK 9) is a protein that binds LDL-receptors and transport them to lysosomes where these are degraded.
  • Therefore instead of recycling of LDL-R to surface of hepatocytes, they get destroyed.
  • Inhibitors of PCSK 9, therefore prevent destruction of LDL-R resulting in lowering of LDL-cholesterol.
  • Alirocumab and evolocumab are monoclonal antibodies against PCSK 9 and are approved for familial hypercholesterolemia as an adjunct to diet and maximally tolerated statin therapy.

Key takeaway:

  • Alirocumab and evolocumab are monoclonal antibodies against PCSK 9 and are approved for familial hypercholesterolemia as an adjunct to diet and maximally tolerated statin therapy.

Explanation of other options

B) Ezetimibe

  • Inhibits NPC1L1 transporter → reduces intestinal absorption of cholesterol
  • Used for hyperlipidemia, often combined with statins

C) Bempedoic acid

  • Inhibits ATP citrate lyase, an enzyme upstream of HMG-CoA reductase → lowers cholesterol
  • New oral non-statin agent

D) Clofibrate

  • Fibrate class → activates PPAR-α → reduces triglycerides
  • Older drug, no longer commonly used due to side effects

Tag: Evolocumab

questions.text: A 39 year old male patient brought to emergency department with complaints of acute chest pain, mimicking an acute anginal attack. Which of the following medication that can be used in the treatment of angina and its prevention in this patient, which acts through opening of cardiac potassium channels?
questions.solution:
• Nicorandil This dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.
  • The vasodilator action is partly antagonized by the K+ channel blocker glibenclamide.
  • Like nitrates it also acts as a NO donor-relaxes blood vessels by increasing cGMP.
  • Thus, arterial dilatation is coupled with venodilatation, and both cardiac preload as well as afterload are reduced.
  • Beneficial effects on angina frequency and exercise tolerance comparable to nitrates and CCBs have been obtained in stable as well as vasospastic angina.
  • Nicorandil is believed to exert cardioprotective action by simulating 'ischaemic preconditioning' as a result of activation of mitochondrial KATP channels.

Side effects of nicorandil

  • Flushing
  • Palpitation
  • Weakness
  • Headache
  • Dizziness
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Large painful aphthous ulcers in the mouth, which heal on stopping nicorandil

Key takeaway:

  • Nicorandil is the agent that causes coronary dilation by activating myocardial ATP sensitive K+ channels. In addition it possesses NO releasing property; to which tolerance does not develop.

Tag: Nicorandil

questions.text: A 56 yr old male with a known history of hypertension presented to emergency ward with fatigue, drowsiness, inability to urinate and weight loss. Later he diagnosed with end stage chronic kidney disease with eGFR <20 ml/min. His doctor wants to prescribe a thiazide diuretic. Which of the following is the most appropriate thiazide diuretic of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Metolazone In common with loop diuretics, it is able to evoke a clinically useful response even in severe renal failure (g.f.r. ~15 ml/min), and has marked additive action when combined with furosemide.
  • An additional proximal tubular action has been demonstrated; PO4 reabsorption that occurs in Proximal tubule, is inhibited.
  • It is excreted unchanged in urine. Metolazone has been used mainly for edema.

Key takeaway:

  • Metolazone In common with loop diuretics, it is able to evoke a clinically useful response even in severe renal failure

Tag: Metolazone

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient undergoes laparoscopic removal of tubal ectopic. At the end of the surgery, the patient is extubated . Suddenly retches, vomits and aspirates. Which of the following will not form part of her immediate management?
questions.solution:
• Aspiration pneumonitis (Mendelson’s syndrome): Inflammatory reaction of lung parenchyma following aspiration of gastric contents, originally described in obstetric patients.
  • Treatment is mainly supportive, with O2 therapy, bronchodilator drugs, and removal of aspirate and secretions by physiotherapy and suction. Bronchoscopy may be required to remove large particulate matter.

questions.text: Sexual asphyxia is seen in
questions.solution:
Sexual asphyxia is seen in masochism.

In masochism, the person obtains sexual gratification by suffering pain. Partial hanging can be used as a means to obtain sexual gratification. Failure to release the ligature might lead to asphyxia and death. This is known as sexual asphyxia (autoerotic death). It is more common in males.

Other options -

Option A: Fetichism means the use of fetish for sexual gratification. A fetish is an abnormal stimulus or object of sexual desire. In this, recurrent, intense sexual fantasies, sexual urges or behaviour involving the use of living or non-living objects. It is almost exclusively seen in males. It is harmless, but rarely it may drive the person to obtain his fetish object through violence or criminal act.

Option C: Sexual oralism is obtaining sexual pleasure from the application of mouth to the sexual organs.

Option D: Necrophagia means sadistic perversion seen among male, who gets sexual gratification by tearing out the genitals or other parts like breasts, buttocks, etc. of their partner after her death by his teeth and may virtually eat them raw.

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, altered sensorium. The poisoning is?
questions.solution:
• Datura is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties. It can cause symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity, which include dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and altered sensorium. This is consistent with the clinical presentation described.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Morphine:
    Morphine is an opioid and typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), not mydriasis. It can lead to respiratory depression and altered sensorium, but the dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic of morphine poisoning.
  • Option B - Cannabis:
    Cannabis can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech but is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Cannabis effects are typically less severe and do not match the full clinical picture described.
  • Option D - Alcohol:
    Alcohol can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech, but it is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Alcohol typically causes miosis and does not have the anticholinergic effects seen with Datura.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic symptoms, including dry skin, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and altered sensorium.

questions.text: Which of the following tests measures ratio of weight of the lungs to the body weight that helps in determination of whether the baby was born alive or not?
questions.solution:
The test that measures the ratio of the weight of the lungs to the body weight that helps in the determination of whether the baby was born alive or not is Plocquet's test.

Plocquet's test: It is based on the ratio of weight of lungs to whole body weight, a respired lung weighs 1/35 of the body weight.

Before respiration: 1/70 of body weight

After respiration: 1/35 of body weight

Other options:

Option A: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test: It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration. On breathing, the volume of the lungs is increased, which more than compensates for the weight of additional blood, due to which specific gravity is diminished. Hence, after respiration, the lung floats in water.

Option C: Breslau's second life test: It works on the principle that some air is swallowed during respiration in a live-born child and detecting the presence of this air in these viscera constitutes the basis for this 1 test.

Option D: Wredin's test: Before birth, the middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue and not air. With respiration, the eustachian tube opens and air replaces the gelatinous substances in a few hours to five weeks.

questions.text: An intern while putting the catheter forgot to pull the prepuce back which led to paraphimosis. The head of the department was held liable for the intern's negligence. What is this called?
questions.solution:
The senior doctor is responsible for the negligent act of a junior doctor, resident, intern, or assistant working under him by the principle respondeat superior (vicarious liability).

Vicarious liability is by which the employer is responsible for his employees' negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope. It is by the principle of 'respondeat superior' (let the superior answer).

When two doctors practice as partners, they are both responsible for each other's negligent acts. When 2 or more doctors independently attend to a patient, each may be held liable for the negligence of others that he observes or in the ordinary course should have observed and allowed 1 it to continue without objection.

Other options:

Option A: When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily loses his control over this worker and the borrowing employer assumes control. This is known as the borrowed servant doctrine.

Option B: Res ipsa loquitur means 'the thing speaks for itself'. It is used as supportive evidence of negligence on the part of the doctor. Say leaving behind a scalpel or scissors whilst operating leading to sepsis/peritonitis speaks for itself.

Option C: Res indicata-A suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed.

questions.text: Hypyopyon corneal ulcer is most commonly caused by which of the following organisms:
questions.solution:
Hypopyon Corneal Ulcer:

Etiopathogenesis

  • Causative Organisms:
    • Pneumococcus: Classic "ulcus serpens."
    • Corneal ulcer WITH hypopyon: Staphylococci, Streptococci, Gonococci, Moraxella, Pseudomonas.
    • Source: Chronic dacryocystitis (especially for pneumococcal ulcers).
  • Predisposing Factors:
    • Virulence of organisms.
    • Weakened host resistance (e.g., old age, alcoholism).
  • Mechanism:
    • Bacterial toxins cause iritis → leukocytes accumulate in the anterior chamber → sterile hypopyon.
    • Resolves as the ulcer heals.

Clinical Features

  • Symptoms: Similar to bacterial ulcers but early stages of ulcus serpens show minimal pain.
  • Signs (Ulcus Serpens):
    • Greyish-white/yellow disc-shaped central ulcer.
    • Spreads in a serpiginous pattern with uneven edges.
    • Associated violent iridocyclitis and hypopyon.
  • Rapid progression → secondary glaucoma and risk of perforation.

Management

  • General treatment for bacterial corneal ulcers.
  • Special considerations:
    • Treat secondary glaucoma (e.g., timolol maleate 0.5%, acetazolamide).
    • Address infection source (e.g., dacryocystectomy for chronic dacryocystitis).

Complications

  1. Toxic Iridocyclitis: Toxin absorption into the anterior chamber.
  2. Secondary Glaucoma: Inflammatory exudates block the angle.
  3. Descemetocele: Herniation of Descemet's membrane → impending perforation.
  4. Perforation: Sudden rupture from strain → sequelae:
    • Iris prolapse, lens dislocation, anterior capsular cataract, corneal fistula.
    • Severe outcomes: Uveitis, endophthalmitis, panophthalmitis, intraocular hemorrhage.
  5. Corneal Scarring: Permanent vision impairment ranging from nebula to anterior staphyloma.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are specifically targeted for blindness prevention under the Vision 2020 program in India?
questions.solution:
Strategic Plan for Vision 2020: The Right to Sight in India

In August 2002, the 'Working Group' submitted a draft plan for Vision 2020 to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. The key strategies include:

A. Strengthening Advocacy

  • National & State Levels:
    • Raise awareness about eye care via media (press releases, articles, TV/Radio broadcasts).
    • Involve professional organizations like AIOS, EBAI, and IMA.
    • Introduce eye care topics in school curricula.
    • Publish quarterly newsletters and scientific journal articles.
  • District Level:
    • Strengthen District Blindness Control Societies (DBCS).
    • Involve local NGOs, community leaders, and volunteers.
    • Use media for awareness and communication at the grassroots level.

B. Reduction of Disease Burden

Target diseases for intervention:

  1. Cataract: The leading cause of blindness. Targets include increasing cataract surgery rates and improving outcomes.
  2. Childhood Blindness: A focus on prevention and early treatment for causes like vitamin A deficiency, congenital cataracts, and retinopathy of prematurity.
  3. Refractive Errors and Low Vision: Ensure access to refraction services and low-cost spectacles.
  4. Glaucoma: Early detection through opportunistic screening.
  5. Diabetic Retinopathy: Regular screening for diabetics to prevent blindness.
  6. Corneal Blindness: Promote eye donation and effective treatment through keratoplasty.

C. Human Resource Development

  • Mid-Level Ophthalmic Personnel (MLOP): Includes hospital-based and community-based personnel like ophthalmic nurses, technicians, optometrists, and assistants.

D. Eye Care Infrastructure Development

  • Primary Level: Develop 20,000 vision centers with trained ophthalmic assistants.
  • Secondary Level: Establish 2,000 service centers with ophthalmologists and paramedics.
  • Tertiary Level: Create 200 training centers and 20 Centers of Excellence (COE) for advanced ophthalmic care.

The overall goal is to eliminate avoidable blindness and improve eye care infrastructure and human resources across India by 2020.

questions.text: What is the concentration of topical acyclovir used in viral keratitis?
questions.solution:
Acyclovir Overview:

Acyclovir is a selective, virustatic drug activated in virus-infected cells, making it effective for treating herpesvirus infections such as herpes simplex keratitis and herpes zoster. It is less toxic than other antiviral drugs.

  • Topical Treatment: Acyclovir 3% ointment is applied five times a day until the infection subsides.
  • Systemic Use:
    • For recurrent herpes simplex keratitis, herpes simplex iridocyclitis, and acute herpes zoster ophthalmicus, oral acyclovir is administered.
    • Oral acyclovir (400 mg) five times a day for 5-7 days for acute herpes simplex infections.
    • Prophylactic use: 200 mg twice daily for 6 months to 1 year to prevent recurrent infections.
    • For herpes zoster ophthalmicus, 800 mg five times a day for 7-10 days within 72 hours to reduce neuralgia and complications like uveitis.

Acyclovir is also effective against Epstein-Barr virus and cytomegalovirus (CMV). Its intraocular penetration is good, allowing effective treatment for keratouveitis and acute retinal necrosis.
