To measure the refractive error of the eye

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of the Ishihara chart?
questions.solution:
Isochromatic Charts - Key Points:

  • Design: Composed of colored lithographic plates with bold numerals represented in dots of various tints.
  • Purpose: To test for color vision deficiencies, particularly red-green and blue-yellow anomalies.
  • Normal Trichromats: Can easily read the numbers.
  • Color Defective Individuals: May have difficulty distinguishing the numbers, depending on their specific color defect.
  • Types of Tests:
    • Red-green anomalies: Identified by Ishihara chart (replacing Stilling's original tests).
    • Blue-yellow anomalies: Identified by the Hardy-Rand-Ritler (H-R-R) test.
  • Use: Primarily used to assess color blindness and deficiencies in clinical settings.

questions.text: A 60 year old diabetic patient presented with right sided severe ear ache, rapidly progressing infection in the external auditory canal with involvement of bone and presence of granulation tissue. What will be the drug of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Malignant otitis externa, also known as necrotizing otitis externa or malignant external otitis (MEO), is an infection that affects the external auditory canal and temporal bone.

The causative organism is usually Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and the disease commonly manifests in elderly patients with diabetes. The infection begins as an external otitis that progresses into an osteomyelitis of the temporal bone. Spread of the disease outside the external auditory canal occurs through the fissures of Santorini and the osseocartilaginous junction.

The pain Is out of proportion to the physical examination findings. Marked tenderness is present in the soft tissue between the mandibular ramus and mastoid tip.

Granulation tissue is present at the floor of the osseocartilaginous junction. This finding is virtually pathognomonic of malignant external otitis (MEO). Otoscopic examination may also reveal exposed bone.

Treatment includes meticulous glucose control, aural toilet, systemic and ototopic antimicrobial therapy. Fluoroquinolones that attain high soft tissue and bone levels with oral doses were then developed. Subsequently, several authors have demonstrated the efficacy of oral ciprofloxacin monotherapy.

questions.text: Wullstein classification type 3 tympanoplasty is ?
questions.solution:
Type I Tympanoplasty

Involves reconstruction of a new tympanic membrane in situations with a normal ossicular chain; recreates the middle ear space nearly exactly to its native size and geometry. It is termed as myringoplasty.

Type II Tympanoplasty

Involves reconstruction of a new tympanic membrane in situations where the malleus is partially eroded; the new tympanic membrane is coupled with or without the malleus remnant to the native incus.it is termed as myringo ossiculoplasty

Type III Tympanoplasty

Involves reconstruction of a new tympanic membrane in situations involving defects of the malleus and incus; the new tympanic membrane is coupled to the capitulum of the stapes. It is also termed as Myringostapedopexy.

Type IV Tympanoplasty

Involves reconstruction of a new tympanic membrane and establishment of ossicular coupling to a mobile stapes footplate with absent crura; the new tympanic membrane is coupled to the footplate of the stapes.

Type V Tympanoplasty

Involves reconstruction of a new tympanic membrane and establishment of ossicular coupling to the scala vestibuli in situations involving a fixed stapedial footplate; creation of a fenestra is necessary hence it is also called fenestration operation.

questions.text: Potts puffy tumor occurs due to repeated infection of which of the following sinus ?
questions.solution:
Pott puffy tumor is a subperiosteal abscess due to associated frontal skull osteomyelitis. This usually occurs as a rare complication of frontal sinusitis or trauma to the forehead, that presents with tender forehead swelling associated with fever, headaches, nasal discharge, or symptoms of increased intracranial pressure.

The frontal scalp swelling with edema is caused by underlying osteomyelitis of the frontal bone with an associated subperiosteal abscess, which, if not treated, leads to severe complications.

The pathophysiology for the development of frontal skull osteomyelitis can occur due to hematogenous spread of the infection or to direct extension of infection.

Hematogenous spread: It is the most common route. The process starts with frontal sinusitis that is untreated or partially treated, which leads to vascular compromise of the area, which in part leads to the development of secondary septic thrombophlebitis. This produces bone necrosis and an increased risk of intracranial complications. The communication of frontal sinus with dural venous plexuses through diploic veins can propagate septic emboli and lead to intracranial involvement with or without direct erosion of the frontal bone.

Direct extension: From an open trauma to the forehead, which becomes infected. Bacterial sinusitis in contact with the frontal skull bone.

questions.text: Today it is considered as negligence to omit APGAR scoring of a newborn infant, especially low birth weight babies. The APGAR score is taken at ___ and again at ___ after birth. Fill the black space with correct option?
questions.solution:
• The APGAR score is taken at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.
  • It requires immediate and careful observation of the heart rate, respiration, muscle tone, reflex response and colour of the infant.
  • Each sign is given a score of 0, 1, or 2.
  • It provides immediate estimate of the physical condition of the baby.
  • A perfect score should be 9 or 10, 0-3 indicated the baby is severely depressed and 4-6 moderately depressed.
  • Infants with low APGAR scores at 5 minutes of age are subject to high risk of complications and death during the neonatal period.

choices.text: Vitamin C, by oxidising ferrous iron to ferric iron, facilitates the iron absorption.
Vitamin C, by reducing ferrous iron to ferric iron, facilitates the iron absorption.
Vitamin C, by oxidising ferric iron to ferrous iron, facilitates iron absorption.
Vitamin C, by reducing ferric iron to ferrous iron, facilitates the iron absorption.

questions.text: Often it is observed that along with Iron folic acid tablets, Vitamin C tablets are also prescribed to patients. What can be the reason behind this practice?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin C is a potent antioxidant and has an important role to play in tissue oxidation.
  • It is needed for collagen formation, which accounts for 25% of total body protein.
  • Collagen provides a supporting matrix for the blood vessels and connective tissue, and for bones and cartilage, that explains why in Vitamin C deficiency this support fails with the result that local haemorrhages occur and the bones fracture easily.
  • Vitamin C by reducing ferric iron to ferrous iron, facilitates the absorption of iron from vegetable foods.

questions.text: Methylene blue reduction test is used to detect microorganisms in?
questions.solution:
• The safety and keeping quality of milk are related to its microbial content.
  • Methylene blue reduction test is an indirect method for detection of microorganisms in milk.
  • The test is carried out on the milk accepted for pasteurization.
  • It is based on the observation that bacteria growing in milk bring about a decrease in colour imparted to milk.
  • In conducting the test, definite quantities of methylene blue are added to 10ml of milk and the sample is held at a uniform temperature of 37 deg C until the blue colour has disappeared.
  • The milk which remains blue the longest is considered to be of the best quality and a scale of grading different milk samples, on the basis of the time required to reduce a definite quantity of methylene blue has been worked out.

questions.text: When an individual is faced with problems, difficulties or failures, he employs certain ways or devices to achieve health, happiness or success, these are called defence mechanisms. Match the following defence mechanisms with their descriptions?
questions.solution:
• Rationalization: Instead of accepting failures and correcting himself, the individual tries to make excuses and justifies his behaviour.
  • Projection: Sometimes the individual blames others for his mistakes or failures.
  • Compensation: Many people make use of compensation to enhance their self esteem and prestige. The familiar example is that the student who is not good in his studies may distinguish himself in sports or dramatics, music or other activities.
  • Escape mechanisms: Examples are- students pretend illness and do not appear for examination, people who take alcohol or drugs trying to solve their problems.
  • Displacement: It is trying to escape from one situation and fixing blame on another situation. Example- an office clerk badly snubbed by his superior takes it out on his wife and children at home.
  • Regression: Some people resort to childhood practices as a mode of adjustment.

questions.text: Identify the programme given in the image below?
questions.solution:
• The given image is the logo for mid-day meal scheme.
  • It is now known as PM Poshan Scheme and also as National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education.
  • Some suggestions for preparation of nutritious and economical mid-day meals are as under:
    • Foodgrains must be stored in a place away from moisture, in tight containers to avoid infestation.
    • Use whole wheat or broken wheat (dalia) for preparing mid-day meals.
    • Rice should preferably be parboiled or unpolished.
    • Single dish meals using broken wheat or rice and incorporating some amount of pulse or soyabeans, a seasonal or green leafy vegetable, and some amount of vegetable oil should be preferred.
    • The cereal pulse ratio could range from 3:1 to 5:1.
    • Sprouted pulses should be incorporated in single dish meals.
    • Leafy vegetables should be thoroughly washed before cutting.
    • Wash the grains and soak in just sufficient amount of water required for cooking.
    • Rice water if left after cooking should be mixed with dal if these are cooked separately and should never be thrown away.
    • Cooking must be done with the lid on to avoid loss of nutrients.
    • Overcooking should be avoided.
    • Reheating of oil used for frying is harmful and should be avoided.
    • Leafy tops of carrots, radish, turnips, etc. should not be thrown but utilized in preparing mid-day meals.
    • Only iodized salt should be used for cooking mid-day meals.

questions.text: Farmers lung is due to the inhalation of mouldy hay or grain dust. The main cause of farmers lung is?
questions.solution:
• Micropolyspora faeni: It is the main cause of farmer's lung which occurs due to inhalation of hay mould or grain dust. Acute illness is characterised by general and respiratory symptoms and physical signs. Repeated attacks cause pulmonary fibrosis and inevitable pulmonary damage and cor pulmonale.
  • Thermoactinomyces sacchari: It is the main organism responsible for bagassosis caused by inhalation of sugarcane fibres or bagasse.symptoms consists of breathlessness, hempotysis, cough, and slight fever.
  • Candida albicans: It can cause candidiasis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the below image?
questions.solution:
• Given image is of ANTARA an injectable contraceptive which contain DMPA (depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate). The standard dose is intramuscular injection of 150mg every 3 months. It exerts contraceptive effect primarily by suppression of ovulation. It also has an indirect effect on endometrium and direct action on fallopian tube and on the production of cervical mucus, all of which play a role in reducing fertility.

questions.text: Match the following waste disposal method with the type of waste it is contraindicated for?
questions.solution:
• Incineration: Incineration is a high temperature dry oxidation process, that reduces organic and combustible waste to inorganic incombustible matter. Wastes type not to be incinerated are:
    • Pressurized gas containers.
    • Large amount of reactive chemical wastes.
    • Silver salts and photographic or radiographic wastes.
    • Halogenated plastics such as PVC.
    • Waste with high mercury or cadmium content such as broken thermometers, used batteries and lead-linen wooden panels.
    • Sealed ampoules or ampoules containing heavy metals.
  • Wet thermal treatment: Wet thermal treatment or steam disinfection is based on exposure of shredded infectious wastes to high temperature, high pressure steam, and is similar to the autoclave sterilization process. The process is inappropriate for the treatment of anatomical waste and animal carcasses and will not efficiently treat chemical and pharmaceutical waste.
  • Screw feed technology: It is the basis of a non-burn, dry thermal disinfection process in which waste is shredded and heated in a rotating auger. The waste is reduced by 80% in volume and by 30-35% in weight. This process is suitable for treating infectious waste and sharps, but it should not be used to process pathological, cytotoxic or radioactive waste.
  • Inertization: It involves mixing waste with cement and other substances before disposal, in order to minimize the risk of toxic substances contained in the wastes. Typical proportion of the mixture is 65% pharmaceutical waste, 15% lime, 15% cement and 5% water. This method is not applicable for infectious waste.

questions.text: In jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, atrial diastole is represented by which wave?
questions.solution:
Pointwise Summary

  1. a Wave Dynamics:
    • Reflects right atrial presystolic contraction.
    • Occurs after the electrocardiographic P wave and just before the first heart sound (S1).
    • Prominent in conditions with reduced right ventricular compliance and during AV dissociation (cannon a waves).
  2. x Descent:
    • Represents the fall in right atrial pressure following the a wave.
  3. c Wave:
    • Occurs as the tricuspid valve bulges into the right atrium during early ventricular systole, interrupting the x descent.
  4. v Wave:
    • Represents atrial filling or atrial diastole during ventricular systole.
    • The height of this wave depends on right atrial compliance and blood flow conditions.
  5. y Descent:
    • Follows the v wave, marking the rapid fall in right atrial pressure after the tricuspid valve opens.
    • Can be prolonged or blunted with right ventricular inflow obstructions, such as tricuspid stenosis or pericardial tamponade.
  6. Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) and Respiratory Variations:
    • Normal response includes a fall in venous pressure by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration.
    • Kussmaul's sign (rise or lack of fall in JVP with inspiration) indicates conditions like constrictive pericarditis.
  7. Abdominojugular Reflux Test:
    • Used to evaluate a rise in JVP with firm abdominal pressure, indicative of a volume-overloaded state or venous system issues.
    • A positive response is a sustained rise of more than 3 cm in the JVP.
  8. Clinical Implications:
    • Abdominojugular reflux is useful in predicting elevated pulmonary artery wedge pressures in heart failure cases.
    • It is important during the test that patients avoid breath-holding or Valsalva maneuvers to prevent confounding the results.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with an acute aortic dissection. All of the following drugs can be used alone for the management of this condition except?
questions.solution:
Pointwise Summary

  1. Initial Medical Management:
    • Patients suspected of having an aortic dissection should be admitted to the ICU for close hemodynamic monitoring.
    • Therapy aims at reducing cardiac contractility and systemic arterial pressure to lower shear stress.
  2. Pharmacological Treatment:
    • β-adrenergic blockers (e.g., propranolol, metoprolol, esmolol) are administered to achieve a heart rate of approximately 60 beats/min.
    • Sodium nitroprusside infusion is used to reduce systolic blood pressure to ≤120 mmHg.
    • Labetalol, which has both β- and α-blocking effects, is another option for parenteral use in acute situations.
    • If β-blockers are contraindicated, calcium channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem can be used intravenously.
    • Isolated use of a direct vasodilator such as hydralazine is contraindicated because these agents can increase hydraulic shear and may propagate the dissection.
  3. Surgical Intervention:
    • Emergent surgery is preferred for acute ascending aortic dissections (type A), involving excision of the intimal flap and placement of an interposition graft.
    • Surgical techniques also address any associated complications, such as aortic valve disruption.
  4. Endovascular Repair:
    • Thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) with a stent graft is indicated for complicated type B dissections.
    • Additional interventions might include fenestration of intimal flaps and stenting of branch vessels to restore organ perfusion.
  5. Management of Uncomplicated Cases:
    • Medical therapy is the primary treatment for stable type B dissections.
    • Long-term management includes antihypertensive therapy, primarily using β-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and calcium channel blockers.

choices.text: Acute hepatitis B with fulminant hepatic failure
Acute hepatitis E in previously healthy adults

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for starting antiviral therapy in hepatitis?
questions.solution:
1. Acute Hepatitis A, B, and E:
    • Most individuals with acute hepatitis A, B, and E recover spontaneously without the need for specific antiviral therapy.
  2. Acute Hepatitis B:
    • Among healthy adults, about 99% recover from clinically apparent acute hepatitis B without antiviral treatment.
    • For rare severe cases, antiviral therapy with nucleoside analogues (e.g., entecavir or tenofovir) has been used successfully.
    • Treatment should be considered for severe cases and continued until 3 months post-HBsAg seroconversion or 6 months post-HBeAg seroconversion.
  3. Acute Hepatitis C:
    • Typical recovery from acute hepatitis C is rare (~15-20%).
    • Factors increasing likelihood of recovery include jaundice, female gender, earlier age at infection, lower HCV RNA levels, HBV co-infection, absence of injection drug use, and presence of IL28B CC haplotype.
    • Progression to chronic hepatitis is common.
  4. Treatment Approaches for Acute Hepatitis C:
    • With the advent of highly effective oral direct-acting antiviral (DAA) therapy, early treatment is advised without waiting for possible spontaneous recovery.
    • Treatment typically involves a full course of 8- to 12-weeks using first-line drug combinations of polymerase inhibitors, protease inhibitors, and/or NS5A inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can improve mortality in patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
1. Use of Glucocorticoids:
    • Glucocorticoids may be used in severe alcoholic hepatitis without concurrent infection.
    • They are shown to improve short-term survival based on certain studies and meta-analyses.
    • Treatment with glucocorticoids is restricted to patients with a Discriminant Function (DF) value of >32.
  2. Discriminant Function (DF):
    • DF is calculated using the formula: serum total bilirubin plus the difference in the patient's prothrombin time from the upper limit of control (in seconds) multiplied by 4.6.
  3. Treatment Duration and Assessment:
    • If there is no improvement in total bilirubin after 7 days, glucocorticoid treatment is considered a failure and is discontinued.
    • If improvement is seen, treatment continues for a total of 28 days.
  4. Combination Therapy with N-acetylcysteine:
    • There is modest evidence that the combination of intravenous N-acetylcysteine and glucocorticoids may provide a survival benefit in severe cases if the DF is >32.
  5. Other Therapies:
    • Other treatments such as oral pentoxifylline, TNF-α inhibitors (infliximab or etanercept), anabolic steroids, propylthiouracil, antioxidants, colchicine, and penicillamine have not demonstrated clear benefits and are not recommended.
  6. Nutritional Therapies:
    • Various nutritional therapies have been explored, including parenteral and enteral feedings, but clear evidence of improved survival is lacking.
    • Evidence suggests that consuming >21.5 kcal/kg body weight per day may improve survival, so aiming for higher caloric intake is advised.
  7. Liver Transplantation:
    • In highly selected patients who have good social support and have failed other treatments for alcoholic hepatitis, early liver transplantation can be an effective option.

questions.text: All of the following drugs are used for the management of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) except:
questions.solution:
Drugs used for treatment of Rheumatoid arthritis.


Targeted Synthetic DMARDs: Tofacitinib

  1. Definition and Role of DMARDs:
    • Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drugs (DMARDs) are used to slow or prevent the structural progression of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
  2. Conventional DMARDs:
    • Include hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, methotrexate, and leflunomide.
    • These drugs generally exhibit a delayed onset of action, approximately 6-12 weeks.
  3. Methotrexate:
    • Considered the DMARD of choice for RA treatment since its approval in 1988.
    • Administered weekly either orally or subcutaneously, with folic acid as co-therapy to mitigate side effects.
    • Works by stimulating adenosine release, producing an anti-inflammatory effect.
  4. Leflunomide:
    • Inhibits pyrimidine synthesis.
    • Clinical efficacy similar to methotrexate and can be used as monotherapy or in combination with other DMARDs.
  5. Hydroxychloroquine:
    • Used generally in early, mild RA or as adjunct therapy.
    • Not considered a true DMARD as it does not delay radiographic progression.
    • Prescribed with a maximum dosage of 5 mg/kg of body weight to minimize retinal toxicity.
  6. Sulfasalazine:
    • Demonstrated in controlled trials to reduce radiographic progression of RA.
  7. Other Agents:
    • Minocycline, gold salts, penicillamine, azathioprine, and cyclosporine have been used with varying success.
    • These are less frequently used today due to inconsistent efficacy or unfavourable toxicity profiles.
  8. Biologic DMARDs:
    • Have revolutionized RA treatment over the past decade, targeting cytokines and cell-surface molecules.
    • Include TNF inhibitors (first approved), anakinra (an IL-1 receptor antagonist with modest benefits), abatacept, rituximab, and tocilizumab.
    • Anakinra is rarely used due to other more effective options being available.

questions.text: Shrinking lung syndrome is a pulmonary manifestation of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
1. Common Pulmonary Manifestation in SLE:
    • Pleuritis, with or without pleural effusion, is the most common pulmonary manifestation of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).
  2. Treatment for Mild and Severe Pleuritis:
    • Mild cases may respond to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
    • More severe cases require a brief course of glucocorticoid therapy.
  3. Pulmonary Infiltrates:
    • Occur as a manifestation of active SLE.
    • These infiltrates are challenging to distinguish from infections on imaging studies.
  4. Life-threatening Pulmonary Manifestations:
    • Include interstitial inflammation leading to fibrosis, which mimics the histologic pattern of usual diffuse interstitial pneumonitis.
    • Shrinking lung syndrome and intra-alveolar hemorrhage are also life-threatening manifestations.
    • These conditions typically require early aggressive immunosuppressive therapy and supportive care.
  5. Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension:
    • Occurs in a small proportion of SLE patients.
    • Should be managed similarly to idiopathic pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following is antiphospholipid antibody?

A patient exhibits sustained and patterned muscle contractions that result in twisting movements and abnormal postures. The condition worsens with voluntary actions and is sometimes accompanied by a tremor. What is the most likely diagnosis for this movement disorder?
The alien hand phenomenon is seen in which of the following forms of atypical parkinsonism?
questions.solution: Atypical Forms of Parkinsonism

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is found in patients with thymoma who have myasthenia gravis (MG) and neuromyotonia?
questions.solution:
1. Anti-AChR Antibodies
    • Prevalence: Detectable in about 85% of all myasthenic patients and about 50% of those with weakness confined to the ocular muscles.
    • Diagnostic Value: Virtually diagnostic of MG when present; however, a negative test does not exclude the disease.
    • Severity Correlation: The antibody level does not consistently correlate with the severity of MG across different patients.
  2. MuSK Antibodies
    • Prevalence: Found in approximately 40% of patients who are negative for AChR antibodies and have generalized MG.
    • Characteristics: Rarely present in AChR antibody-positive patients or those with ocular muscle-limited MG.
    • Functional Impact: These antibodies may interfere with the clustering of AChRs at the neuromuscular junctions (NMJs).
  3. LRP4 Antibodies
    • Prevalence: Detected in a small percentage of MG patients who do not have antibodies to either AChR or MuSK.
    • Role: LRP4 works in conjunction with agrin in the normal clustering of AChRs at NMJs.
  4. Agrin Antibodies
    • Prevalence: Found in rare cases of MG.
    • Function: Agrin is essential for the proper clustering of AChRs at NMJs.
  5. Anti-Striated Muscle Antibodies
    • Prevalence:Found in about 30% of myasthenic patients without thymoma, 24% of thymoma patients without myasthenia, and 70-80% of patients with both conditions.
    • Target:Directed against titin and other skeletal muscle components.
  6. Netrin-1 Receptor and Caspr2 Antibodies
    • Association: Often coexist and are associated with patients who have thymoma with MG and also display symptoms of neuromyotonia or Morvan's syndrome.

choices.text: Blood pressure-systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT included under the CURB-65 score criteria for assessing the severity of pneumonia?
questions.solution:
1. Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI) and CURB-65:
    • Tools like PSI and CURB-65 are used to assess the risk of severe illness and death in pneumonia patients and to guide decisions regarding hospitalization.
  2. PSI Details:
    • The PSI includes 20 variables such as age, coexisting illnesses, and abnormal physical and laboratory findings.
    • Patients are classified into five classes based on their score, with mortality rates ranging from 0.1% in Class 1 to 29.2% in Class 5.
    • PSI helps to reduce hospital admissions for patients in Class 1 and 2, while Class 3 patients may be admitted to an observation unit for further decisions.
  3. CURB-65 Criteria:
    • Consists of five variables: Confusion, Urea >7 mmol/L, Respiratory rate ≥30/min, Blood pressure (systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg), and Age ≥65 years.
    • Scoring:
      • Score 0: 30-day mortality rate of 1.5%, suitable for outpatient treatment.
      • Score 1 or 2: Generally requires hospitalization, unless the score is mainly due to age.
      • Score ≥3: High mortality rate of 22%, may necessitate ICU admission.
  4. Comparative Efficacy:
    • PSI is more effective than CURB-65 but is more complex to calculate.
  5. Hospitalization Criteria:
    • Necessary if the patient cannot maintain oral intake, has potential compliance issues due to mental condition or living situation, or if O2 saturation is below 92% on room air.
    • If none of these apply, clinical judgment alongside a prediction rule should determine the care setting.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for empirical therapy of enteric fever in adults?
questions.solution: Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is widely recommended as the empirical treatment for enteric fever in adults, especially in regions where multidrug-resistant (MDR) strains of Salmonella typhi are prevalent. It is effective against both MDR and fluoroquinolone-resistant strains, which have become increasingly common globally. Administered intravenously or intramuscularly, it ensures reliable bioavailability and is particularly useful in severe cases or when oral therapy is not feasible.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a cause of exudative ascites?
questions.solution:
Ascites, the accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, is typically classified as either exudative or transudative. Exudative ascites occurs due to conditions involving inflammation, malignancy, or infection, while transudative ascites is primarily caused by systemic conditions affecting fluid balance, such as cirrhosis or heart failure. The distinction is crucial for proper diagnosis and management.

  • A. Meigs' syndrome: This condition involves the triad of ovarian tumor (usually benign), ascites, and pleural effusion. The ascites in Meigs' syndrome is exudative due to the inflammatory response induced by the tumor, which leads to increased vascular permeability and fluid leakage into the peritoneum.
  • B. Hepatic vein thrombosis (Budd-Chiari syndrome): This condition results from obstruction of the hepatic veins, leading to hepatic congestion, increased intrahepatic pressure, and fluid leakage into the abdominal cavity. The ascites is exudative due to the underlying inflammatory process and impaired liver function.
  • C. Pancreatic ascites: This occurs as a complication of chronic pancreatitis or pancreatic duct rupture, where pancreatic enzymes leak into the peritoneum, causing inflammation. The ascitic fluid in pancreatic ascites is exudative because of the inflammatory response to the pancreatic enzymes.
  • D. Portal vein thrombosis: This condition involves the formation of a clot in the portal vein, leading to impaired blood flow to the liver. It does not typically cause inflammation or increased vascular permeability, which are necessary for the development of exudative ascites. Instead, it often leads to a more gradual increase in portal pressure and transudative ascites due to increased hydrostatic pressure in the portal venous system.

Key Takeaway: Exudative ascites is caused by conditions involving inflammation, malignancy, or injury to the peritoneal cavity, while transudative ascites is primarily a result of systemic conditions like portal hypertension. Portal vein thrombosis (Option D) is not a cause of exudative ascites, as it typically leads to transudative ascites due to increased portal pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard technique to assess Portal Hypertension?
questions.solution:
Portal hypertension is a key feature of various liver diseases, including cirrhosis, and its assessment is crucial for diagnosis and management. Understanding the gold standard method to measure portal hypertension aids clinicians in making accurate assessments and guiding therapy.

Correct Answer: B. Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) HVPG is the gold standard technique for assessing portal hypertension. It is calculated as the difference between wedged hepatic venous pressure (WHVP), which reflects sinusoidal pressure, and free hepatic venous pressure (FHVP), which represents systemic venous pressure.

HVPG = WHVP - FHVP

  • An HVPG >5 mmHg indicates portal hypertension, with clinically significant portal hypertension typically defined as >10 mmHg.

Option A: Hepatic vein wedge pressure (WHVP) While WHVP is used to measure sinusoidal pressure, it does not directly reflect portal pressure alone. It must be combined with FHVP to calculate the HVPG for an accurate assessment of portal hypertension.

Option C: Endoscopic detection of varices Endoscopy is used to visualize esophageal or gastric varices, a complication of portal hypertension. However, it cannot quantify portal pressure, especially in early or subclinical cases. Thus, it is not the gold standard.

Option D: Free hepatic venous pressure (FHVP) FHVP represents systemic venous pressure and is used as a baseline in the calculation of HVPG. On its own, it does not provide information about portal hypertension.

Key Takeaway Point: The hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) is the gold standard for assessing portal hypertension because it accurately represents the pressure in the hepatic sinusoids and portal vein

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common presentation in patients with somatostatinoma?
questions.solution:
Somatostatinomas cause excessive somatostatin release, leading to inhibition of bile secretion and subsequent bile stasis. This results in the formation of gallstones (cholelithiasis) (CHOICE A), which is a common presentation in patients with these tumors. Approximately 19% of patients present with gallstones, often accompanied by abdominal pain and jaundice.

  • Choice B. Diarrhea: Although somatostatinomas can cause diarrhea due to the inhibition of pancreatic enzyme secretion and malabsorption, it is less common compared to cholelithiasis. Diarrhea is often seen in association with other gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Choice C. Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia is not a primary feature of somatostatinomas. Instead, these tumors inhibit insulin secretion, leading to hyperglycemia or diabetes mellitus in some patients.
  • Choice D. Steatorrhea: Steatorrhea occurs due to decreased pancreatic enzyme secretion and bile stasis caused by somatostatin's inhibitory effects. However, it is less commonly reported compared to cholelithiasis.

Key Takeaway Point: Somatostatinomas most commonly present with abdominal pain, jaundice, and cholelithiasis (19%). These tumors frequently arise in the proximal pancreas or the pancreatoduodenal groove, with the ampulla and periampullary area being the most common site (60%). Understanding these hallmark features aids in early diagnosis and treatment.

choices.text: Arise more commonly with chronic pancreatitis than acute pancreatitis
Pseudocysts arising in chronic pancreatitis are more likely to resolve spontaneously
Operative correction is usually required when the pancreatico-enteric fistula opens into the colon
Internal drainage is preferred over external drainage

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the pseudocyst of the Pancreas
questions.solution:
Pancreatic pseudocysts are fluid collections surrounded by a wall of granulation tissue that often arise as a complication of both acute and chronic pancreatitis. While most pseudocysts resolve without intervention, certain features can dictate the management approach. This question assesses knowledge regarding the characteristics and management of pancreatic pseudocysts.

Choice A: Arise more commonly with chronic pancreatitis than acute pancreatitis

This statement is correct. Pancreatic pseudocysts are a common complication in chronic pancreatitis, occurring in 20% to 38% of cases. They are less common in acute pancreatitis, affecting up to 10% of patients.

Choice B: Pseudocysts arising in chronic pancreatitis are more likely to resolve spontaneously

This statement is incorrect. Pseudocysts associated with chronic pancreatitis, especially those that are large (>6 cm) or have been present for over 12 weeks, are less likely to resolve spontaneously. These cysts often require drainage or surgical intervention to prevent complications such as infection or rupture.

Choice C: Operative correction is usually required when the pancreatico-enteric fistula opens into the colon

This statement is correct. When a pancreatic pseudocyst erodes into the colon, it can create a pancreatic-enteric fistula. The most common site of communication is the transverse colon or splenic flexure, and operative intervention is typically required, especially if it leads to gastrointestinal bleeding or sepsis.

choice D: Internal drainage is preferred over external drainage

This statement is correct. Internal drainage, such as cystogastrostomy or cystojejunostomy, is preferred for pseudocysts as it provides a more stable and physiologically appropriate pathway for fluid drainage, reducing the risk of complications like pancreatic duct leakage seen with external drainage.

Key Take Away Point:

Internal drainage is usually preferred to external drainage to avoid the complication of a pancreaticocutaneous fistula

questions.text: Which of the following tumours do not lead to gynaecomastia?
questions.solution:
Choice A - Testicular tumors (e.g., Leydig cell and Sertoli cell tumors, choriocarcinomas) lead to gynaecomastia

Choice B - Adrenal tumours can cause gynaecomastia

Choice C - Lung carcinoma can cause gynaecomastia

Choice D - None of the options are unrelated to gynaecomastia

Key takeaway: Gynaecomastia can be caused due to cirrhosis, malnutrition, hypogonadism, renal disease, hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism, Klinefelter syndrome, various drugs

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate is stored at what temperature?
questions.solution:
Choice B- Cryoprecipitate is a supernatant precipitate of FFP and is rich in fbrinogen, factor VIII and factor XIII. It is stored at −30°C with a 2year shelf life. It is given in low fbrinogen states or factor VIII deficiency

Choice A - Packed cells are stored in a SAGM (saline-adenine-glucose-mannitol) solution to increase shelf life to 5 weeks at 2-6°C

Choice C - Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is rich in coagulation factors and is removed from fresh blood and stored at −40°C to −50°C with a 2year shelf life

Choice D - Platelets are stored on a special agitator at 20-24°C and have a shelf life of only 5 days

Key Takeaway: Cryoprecipitate is stored at −30°C with a 2year shelf life

questions.text: In SAG-M solution, G stands for?
questions.solution:
Choice A - Packed cells are stored in a SAGM (saline-adenine-glucose-mannitol) solution to increase shelf life to 5 weeks at 2-6°C

Choice B - G in SAG-M does not stand for glutamine

Choice C - G in SAG-M does not stand for glycine

Choice D - G in SAG-M does not stand for glutathione

Key Takeaway - Packed cells are stored in a SAGM (saline-adenine-glucose-mannitol) solution to increase shelf life to 5 weeks at 2-6°C

questions.text: In case of a physiologically unstable case of chest trauma with physical examination being inconclusive, what is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Choice A - Finger thoracostomy is a rapid bedside procedure performed in unstable patients suspected of having a tension pneumothorax or hemothorax when clinical findings are inconclusive. It allows for immediate decompression of the pleural space and is often used as a bridge to more definitive management, such as chest tube insertion. This procedure does not rely on imaging and is lifesaving in acute settings.

Choice B - Xray is not useful in such cases. Additionally, the supine position often used during X-rays in trauma settings may mask findings like pneumothorax.

Choice C - For CT scan, patient needs to be mobilized and is relatively time consuming

Choice D - Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is becoming the most common investigation. The technique uses sonographic assessment in the chest, looking for a cardiac tamponade or free blood and air in the hemithoraces, and assessment for blood in the abdominal cavity, in the paracolic gutters, subdiaphragmatic spaces and pelvis

Key Takeaway- In the physiologically grossly unstable patient, where physical examination is inconclusive and there is no time for radiological investigations, bilateral finger thoracostomy can be a diagnostic procedure as well as a therapeutic one, and the benefits of undertaking it often outweigh the risks. It is undertaken by making a 5-cm skin incision on the fifth rib just anterior to the mid-axillary line. The intercostal muscles are then separated just above the fifth rib and the pleural cavity entered. A finger is then inserted and a pleural sweep made to ensure the pleural cavity has been entered

questions.text: Which is the diagnostic modality of choice for duodenal injuries?
questions.solution:
Choice A - FAST is operator dependent, especially in obese patients or when bowel is full of gas. Hollow viscus and solid organ injuries are difficult to diagnose

Choice B - Laparoscopy can be considered for physiologically non-compromised patients

Choice C - DPL is rarely used in modern day practice and is of value in resource limited settings

Choice D - CT scan has become "gold standard" for intra-abdominal diagnosis of injury in stable patients

Key Takeaway - Like the pancreas, the duodenum lies retroperitoneally and so injuries are hidden, discovered late or at laparotomy performed for other reasons. CT is the diagnostic modality of choice. The only sign may be gas or a fluid collection in the periduodenal tissue, and leakage of oral contrast, administration of which may improve accuracy of diagnosis

Zone 2 is pelvic zone and should be explored only if haematomas are expanding or pulsatile or there is penetrating injury
Zone 3 is lateral zone and should be explored only if haematomas are expanding or pulsatile or there is penetrating injury

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true for zones of retroperitoneum?
questions.solution:
Choice A -Zone 1 is central haematomas and should always be explored, once proximal and distal vascular control has been obtained

Choice B- Zone 2 are lateral haematomas and should only be explored if haematomas are expanding or pulsatile or penetrating injury is present. These are usually renal in origin and can be managed non operatively

Choice C - Zone 3 are pelvic haematomas and should be explored only if haematomas are expanding or pulsatile or penetrating injury is present. They are difficult to control and whenever possible should not be opened. They are best controlled with compression or extra peritoneal packing and if bleeding is arterial then angioembolism

Choice D - A is the correct answer
