questions.text: Picture below is an end result of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
The picture shows elephantiasis, which is a severe, chronic condition caused by filariasis. Filariasis is a parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes, caused by filarial worms (such as Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori). The infection leads to the obstruction of lymphatic vessels, resulting in the accumulation of fluid and lymph, which causes the characteristic thickening of the skin and subcutaneous tissues-referred to as elephantiasis due to the extreme swelling that mimics the skin appearance of an elephant's hide.

  • CHOICE A. DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): DVT is caused by a blood clot in a deep vein, often in the legs. It does not cause the thickening or changes in the dermis as seen in elephantiasis.
  • CHOICE C. Malignant melanoma: Malignant melanoma is a form of skin cancer that originates from melanocytes. It does not cause the dermal thickening and swelling seen in elephantiasis.
  • CHOICE D. Chronic venous insufficiency: This condition involves poor venous return from the legs, leading to swelling and skin changes, but it does not cause the lymphatic obstruction or significant dermal thickening seen in filariasis.

Key Takeaway: Elephantiasis, characterized by extreme swelling and thickening of the skin, is a long-term consequence of filariasis, a parasitic infection that causes lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: What is the name of clinical test used to evaluate varicose veins?
questions.solution:
Varicose veins occur due to incompetent valves within the venous system, leading to blood pooling and dilation of veins, most commonly in the lower extremities. Various clinical tests can be used to assess the venous system, and one of the historical methods is Trendelenburg's test, which helps evaluate valve competency in the superficial, deep, and perforating venous systems.

CHOICE A: Gaiter's test
This test is not a recognized clinical test for varicose veins. It is likely confused with other terms or clinical signs.

CHOICE B: Trendelenburg's test
Trendelenburg's test is designed to assess venous reflux and valve incompetence in the veins. It involves two components:

  1. The patient lies supine with the leg elevated at a 45° angle to empty the veins. The great saphenous vein (GSV) is occluded manually or with a tourniquet.
  2. The patient then stands, and the superficial veins are observed. If blood fills suddenly after standing while the GSV is still occluded, this indicates incompetent valves in the perforator or deep veins. A gradual filling suggests no venous reflux, indicating normal valve function. This test has been largely replaced by more objective, noninvasive methods but remains a historical and educational tool.

CHOICE C: Allen's test
Allen's test is used to assess the patency of the radial and ulnar arteries by evaluating collateral circulation to the hand, not for varicose veins.

CHOICE D: Adson's test
Adson's test is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome by assessing the presence of subclavian artery compression, not varicose veins.

Key Takeaway: Trendelenburg's test is an important historical test used to assess venous reflux in patients with varicose veins. It helps determine whether there is valve incompetence in the superficial, deep, or perforating veins. Although less commonly used today due to more accurate noninvasive testing, it is still valuable in understanding venous pathology.

questions.text: Patients having gangrene as typical ABI of ...........
questions.solution:
The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) is an important tool used to assess the risk of peripheral vascular disease and cardiovascular events. The ABI is calculated by measuring the systolic blood pressure in both arms and both ankles, with the highest systolic blood pressure in the arm serving as the denominator. An ABI of <0.9 indicates the presence of peripheral vascular disease and increased risk for cardiovascular events, including myocardial infarction.

For patients with claudication, the ABI typically ranges from 0.5 to 0.7, while those with rest pain have an ABI in the 0.3 to 0.5 range. For gangrene, an ABI of <0.3 is observed. This low ABI reflects severe peripheral artery disease with significant ischemia.

However, the ABI test has limitations, especially in patients with noncompressible arteries, often due to calcification, which may result in an ABI of ≥1.40. This is common in diabetic patients or those with end-stage renal disease. In these cases, additional diagnostic tests like toe-brachial pressure, pulse volume recordings, transcutaneous oxygen measurements, or vascular imaging may be needed for accurate diagnosis.

Key Takeaway: An ABI <0.3 is associated with severe ischemia and is typically seen in patients with gangrene due to peripheral artery disease.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman develops preeclampsia at 30 weeks. Analysis of the placental bed shows incomplete spiral artery transformation. Which cell type is primarily responsible for this pathological change?
questions.solution:
A) Villous cytotrophoblasts

  • These cells contribute to the development of the chorionic villi and are involved in nutrient and gas exchange. They are not directly involved in spiral artery transformation.

B) Extravillous trophoblasts

  • Correct Answer. Extravillous trophoblasts invade the maternal spiral arteries during normal pregnancy, replacing the endothelial lining and converting them into low-resistance vessels. Incomplete invasion by these cells is a hallmark of preeclampsia.

C) Syncytiotrophoblasts

  • These cells form the outer layer of the placental villi and are primarily responsible for hormone secretion. They are not involved in vascular remodeling of spiral arteries.

D) Endothelial cells of maternal origin

  • These cells line the maternal spiral arteries, but their failure to undergo remodeling is due to inadequate invasion by extravillous trophoblasts rather than a primary defect in the endothelial cells themselves.

Topic: Pathophysiology of preeclampsia

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with pregestational diabetes presents for her 18-week ultrasound. The fetus has a congenital heart defect. Which of the following heart defects is most commonly seen in fetuses of women with poorly controlled pregestational diabetes?
questions.solution:
• A) Transposition of the great vessels
    Less likely: While transposition of the great vessels is a serious congenital defect, it is not the most common heart defect in infants of women with poorly controlled pregestational diabetes. There is an increased risk of this defect, but VSDs are more frequently seen.
  • B) Atrial septal defect (ASD)
    Less likely: ASDs are generally less common in the offspring of diabetic mothers when compared to other defects like VSD. The association between ASDs and maternal diabetes is weaker than with VSD.
  • C) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
    Most likely: VSDs are the most common congenital heart defects seen in fetuses of women with poorly controlled pregestational diabetes. Elevated blood glucose levels during early pregnancy can disrupt normal cardiac development, leading to defects like VSDs.
  • D) Coarctation of the aorta
    Less likely: Coarctation of the aorta is a rare defect that does occur more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers, but it is not the most common defect associated with maternal diabetes.

Topic: Congenital anomalies in pregestational diabetes

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac conditions has the highest risk of maternal mortality in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• A) Mitral valve prolapse:
    Mitral valve prolapse is generally well tolerated in pregnancy. Most cases are asymptomatic and do not carry a significant risk of maternal mortality unless associated with severe mitral regurgitation or arrhythmias.
  • B) Severe aortic stenosis:
    Severe aortic stenosis poses a moderate to high risk in pregnancy due to reduced cardiac output and inability to meet increased physiological demands. However, maternal mortality is lower than in Eisenmenger syndrome.
  • C) Eisenmenger syndrome:
    Eisenmenger syndrome is associated with a very high risk of maternal mortality (30-50%). Pregnancy exacerbates pulmonary hypertension, leading to right-to-left shunting, hypoxemia, and fatal complications like sudden cardiac death or thromboembolism.
  • D) Atrial septal defect:
    An atrial septal defect is usually well tolerated in pregnancy, even if it causes a left-to-right shunt. Complications are rare unless Eisenmenger syndrome has developed, which is a distinct scenario.

Topic: Cardiac disease in pregnancy

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with a mechanical heart valve is started on anticoagulation. Which is the recommended anticoagulant during the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Optionwise analysis:

  • Warfarin (A): Warfarin is contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects, including warfarin embryopathy (nasal hypoplasia, stippled epiphyses, and growth retardation) and central nervous system abnormalities.
  • Low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) (B): LMWH is the anticoagulant of choice during the first trimester because it does not cross the placenta, is safer for the fetus, and has a lower risk of bleeding complications compared to unfractionated heparin.
  • Unfractionated heparin (UFH) (C): UFH is an alternative to LMWH but is less preferred due to its shorter half-life, the need for more frequent dosing, and a higher risk of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).
  • Direct oral anticoagulants (D): These are contraindicated in pregnancy because of insufficient safety data and potential adverse fetal effects.

Topic: Anticoagulation in pregnancy

Reference: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) - Practice Bulletin No. 212: Pregnancy and Heart Disease (2019)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding and elevated beta-hCG levels following a recent miscarriage. Ultrasound reveals no visible gestational sac, and biopsy confirms the diagnosis of choriocarcinoma.
Which of the following is the most common site of metastasis in choriocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Choriocarcinoma, a type of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), often metastasizes to distant organs, with the lungs being the most common site of metastasis. Other common sites include the liver, vagina, and occasionally the brain. In this patient, the presence of multiple lung nodules is highly suggestive of choriocarcinoma with pulmonary metastasis, which is the most frequent site of spread in this disease.

  • Lungs: Pulmonary involvement occurs in 50-80% of cases of metastatic choriocarcinoma. Lung metastasis can lead to symptoms such as cough, hemoptysis, or dyspnea (difficulty breathing) and may present as multiple nodules on imaging (as seen in this case).
  • Liver: The liver is the second most common site of metastasis (after the lungs), seen in 30-40% of cases. However, lung metastasis remains more prevalent.
  • Brain: Brain metastases are less common, occurring in about 10-15% of cases, but are associated with poorer prognosis when present.
  • Kidneys: Renal metastasis is rare and not a frequent site of choriocarcinoma spread.

Topic: Metastatic choricarcinoma

Reference: FIGO Guidelines on Gestational Trophoblastic Disease (GTD) 2015

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
A DEXA scan is the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis by measuring bone mineral density (BMD) and calculating T-scores.

Optionwise analysis:

A) Serum calcium levels
Explanation:
Serum calcium levels are not a reliable diagnostic tool for osteoporosis. Although calcium is important for bone health, its serum concentration may not reflect bone density or the presence of osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is characterized by low bone mass and structural deterioration of bone tissue, which cannot be assessed by serum calcium alone.

B) Bone biopsy
Explanation:
A bone biopsy is a more invasive procedure and is generally not used in the diagnosis of osteoporosis. It may be helpful in diagnosing other bone disorders or conditions that mimic osteoporosis, but it is not the standard method for diagnosing osteoporosis.

C) Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan
Explanation:
The DEXA scan is the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis. It measures bone mineral density (BMD), and a T-score of -2.5 or lower indicates osteoporosis. DEXA is non-invasive, quick, and has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting low bone density and assessing fracture risk.

D) X-ray of the spine
Explanation:
While X-rays can reveal fractures and significant bone loss, they are not sensitive enough for early diagnosis of osteoporosis. X-rays typically show changes only after significant bone loss has occurred, so they are not useful for detecting osteoporosis in its early stages.

Topic: Postmenopausal osteoporosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid (VIA) as part of cervical cancer screening. The result shows a positive acetowhite area. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A positive VIA result indicates the presence of acetowhite areas on the cervix, suggesting possible dysplasia or cervical cancer. The next step in management is colposcopy to further evaluate and biopsy any abnormal areas.

Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid (VIA) is a screening tool used to detect cervical lesions, where areas of acetowhite changes indicate possible dysplasia or precancerous lesions. A positive VIA result (acetowhite areas) warrants further evaluation to rule out cervical cancer or severe dysplasia. The next step in management is colposcopy, which allows for closer examination of the cervix and the ability to perform biopsy on abnormal areas to confirm the diagnosis.

  • Colposcopy (Option B) is the appropriate next step as it provides detailed visualization and allows biopsy of suspicious lesions for histopathological examination.
  • Repeat VIA in 6 months (Option A) is not recommended as VIA cannot definitively diagnose the severity of lesions; a more invasive diagnostic step (colposcopy) is required for further evaluation.
  • HPV testing (Option C) may be useful in women with abnormal cytology but is not the first-line approach following a positive VIA result. Colposcopy is preferred for direct evaluation.
  • Cryotherapy (Option D) is typically used for treating low-grade cervical lesions after colposcopy confirms the presence of such lesions. It is not the first step in management.

Topic: VIA

Reference: Screening for cervical cancer: WHO guidelines

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with a monochorionic, monoamniotic twin pregnancy at 12 weeks. What is the most significant risk associated with this type of twin pregnancy?
questions.solution:
In a monochorionic, monoamniotic twin pregnancy, the most significant risk is umbilical cord entanglement (OPTION B), which can lead to fetal distress and other complications. TTTS and preterm birth are also risks but less common in this specific type of twin pregnancy.

Other Options:

  • A) Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS): TTTS is a complication that affects monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) pregnancies, where blood flow between the twins is uneven due to abnormal placental anastomoses.
  • C) Preterm birth: Preterm birth is a common complication in multiple pregnancies, including MCMA twins, but umbilical cord entanglement remains the most significant and immediate risk.
  • D) Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR): IUGR is a potential risk in any twin pregnancy, but it is not as significant as cord entanglement in MCMA pregnancies.

Topic: Monoamniotic twin gestation

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery, Chapter 12 Multiple Pregnancy, Page no. 175-176

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl with CAIS seeks genetic counseling. She has a 46, XY karyotype and typical female external genitalia. If she has children in the future, what is the risk of passing the mutation to her offspring?
questions.solution:
Since CAIS is X-linked recessive, affected women (with one mutated X chromosome) are carriers. If they have children with a male partner, there is a 50% chance that each daughter will inherit the mutated X chromosome and become a carrier, and a 50% chance that each son will inherit the Y chromosome from the father and not be affected by the condition.

Topic: Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome

choices.text: Injury at the level of the ureterovesical junction

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is undergoing Total Laparoscopic Hysterectomy (TLH) for symptomatic uterine fibroids. During the procedure, the surgeon is carefully dissecting the uterine arteries. The patient develops a sudden increase in flank pain and difficulty voiding urine postoperatively. Imaging shows mild hydronephrosis on the left side. Based on the surgical site and symptoms, what is the most likely cause of the injury?
questions.solution:
A) Injury to the pelvic brim:
Injuries to the pelvic brim are uncommon during TLH because the pelvic brim is not typically in direct proximity to the uterus or ureter.

Injury at this location is more commonly seen in open abdominal surgeries where extensive dissection is required at the pelvic inlet. This option is less likely in the context of TLH and the symptoms described.

B) Injury to the uterine artery:
The ureter runs in close proximity to the uterine artery, particularly as it crosses near the cervix.

In Total Laparoscopic Hysterectomy (TLH), injury to the ureter is most commonly associated with dissection of the uterine arteries. The increased flank pain and hydronephrosis postoperatively, coupled with the timing during uterine artery dissection, strongly suggest an injury to the ureter in this region.

The vascular and anatomical proximity of the uterine artery to the ureter makes it the most common site of injury during TLH

C) Injury at the level of the ureterovesical junction
Injury at the level of the ureterovesical junction is more likely to occur during procedures involving the bladder or during a cesarean section, where direct manipulation of the bladder and its junctions can occur.

This is not a typical complication seen in TLH, especially if the surgery is not performed near the bladder or uterine cervix.

D) Injury near the ovarian fossa:
Injuries near the ovarian fossa may occur when manipulating the ovaries or fallopian tubes during TLH, but these injuries typically do not involve the ureter.

This site is further removed from the common pathway of the ureter and is less likely to result in symptoms of hydronephrosis.

Topic: Total Laparoscopic hysterectomy

Reference: ACOG: Management of Complications in Minimally Invasive Gynecologic Surgery, 2021

choices.text: Apply local cold compress and observe
Perform manual reduction of the tear with perineal massage
Perform a thorough surgical repair of the third-degree perineal tear under local anesthesia
Administer IV antibiotics and analgesia alone

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman, G1P1, presents in labor at 39 weeks gestation. She has had a vaginal delivery of a 3.5 kg infant after 8 hours of active labor. The delivery was uncomplicated, and the baby was delivered spontaneously. On examination, you notice significant perineal bleeding and swelling at the perineal site. Upon inspection, you suspect a third-degree tear involving the anal sphincter. The patient is stable, and the bleeding is controlled, but she is in significant pain.
What is the next step in the management of this patient's perineal tear?
questions.solution:
In this case, the woman has sustained a third-degree perineal tear, which involves the anal sphincter muscles. The appropriate management involves surgical repair to restore the anatomy and function of the anal sphincter. This repair should be performed under local anesthesia or regional block. Early repair is essential to minimize complications such as fecal incontinence.

  • Option A (Cold compress and observe): While cold compresses may provide initial comfort, observation alone is not sufficient for a third-degree tear, as it can lead to long-term functional issues.
  • Option B (Manual reduction and massage): This is not an appropriate intervention for a third-degree tear. Manual reduction is not indicated in this scenario.
  • Option D (IV antibiotics and analgesia): While antibiotics and analgesia are important components of postpartum care, they are not the primary treatment for a third-degree perineal tear. Immediate surgical repair is required.

Topic: Perineal tears

Reference: ACOG. Practice Bulletin No. 165. Obstetric Care Consensus: Obstetric Anal Sphincter Injury

questions.text: The upper segment to lower segment ratio in a child is equal at which age?
questions.solution: • The lower segment grows rapidly after birth as compared to upper segment giving rise to the gradual reduction in the upper segment/lower segment ratio with the progression of age.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a history of multiple warts on her genital region. The patient reports that she has been sexually active with multiple partners and has had unprotected intercourse. She is diagnosed with genital warts and is referred to a specialist for further management. The virus responsible for her condition is known for its high oncogenic potential, particularly associated with cervical cancer. Which of the following viruses is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

  • A) Herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 2:* This is incorrect. While HSV type 2 causes genital lesions, it is not the primary cause of genital warts. HSV causes painful, fluid-filled blisters, while HPV causes wart-like growths.
  • B) Human papillomavirus (HPV) type 16:* This is the correct answer. HPV types 16 and 18 are known for their high oncogenic potential, particularly in the development of cervical cancer. HPV infection can lead to genital warts, and type 16 is a high-risk strain associated with malignancy.
  • C) *Varicella-zoster virus (VZV):** This is incorrect. VZV causes chickenpox and shingles, not genital warts. It can cause painful rashes but is unrelated to the formation of warts.
  • D) *Epstein-Barr virus (EBV):** This is incorrect. EBV causes infectious mononucleosis and is associated with other conditions like Burkitt's lymphoma, but it is not responsible for genital warts.

Key Takeaways:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) is the main cause of genital warts, with types 6 and 11 being low-risk, and types 16 and 18 being high-risk and associated with cervical cancer.
  • HPV transmission occurs primarily through sexual contact.
  • HPV 16 is one of the most oncogenic strains, linked to an increased risk of cervical and other genital cancers.
  • Vaccination against HPV (including types 16 and 18) is an important preventive measure for reducing the risk of cervical and other cancers

Reference: Mim's Medical Microbiology, PP- e9

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2021). Human Papillomavirus (HPV) and Cancer. CDC Website
  • World Health Organization (WHO). (2017). HPV Vaccination and Cancer Prevention. WHO Website

choices.text: Transmission occurs only through ingestion of contaminated food.
The infection produces alpha-toxin, which is detected in the Nagler's test.
It is primarily transmitted via inhalation of spores.
It can only cause infection in clean wounds with no previous trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of gas gangrene and food poisoning caused by Clostridium perfringens?
questions.solution:
• A) Transmission occurs only through ingestion of contaminated food: This statement is incorrect. While food poisoning is caused by ingestion of contaminated food, Clostridium perfringens can also cause gas gangrene in dirty ischemic wounds (not just through food ingestion). The bacterium is widely found in soil and the normal flora of humans and animals.
  • B) The infection produces alpha-toxin, which is detected in the Nagler's test: This is the correct answer. Clostridium perfringens produces alpha-toxin (lecithinase), which is identified using the Nagler's test. The alpha-toxin is crucial in the pathogenesis of both gas gangrene and food poisoning.
  • C) It is primarily transmitted via inhalation of spores: This is incorrect. Clostridium perfringens is primarily transmitted through contact with contaminated wounds or ingestion of contaminated food. Inhalation is not a typical transmission route for this organism.
  • D) It can only cause infection in clean wounds with no previous trauma: This is incorrect. Clostridium perfringens is more likely to infect dirty, ischemic wounds with compromised blood supply, where it can multiply in anaerobic conditions and produce toxins that lead to tissue necrosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Clostridium perfringens is an anaerobic, spore-forming Gram-positive rod that can cause gas gangrene and food poisoning.
  • The primary diagnostic feature of perfringens infection is the detection of alpha-toxin, which can be identified using the Nagler's test.
  • Gas gangrene is associated with infection of dirty, ischemic wounds, where the bacterium produces toxins and enzymes that destroy tissues and impair blood supply.
  • Treatment of gas gangrene requires rapid wound debridement, and antibiotics like penicillin and clindamycin are commonly used. Food poisoning usually resolves without specific treatment.

Table: Key Features of Clostridium perfringens

Reference: Mim's Medical Microbiology, PP- e23

  • National Institute of Health (NIH). (2019). Clostridium perfringens NIH Website
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2021). Clostridium perfringens food poisoning. CDC Website

choices.text: Transmitted via blood transfusion, characterized by fever, vomiting, and jaundice in infants
Transmitted vertically from mother to child, with clinical features including prematurity, low birth weight, anaemia, and hepatosplenomegaly
Transmitted orally, with symptoms including diarrhea, vomiting, and rash in neonates
Transmitted via Reduviid bug bite, with typical features such as skin ulceration, swollen lymph nodes, and a characteristic heart murmur in infants

questions.text: What is the primary method of transmission for congenital Chagas disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, and what are the key clinical features associated with this infection in infants?
questions.solution:
• A) Transmitted via blood transfusion, characterized by fever, vomiting, and jaundice in infants:
    While Trypanosoma cruzi can be transmitted via blood transfusion, this answer does not correctly describe the primary clinical presentation of congenital Chagas disease. Congenital infections are usually asymptomatic or show clinical features like prematurity, low birth weight, and hepatosplenomegaly, not the symptoms listed in option A.
  • B) Transmitted vertically from mother to child, with clinical features including prematurity, low birth weight, anaemia, and hepatosplenomegaly:
    Correct Answer. Congenital T. cruzi infection occurs vertically from mother to infant, often asymptomatically. When symptomatic, common features include prematurity, low birth weight, anaemia, thrombocytopenia, meningoencephalitis, and hepatosplenomegaly.
  • C) Transmitted orally, with symptoms including diarrhea, vomiting, and rash in neonates:
    Incorrect. Although T. cruzi can be transmitted orally, this mode is not the most common for congenital transmission. Additionally, diarrhea, vomiting, and rash are not typical symptoms of congenital Chagas disease. The clinical features described in this option are more characteristic of other infections.
  • D) Transmitted via Reduviid bug bite, with typical features such as skin ulceration, swollen lymph nodes, and a characteristic heart murmur in infants:
    Incorrect. Transmission via the Reduviid bug (vectorial transmission) is common for Chagas disease, but this is not the primary mode for congenital Chagas disease. Also, heart murmur and skin ulceration are more associated with adult Chagas disease, not congenital infection.

Key Points to Remember:

  • Congenital Chagas disease is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi and transmitted vertically from mother to infant.
  • Symptoms in newborns include prematurity, low birth weight, anaemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and meningoencephalitis.
  • Early treatment with benznidazole or nifurtimox is highly effective for infants.
  • Prevention includes serological screening of females born in endemic areas and screening infants for infection post-birth.
  • Vertical transmission accounts for about 20% of new infections due to improvements in vector control.

Reference:

  • World Health Organization (WHO). (2023). Chagas Disease: Epidemiology and Control. WHO Website.
  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2022). Chagas Disease - Congenital Infection. CDC Website.

choices.text: Production of exotoxins that inhibit the immune response
Enhanced ability to evade phagocytosis due to the thick polysaccharide capsule
Increased resistance to antibiotics due to mutations in the β-lactamase gene
Production of siderophores that capture iron from the host for growth

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient with cystic fibrosis presents with chronic respiratory symptoms, including a persistent productive cough, difficulty breathing, and recurrent exacerbations. Sputum cultures reveal Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a mucoid form. This mucoid transformation is associated with an enhanced ability to form biofilms and is highly resistant to antimicrobial therapy. Which of the following best explains the pathogenic mechanism of mucoid Pseudomonas aeruginosa in cystic fibrosis patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation of All 4 Options:

  • A) Production of exotoxins that inhibit the immune response: Pseudomonas aeruginosa produces exotoxins like exotoxin A, which can inhibit the immune response, but this is not the primary mechanism by which mucoid P. aeruginosa in cystic fibrosis evades immune defenses. The key mechanism in the mucoid form is the production of a thick biofilm, which is difficult for the immune system to clear.
  • B) Enhanced ability to evade phagocytosis due to the thick polysaccharide capsule: Correct. The mucoid form of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in cystic fibrosis patients produces an abundant polysaccharide capsule (alginate), which forms a biofilm. This biofilm protects the bacteria from both phagocytosis and antimicrobial agents, making it harder for the immune system to eliminate the infection.
  • C) Increased resistance to antibiotics due to mutations in the β-lactamase gene: Pseudomonas aeruginosa can develop antibiotic resistance through the production of β-lactamase, but mucoid transformation is primarily related to biofilm formation and immune evasion, not just β-lactamase production.
  • D) Production of siderophores that capture iron from the host for growth: Siderophores are produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa to capture iron from the host for bacterial growth, but this is not the central mechanism involved in the mucoid transformation. The mucoid form is more closely linked to biofilm formation and immune evasion than iron acquisition.

Key Takeaways:

  • The mucoid form of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in cystic fibrosis involves the production of a thick polysaccharide capsule (alginate), which forms a biofilm. This biofilm allows the bacteria to evade both phagocytosis and antimicrobial therapy.
  • Mucoid transformation is a key factor in the chronic and persistent nature of Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections in cystic fibrosis patients.
  • While β-lactamase production and siderophores play roles in resistance, the biofilm formation is the primary mechanism of immune evasion.

Reference:

  • Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. (2023). Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Biofilm Formation in Cystic Fibrosis. CFF Website.
  • American Society for Microbiology. (2022). Mechanisms of Biofilm Formation and Resistance in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. ASM Website.

questions.text: A 39 year old patient with history of myocardial infarction was on aspirin since 3 years and now he presented to medicine outpatient department with complaints of having presence of occult blood in his stool. Inhibition of which of the following by aspirin would best explain this adverse event?
questions.solution:
• Aspirin, even in small doses, irreversibly inhibits TXA2 synthesis by platelets.
  • Thus, it interferes with platelet aggregation and bleeding time is prolonged to nearly twice the normal value.
  • Long-term intake of large dose decreases synthesis of clotting factors in liver and predisposes to bleeding. This can be prevented by prophylactic vit K therapy.
  • Aspirin particle coming in contact with gastric mucosa promotes local back diffusion of acid.
  • This causes focal necrosis of mucosal cells and capillaries → acute ulcers, erosive gastritis, congestion and microscopic haemorrhages. The occult blood loss in stools is increased by even a single tablet of aspirin.

Aspirin side effects:

(a) Side effects that occur at analgesic dose (0.5-2.0 g/day)

  • Nausea,
  • Vomiting,
  • Epigastric distress,
  • Increased occult blood loss in stools.
  • The most important adverse effect of aspirin is gastric mucosal damage and peptic ulceration.

(b) Hypersensitivity and idiosyncrasy

  • Reactions include rashes,
  • Fixed drug eruption,
  • Urticaria,
  • Rhinorrhoea,
  • Angioedema,
  • Asthma and anaphylactoid reaction.

(c) Antiinflammatory doses (3-5 g/day)

  • Produce the syndrome called 'salicylism'
  • Dizziness,
  • Tinnitus,
  • Vertigo,
  • Reversible impairment of hearing and vision,
  • Excitement,
  • Hyperventilation and electrolyte imbalance.

(d) Acute salicylate poisoning

Aspirin side effects:

  • Mnemonic : [ASPIRIN]
  • Allergic like reactions (urticaria)
  • Susceptibility to bleeding
  • Peptic ulcer
  • Idiosyncratic reactions
  • Reye's syndrome
  • RInging in ears (Tinnitus)
  • Nephropathy

Key takeaway

Aspirin, even in small doses, irreversibly inhibits TXA2 synthesis by platelets. Thus, it interferes with platelet aggregation and bleeding time is prolonged to nearly twice the normal value.

questions.text: Which of the following agent is called as "Soft steroid" and used in bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
• Ciclesonide is an inhaled corticosteroid which is metabolized by enzymes in the lungs. Thus, it has least risk of toxicity from systemic absorption when given inhalationally. It is known as soft steroid.
  • Ciclesonide This ICS utilizes a novel approach to improve topical: systemic activity ratio.
  • It is a prodrug that is cleaved by esterases in the bronchial epithelium to release the active moiety.
  • Though it is absorbed from the lungs, oral bioavailability is <1%. In the circulation it is extensively bound to plasma proteins, further minimizing exposure of tissue cells to the free and active drug.
  • Inhaled steroids include beclomethasone, budesonide, mometasone, fluticasone, flunisolide and triamcinolone.
  • These have very little oral absorption and thus little systemic activity after inhalation (>90% reaches GIT after inhalational route, only 4-5% is retained in lungs).
  • Hoarseness of voice and oropharyngeal candidiasis are very common adverse effects.
  • Candidiasis can be prevented by gargling after each dose and topical nystatin (can be used for treatment also). Systemic corticosteroids should be avoided in pregnancy but inhaled steroids are safe.

Key takeaway

  • Ciclesonide is an inhaled corticosteroid which is metabolized by enzymes in the lungs. Thus, it has least risk of toxicity from systemic absorption when given inhalationally. It is known as soft steroid.

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient came to surgical outpatient department with complaints of epigastric pain while eating food was put on antacid treatment. Later he presented with loose stools as side effect. Which of the following drug is responsible for above mentioned adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• Misoprostol (methyl-PGE1 ester) is a longer acting synthetic PGE1 derivative which inhibits acid output.
  • Ulcer healing rates comparable to cimetidine have been obtained in 4-8 weeks, but misoprostol is poorer in relieving ulcer pain.
  • Some patients may even complain of increased pain during the first week of therapy.
  • Major problems in the use of misoprostol are-diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, uterine bleeding, abortion, and need for multiple daily doses. Patient acceptability is poor.
  • The primary indication of misoprostol is the prevention and treatment of NSAID associated gastrointestinal injury and blood loss.

Key takeaway

  • Major problems in the use of misoprostol are-diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, uterine bleeding, abortion, and need for multiple daily doses. Hence, patient acceptability is poor.

questions.text: A 56 year old hypotensive male patient was taken to surgical ICU for emergency operative procedure. His anesthetist has used a suitable anesthetic agent for him looking at his vitals. Later during recovery phase he was seen shouting and he also had hallucinations. Which of the following anaesthetic drug was used in this patient during operative procedure?
questions.solution:
Ketamine

  • This unique anaesthetic is pharmacologically related to the hallucinogen phencyclidine.
  • It induces the so called 'dissociative anaesthesia' characterized by profound analgesia, immobility, amnesia with only light sleep.
  • The patient appears to be conscious, i.e. opens his eyes, makes swallowing movements and his muscles are rigid, but he is unable to process sensory stimuli and does not react to them.
  • Thus, the patient appears to be dissociated from his body and surroundings.
  • The primary site of action of ketamine is in the cortex and subcortical areas, but not in the reticular activating system, which is the site of action of barbiturates.
  • Ketamine acts mainly by inhibiting the NMDA type of excitatory amino acid receptors in the brain, and not by interacting with GABAA receptor.

Key Takeaway

  • Ketamine induces so called 'dissociative anaesthesia' characterized by profound analgesia, immobility, amnesia with only light sleep. The patient appears to be dissociated from his body and surroundings.

questions.text: A 42 year old man recently diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder had started a treatment with sertraline, but the drug caused some sexual dysfunction, and the psychiatrist decided to switch to a short course of alprazolam. Which of the following molecular actions on neuronal membranes most likely mediated the therapeutic effect of alprazolam in the patient's disorder?
questions.solution:
• Benzodiazepines bind to receptors located at the interface between α and γ subunits of the GABAA receptor−chloride ion channel macromolecular complex.
  • The binding increases the afinity of the GABAA receptor for GABA, which in turn causes an increased frequency of chloride channel opening.
  • This in turn will increase the negative charges inside the cell, causing hyperpolarization of the cell membrane.
  • Benzodiazepines act preferentially on midbrain ascending reticular formation (which maintains wakefulness) and on limbic system (thought and mental functions).
  • BZDs act by enhancing presynaptic/postsynaptic inhibition through a specific BZD receptor which is an integral part of the GABAA receptor-Cl¯ channel complex
  • Only the α and β subunits are required for GABA action, and most likely the binding site for GABA is located on the β subunit, while the α/γ subunit interface carrys the BZD binding site.
  • The modulatory BZD receptor increases the frequency of Cl¯ channel opening induced by submaximal concentrations of GABA.
  • The BZDs also enhance GABA binding to GABAA receptor.
  • It is noteworthy that the BZDs do not themselves increase Cl¯ conductance; have only GABA facilitatory but no GABA mimetic action.

Option A, C & D: Benzodiazepines do not affect these currents. Moreover,

all of these actions would cause depolarization, not hyperpolarization, of cell membranes

Key takeaway

  • BZDs act by enhancing presynaptic/postsynaptic inhibition through a specific BZD receptor which is an integral part of the GABAA receptor-Cl¯ channel complex.

questions.text: Which of the following atypical antipsychotic agent causes maximum increase in prolactin levels as adverse reaction when given to a patient?
questions.solution:
• Risperidone
    • Its antipsychotic activity has been ascribed to a Combination of D2 + 5-HT2 receptor blockade.
    • In addition, it has high affinity for α1, α2 and H1 receptors: blockade of these may contribute to efficacy as well as side effects like postural hypotension.
    • Risperidone is more potent D2 blocker than clozapine; extrapyramidal side effects are less only at low doses (<6 mg/day).
    • Prolactin levels rise disproportionately during risperidone therapy, but it is less epileptogenic than clozapine, though frequently causes agitation.

Key takeaway

  • Prolactin levels rise disproportionately during risperidone therapy

questions.text: A 34 year old male patient brought to medicine outpatient department with complaints of occult blood in his stools and hematuria. Earlier, the patient was started with warfarin therapy for recurrent deep vein thrombosis. On examination his blood pressure was 90/60 mm Hg & heart rate 110 bpm. Which of the following drug should be administered intravenously to the patient for warfarin overdose?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms of the patient strongly suggest a hemorrhagic complication of warfarin therapy.
  • The standard treatment of warfarin overdose would be vitamin K, but the patient is hypotensive, suggesting that bleeding is life- threatening.
  • In this case, the act ion of vitamin K is too slow to be useful (onset is delayed for 6 hours and is complete by 24 hours).
  • Fresh frozen plasma (which contains prothrombin and factors VII, IX, and X) or activated clotting factors should be administered in case of severe acute bleeding due to anticoagulant therapy.
  • Adverse effects of warfarin
    • Bleeding as a result of extension of the desired pharmacological action is the most important problem causing ecchymosis, epistaxis, hematuria, bleeding in the g.i.t.
    • Intracranial or other internal haemorrhages may even be fatal.
    • Bleeding is more likely if therapy is not properly monitored, or when the
    • International normalized ratio (INR) exceeds 4, or interacting drugs/contraindications are present.
  • Treatment
    • Withhold the anticoagulant.
    • Give fresh blood transfusion; this supplies readymade clotting factors and replenishes lost blood. Alternatively fresh frozen plasma may be used as a source of clotting factors.
    • Give vit K1 which is the specific antidote, but it takes 6-24 hours for
    • the clotting factors to be resynthesized and released in the blood after vit K administration.

Key Takeaway

  • Fresh frozen plasma (which contains prothrombin and factors VII, IX, and X) or activated clotting factors should be administered in case of severe acute bleeding due to anticoagulant therapy

questions.text: A 56 year old female patient with history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus brought to medicine department with worsening heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Which of the following anti diabetic agent is most suitable for her established heart failure with reduced ejection fraction?
questions.solution:
• Liraglutide
    • The liraglutide peptide is a long-acting, DPP-4-resistant form of GLP-1, It has extended t1/2 that permits once-daily administration;
    • The pharmacodynamic profile of liraglutide mimics GLP-1 and exenatide.
    • In clinical trials, liraglutide caused both improvement in glycemic control and weight loss.
    • In a recent report, liraglutide reduced the risk of cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, or nonfatal stroke in patients with type 2 diabetes and established cardiovascular disease.
  • Key Takeaway
    • Liraglutide is associated with reduced the risk of cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, or nonfatal stroke in patients with type 2 diabetes and established cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: A dead body is brought in for autopsy. The cause of death is reported to be pontine hemorrhage. Which postmortem change is delayed in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Pontine hemorrhage can lead to delayed algor mortis (postmortem cooling).

Normally, algor mortis begins within 1-2 hours after death, when the body starts to cool down and eventually reaches the ambient temperature. Factors influencing the rate of cooling include ambient temperature, body size, clothing, and the presence of insulation (e.g., blankets). However, In certain conditions, algor mortis may be delayed due to severe disturbances in body temperature regulation before death.(for example: Pontine hemorrhage, heatstroke, septicemia, thyrotoxicosis)

Pontine Hemorrhage is a type of stroke that affects the pons region of the brain, which plays a crucial role in regulating vital functions, including body temperature. In the event of a pontine hemorrhage, the body's ability to regulate temperature can be severely compromised. As a result, the body's temperature remains raised after death, a condition termed postmortem caloricity, thus delaying algor mortis.

Postmortem caloricity can be seen:

  • When the regulation of body temperature has been severely disturbed before death as in sunstroke, pontine haemorrhage.
  • Increased heat production in muscles due to convulsions as in tetanus and strychnine poisoning.
  • When there has been increased bacterial activity as in septicemia.

Rigor Mortis: This refers to the stiffening of muscles after death, which generally begins within 2-6 hours and lasts up to 72 hours. It is not affected by pontine hemorrhage.

Livor Mortis: This is the pooling of blood in the dependent portions of the body, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin. It typically starts within 20 minutes to 3 hours after death and becomes fixed after 6-12 hours, unaffected by pontine hemorrhage.

questions.text: While recording evidence in the court of law, the lawyer who had called the witness conducts an examination on the witness. He does this to clarify certain doubts and details raised in the cross-examination. What is this procedure called?
questions.solution:
The above procedure is called the re-direct examination.

Re-direct examination is the procedure done by the lawyer who summoned the witness to correct any mistake or clarify or add any details to the statements of the witness made during the cross-examination.

The witness is not allowed to provide any new matter at this stage. The opponent's lawyer will be allowed to do a re-cross examination (option D) on any new point raised in the re-direct examination. Leading questions are not allowed in re-direct examination.

Sequence of Examination

Examination-in-chief/direct examination (options A and B) by the party that summoned the witness : To elicit the facts of the case from the witness. Leading questions are not allowed.

Cross-examination by the defense lawyer : To elicit facts favorable to their case and test the reliability of the witness. Leading questions are allowed.

Re-examination by the party that summoned the witness : To resolve doubts that formed during cross-examination and re-emphasize the party's perspective.

Ashley's rule is used to know sex from the sternum bone. It is also known as 149 rule. According to Ashley's rule, male sternum has total length of >149 mm and female sternum has total length of <149 mm.

Sternal index= Length of manubrium/length of body of sternum * 100

In males: 46.2

In females: 54.3

questions.text: A forensic specialist is conducting an autopsy of a body for suspected plant poisoning. He finds that putrefaction is delayed in this case. Which of the following plants is most likely to be consumed by the deceased?
questions.solution:
Strychnos nux vomica is the plant most likely to be consumed by the deceased. This is because the plant contains strychnine that is responsible for delay in putrefaction. The crushed seed of Strychnous nux vomica is the toxic part of the plant.

Poisoning that resists putrefaction includes:

  • Potassium Cyanide
  • Barbiturates
  • Fluoride
  • Phosphorous
  • Endrin
  • Datura (genus)
  • Strychnine (Strychnos nux vomica)
  • Yellow Oleander (Cascabela thevetia)
  • Nicotine
  • Arsenic
  • Mercury
  • Copper
  • Antimony
  • Lead
  • Thallium

Kidney disease with anasarca, septic diseases, and puerperal sepsis hastens putrefaction.

choices.text: Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, kidney, brain
Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, kidney, lungs
Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, heart, lungs
Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, kidney, blood and urine

questions.text: The materials to be preserved routinely in every case of poisoning during an autopsy include:
questions.solution:
Viscera to be preserved routinely in every case of poisoning include; stomach and proximal 30 cm of small intestine with their contents, 500 gms liver with gall bladder, kidney, blood (25 ml) and urine sample.

Special viscera (To be preserved along with routine viscera):

  • Brain is also to be preserved in cases of volatile and other CNS poisons.
  • Spinal cord should be preserved in case of strychnine and gelsemium poisoning.
  • Half of each lungs or one whole lung should be preserved in case of inhaled poisons.
  • Entire heart should be preserved in cases of cardiac poisoning, arsenic poisoning, etc.
  • Bones, and scalp hairs are preserved in heavy metal poisoning.
  • Nails can be preserved in arsenic poisoning.

A saturated salt solution is used commonly for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy.

Rectified spirit is indicated for most of the poisons, exceptions being alcohol, kerosene, phosphorus, paraldehyde, carbolic acid, acetic acid, etc.

questions.text: You are performing an autopsy on a fetus born dead at 6 months. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Adipocere formation cannot be an autopsy finding in the given scenario since fetuses under 7 months do not show this change.

Adipocere is the formation of a soft greyish-white, waxy, greasy material with an offensive, sweet rancid smell, occurring in fatty tissues. It is due to postmortem hydrolysis or hydrogenation of the fats. It is a modification of putrefaction. It is seen most commonly in bodies immersed in water or in a damp, warm environment. Fetuses under 7 months do not show this change.

If the pregnancy with the dead fetus continues, it may be gradually resorbed or mummified. Mummification occurs when the foetus dies from a deficient supply of blood, when liquor amnii is scanty, and when no air enters the uterus. It is also a finding in fetus papyraceous, which is the intrauterine demise of a fetal twin, where it is compressed between the membranes and the uterine wall.

The most important post-mortem change in an intrauterine death is maceration, which is an autolytic process by which there is self-disintegration of the body by cellular enzymes.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with progressive vision loss over the past 3 months. He reports difficulty reading, dimming of vision, and occasional color distortion, particularly in dim light. The patient has a history of chronic alcohol consumption (10-12 alcoholic drinks per day for the last 10 years) and has been using tobacco for 15 years. On examination, his visual acuity is reduced bilaterally, and fundoscopy reveals a pale, atrophic optic disc with loss of the normal cup. There are no other systemic abnormalities noted on physical examination
What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's vision loss?
questions.solution:
Toxic/Nutritional Optic Neuropathy (Toxic Amblyopia)

  • Definition:
    • Chronic retrobulbar neuritis leading to visual loss caused by exogenous (common) or endogenous (rare) toxins. Typically bilateral and progressive, leading to permanent visual deterioration.
  • Common Causes:
    • Exogenous Toxins: Tobacco, alcohol (ethyl/methyl), lead, arsenic, cannabis, and various drugs (e.g., quinine, chloroquine, ethambutol, isoniazid, etc.).
    • Endogenous Toxins: Rare causes such as genetic disorders.

Varieties of Toxic Amblyopia:

  1. Tobacco Amblyopia
    • Causes: Excessive tobacco use (smoking or chewing), primarily due to cyanide.
    • Clinical Features:
      • Bilateral central vision impairment (gradual and progressive).
      • Centrocaecal scotomas.
      • Normal fundus or slight temporal pallor of the disc.
    • Treatment:
      • Complete cessation of tobacco and alcohol.
      • Hydroxocobalamin injections and nutritional support.
    • Prognosis: Good if abstinence is maintained, with slow visual recovery.
  2. Ethyl Alcohol Amblyopia
    • Causes: Chronic alcohol consumption, often with tobacco amblyopia.
    • Clinical Features: Similar to tobacco amblyopia, but with a poorer prognosis.
  3. Methyl Alcohol Amblyopia
    • Causes: Ingestion of methyl alcohol (e.g., wood alcohol, methylated spirits).
    • Clinical Features:
      • Acute poisoning symptoms: headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, delirium, and even death.
      • Ocular features: mild disc edema, narrowed vessels, and eventual optic atrophy.
    • Treatment:
      • Gastric lavage, alkali for acidosis, ethyl alcohol to block methyl alcohol metabolism, and peritoneal dialysis.
    • Prognosis: Poor; blindness often follows survival.
  4. Quinine Amblyopia
    • Causes: Small doses of quinine in susceptible individuals.
    • Clinical Features:
      • Near-total blindness, deafness, tinnitus.
      • Retinal edema, pallor of the optic disc, and extreme vessel attenuation.
      • Constricted visual fields.
  5. Ethambutol Amblyopia
    • Causes: A side effect of antitubercular treatment (high doses or with alcohol/diabetes).
    • Clinical Features:
      • Optic neuritis with central scotoma or bitemporal hemianopia.
      • Reduced vision and color vision impairment.
      • Fundus signs: papillitis.
    • Treatment: Cessation of the drug usually leads to recovery.

Key Points:

  • General Symptoms: Visual loss, usually central or pericentral scotomas.
  • Treatment: Often involves cessation of the offending toxin and nutritional support.
  • Prognosis: Varies from good (with early cessation) to poor (in severe poisoning cases).

questions.text: Which of the following methods is commonly used to examine the corneal endothelium?
questions.solution:
Examination of Corneal Endothelium:

  • Specular Microscopy:
    • Technique: Examined using specular microscopy on a slit-lamp.
    • Process: Light passes through a slit into a system of mirrors, directed at the cornea via a dipping cone lens.
    • Magnification: 200x magnification, allowing detailed observation and photography of endothelial cells.
    • Functionality: Measures endothelial cell morphology, density (average: 2800 cells/mm²), and corneal thickness.
    • Cell Changes: Age leads to decreased cell density and variations in cell size (pleomorphism and polymegathism).
    • Use: Important for assessing endothelial health before corneal grafting and after intraocular surgery.

  • Confocal Microscopy:
    • Purpose: Provides direct visualization of corneal cells from epithelium to endothelium.
    • Magnification: Allows detailed images of endothelial and epithelial cells, as well as keratocytes.
    • Output: Offers analysis of cell numbers, area, and density.

questions.text: Miculiz cells and Russel bodies are the histological features of which of the following conditions ?
questions.solution:
Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous condition of the nose and other structures of the upper respiratory tract. Rhinoscleroma is a result of infection by the bacterium Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.

The cytological features include a lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory infiltrate admixed with classical Mikulicz cells. Histopathologic analysis has a definite role in the diagnosis of rhinoscleroma.

Classic histopathologic findings include large vacuolated Mikulicz cells and transformed plasma cells with Russell bodies. The Mikulicz cell is a large macrophage with clear cytoplasm that contains the bacilli; this cell is specific to the lesions in Rhinoscleroma.

questions.text: The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies motor innervation to all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except?
questions.solution:
The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) supplies motor innervation to the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, which are responsible for vocalization, swallowing, breathing, and speech: Lateral cricoarytenoid, Posterior cricoarytenoid, Transverse and oblique interarytenoid, and Thyroarytenoid.

Cricothyroid is the only intrinsic muscle not supplied by RLN. Cricothyroid is supplied by external branch of superior laryngeal nerve.

The RLN Is a branch of the vagus nerve, also known as cranial nerve X. It runs obliquely through the neck, usually in the tracheoesophageal groove. The RLN's course differs on the right and left sides:

Right RLN: Loops under the subclavian artery

Left RLN: Curves below and behind the aortic arch

The RLN also provides sensation to the larynx below the vocal cords. It's vulnerable to injury, which can occur during neck surgery or from endotracheal tubing. Symptoms of injury include hoarseness, vocal cord paralysis, and impaired swallowing.

questions.text: Which of the following is the narrowest part of fallopian bony canal of facial nerve ?
questions.solution:
The facial nerve travels through a bony canal in the petrous temporal bone called the facial canal or fallopian canal. The facial canal is the longest bony canal in the human body that a nerve travels through, measuring about 3 centimeters long.

The facial canal has three segments: labyrinthine, tympanic, and mastoid. The labyrinthine portion of the fallopian canal is the shortest and the narrowest portion thus facial paralysis develops if labyrinthine portion of nerve become edematous.

The facial nerve branches out into the greater superficial petrosal nerve and chorda tympani while traveling through the canal. The facial canal's proximal opening is at the internal auditory meatus, and its distal opening is the stylomastoid foramen.

The facial nerve Is susceptible to damage from traumatic injuries and conditions like Bell's palsy. Other complications can include:

Congenital bony dehiscences: These occur when the canal doesn't close completely during development.

Paraganglioma: A rare neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in the fallopian canal.

Cholesteatoma: A mass that can erode into the facial nerve canal, especially the tympanic and mastoid segments.

questions.text: Domiciliary midwifery service is a major component of intra-natal health care in India, as most of the population live in rural area in India, so most deliveries take place in the home with the aid of female health workers or trained dais. All of the following are disadvantages of this service except?
questions.solution:
• Mothers with normal obstetric history may be advised to have their confinement in their own homes, provided the home conditions are satisfactory. In such cases the delivery may be conducted by the Health Worker Female or trained dai. This is known as domiciliary midwifery service.
  • Advantages of this service are: -
    • The mother delivers in the familiar surroundings of her home and this may tend to remove the fear associated with the delivery in a hospital.
    • The chances for cross infection are generally fewer at home than in the nursery/hospital.
    • The mother is able to keep an eye upon her children and domestic affairs, this may tend to ease her mental tension.
  • Disadvantages of this service are: -
    • The mother may have less medical and nursing supervision than in the hospital.
    • The mother may have less rest.
    • She may resume her domestic duties too soon.
    • Her diet may be neglected.

questions.text: Match the following terms used in planning with their respective meanings?
questions.solution:
• OBJECTIVE: - It is either achieved or not achieved. It is a planned end point of all activities. Objectives are concerned directly with the problem itself.
  • TARGET: - Often refers to a discrete activity such as number of blood films collected or vasectomies done, it permits the concept of degree of achievement. Targets are thus concerned with the factor involved in a problem.
  • GOAL: - Is defined as the ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are directed. Unlike objectives and targets, goals are not constrained by time or existing resources, nor are they necessarily attainable. A goal is usually described in terms of what is to be attained, the extent to which it is to be attained, the population or section of the environment involved, the geographic area in which the proposed programme will operate, and the length of time required for attaining the goal.
  • PLAN: - Planning results in the formulation of a plan. A plan is a blue print for taking action. It consists of five major elements objectives, policies, programme, schedule, budgets.

choices.text: 7-9 sq.m. is the floor space required for 1 person.
5 persons can live in 3 rooms.

questions.text: As a medical student, you visited field during your postings and inquired a family. On seeing the house and number of family members, you told them the house is overcrowded. All of the following are accepted standards for overcrowding except?
questions.solution:
• Overcrowding refers to the situation in which more people are living within a single dwelling than there is space for, so that movement is restricted, privacy secluded, hygiene impossible, rest and sleep difficult.
  • The accepted standards with respect to overcrowding are as below: -
  • PERSONS PER ROOM: - the degree of overcrowding can best be expressed as the number of persons per room, i.e. number of persons in the household divided by the number of rooms in the dwelling. The accepted standards are 1 room-2 persons, 2 rooms-3 persons, 3 rooms-5 persons, 4 rooms-7 persons, 5 or more rooms-10 persons.
  • FLOOR SPACE: - the accepted standards are 11sq.m. or more for 2 persons, 9-10sq.m. for 1.5 persons, 7-9sq.m.for 1 person, 5-7sq.m. for 0.5 person. A baby under 12 months is not counted, children between 1 to 10 years counted as a half unit.
  • SEX SEPARATION: - Overcrowding is considered to exist if 2 persons over 9 years of age, not husband wife, of opposite sexes are obliged to sleep in the same room.

A 30-year-old patient presents with multiple vesicular lesions on the genitalia accompanied by pain. The causative pathogen is most likely:
questions.solution:
Painful vesicular lesions on the genitalia are characteristic of genital herpes caused by the herpes simplex virus.

Sexually transmitted pathogens and the disease caused by them:


Explanation of incorrect options

Incorrect Options:

A. Neisseria gonorrhoeae

The presentation lacks discharge or other signs of gonococcal infection, and vesicular lesions are not a feature.

C. Treponema pallidum

The multiplicity and vesicular nature of the lesions, along with pain, rule out syphilis.
