questions.text: The high-risk strategy for hypertension prevention is particularly appropriate when:
questions.solution:
• POPULATION STRATEGY:- The goal of the population approach is to shift the community distribution of blood pressure towards lower levels of biological normality. This involves a multifactorial approach, based on the following non-pharmacotherapeutic interventions such as:-
    • Nutrition:- Reduction of salt intake to an average of not more than 5 gm per day, moderate fat intake, avoidance of high alcohol intake, restriction of energy intake appropriate to body needs.
    • Weight reduction:- The prevention and correction of overweight/obesity is a prudent way of reducing the risk of hypertension and indirectly CHD.
  • Exercise promotion:- The evidence that regular physical activity leads to a fall in body weight, blood lipids and blood pressure.
  • Behavioural changes:- reduction of stress, smoking, modification of personal life style, yoga and meditation could be profitable.
  • Health education:- The general public require preventive advice on all risk factors and related health behaviour. The whole community must be mobilised and made aware of the possibility of primary prevention.
  • Self-care:- The patient is taught self-care i.e. to take his own blood pressure and keep the log book of the same.
  • HIGH RISK STRATEGY:- The aim of this approach is to prevent the attainment of levels of blood pressure at which the institution of treatment would be considered. This approach is appropriate if the risk factors occur with very low prevalence in the community. Detection of high risks subject should be encouraged by the optimum use of clinical methods. Since hypertension tends to cluster in families, the family history of hypertension and tracking of blood pressure from childhood may be used to identify individuals at risk.
  • EARLY CASE DETECTION:- Early detection is a major problem. This is because high blood pressure rarely causes symptoms until organ damage has already occurred, and our aim should be to control it before this happens. The only effective method of diagnosis of hypertension is to screen the population. But screening, that is not linked to follow up and sustained care, Is a fruitless exercise.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the BODE index used to predict mortality in patients with COPD?
questions.solution:
The BODE index for predicting mortality in COPD patients includes airflow obstruction, exercise performance, dyspnea, and body mass index. Exacerbation history, while important in COPD management, is not part of the BODE index.

  1. COPD Characteristics:
    • COPD primarily manifests as airflow obstruction, which can be assessed using pulmonary function tests. These tests typically show reduced FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratios.
  2. Lung Volume Changes:
    • As COPD severity increases, lung volumes such as total lung capacity, functional residual capacity, and residual volume may also increase.
  3. Emphysema and Diffusing Capacity:
    • In emphysema, a subtype of COPD, there is often a reduction in diffusing capacity due to the destruction of lung parenchyma.
  4. Prognostic Factors and Classification:
    • The degree of airflow obstruction is an important prognostic factor in COPD and forms the basis for the GOLD spirometry severity classification.
  5. BODE Index:
    • The BODE index, which includes factors such as airflow obstruction, exercise capacity, dyspnea, and body mass index, provides a better prediction of mortality in COPD patients than airflow obstruction alone.
  6. Updated GOLD Classification:
    • GOLD has updated its COPD classification system to include additional elements such as respiratory symptoms and exacerbation history, further aiding in the management and treatment of COPD.

questions.text: Cardiac output increases in which of the following types of shock?
questions.solution:
• Distributive shock is characterized by a reduction in systemic vascular resistance (SVR).
  • It uniquely features a compensatory increase in cardiac output (CO).

Hemodynamic Indicators:

  • Central venous pressure (CVP) and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) are typically reduced in distributive shock.

Common Causes:

  • The most prevalent cause of distributive shock is sepsis, defined as a dysregulated response to infection causing life-threatening organ dysfunction.
  • Sepsis that persists with hypotension needing vasopressor support despite adequate fluid resuscitation is termed septic shock.

Other Conditions:

  • Conditions such as pancreatitis, severe burns, and liver failure can also lead to cellular hypoxia due to a primary reduction in SVR.

Anaphylaxis:

  • Anaphylaxis is an IgE-mediated allergic reaction triggered by allergens like food, medications, or insect bites.
  • This condition can cause profound distributive shock due to histamine release, leading to both venous and arterial vasodilation.

questions.text: Sohan, a 65-year-old diabetic patient undergoing dialysis, complained of persistent pain after a accidental fall. It was diagnosed as a case of pathological fracture of lower tibia. Evaluation shows increased serum vitamin D, decreased serum Parathyroid level. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Adynamic Bone Disease:

  • Increasingly prevalent, particularly among diabetics and older individuals.
  • Characterized by reduced bone volume and mineralization.
  • Caused by excessive suppression of PTH due to the use of vitamin D preparations or excessive calcium intake from phosphate binders or dialysis solutions.

Complications of Adynamic Bone Disease:

  • Higher incidence of bone fractures and pain.
  • Associated with increased vascular and cardiac calcification.
  • Potential for large calcium concretions in soft tissues, known as tumoral calcinosis.

Symptoms in Adynamic Bone Disease:

  • Patients experience severe musculoskeletal pain, exacerbated by the inability to repair microfractures that normally occur with physical activity.

Hyperparathyroidism and Bone Impact:

  • Hyperparathyroidism increases bone turnover, leading to osteitis fibrosa cystica.
  • Bone histology in these cases shows abnormal osteoid and fibrosis of the bone and bone marrow, along with the formation of brown-colored cysts (brown tumors).

Clinical Manifestations of Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Severe symptoms include bone pain, fragility, brown tumors, and compression syndromes.
  • Resistance to erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs) due to bone marrow fibrosis.
  • Systemic effects include muscle weakness, cardiac muscle fibrosis, and general constitutional symptoms due to high PTH levels, considered a uremic toxin.

Bone Health in Advanced CKD:

  • Patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD) are more prone to fractures compared to age-matched controls due to compromised bone health.

Osteomalacia Distinction:

  • Osteomalacia involves reduced production and action of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (1,25(OH)2D3), leading to accumulation of nonmineralized osteoid, distinct from other bone disorders discussed.

questions.text: A patient who recently underwent a renal transplant is being evaluated one month post-operation for symptoms of infection. Which of the following organisms is NOT typically an usual cause of infection within the first 6 months following a renal transplant?

choices.text: PPIs increase the pH level in the stomach, which affects clopidogrel's absorption.
PPIs and clopidogrel are both metabolized by the same enzyme, leading to reduced effectiveness of clopidogrel.
PPIs lead to decreased renal excretion of clopidogrel.

questions.text: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are known to reduce the efficacy of clopidogrel. What is the primary reason for this?
questions.solution:
1. Clopidogrel Interaction:
    • PPIs are known to reduce the efficacy of clopidogrel by sharing the same metabolic pathway, specifically, both are metabolized by the cytochrome P450 enzyme system, which can lead to reduced activation of clopidogrel, an antiplatelet medication.
  2. Mechanism of Interaction:
    • The interaction involves competition between PPIs and clopidogrel for the cytochrome P450 (CYP2C19) enzyme, potentially reducing clopidogrel's effectiveness.
  3. Class Effect and Pantoprazole:
    • It is not confirmed whether all PPIs similarly affect clopidogrel; pantoprazole might have a theoretical advantage over others in not interfering as much, though this isn't confirmed.
  4. FDA Recommendations:
    • The FDA recommends continuing clopidogrel where necessary and reevaluating the need for concurrent PPI therapy.
  5. Practical Recommendations:
    • For patients on clopidogrel and aspirin, especially those with GI risk factors, GI protective therapy should be considered.
    • High-dose H2 blockers are less effective than PPIs.
    • To minimize interaction, a 12-hour separation between PPI and clopidogrel administration is suggested.

questions.text: In the evaluation of a suspected pituitary adenoma, all of the following investigations should be done initially except:
questions.solution:
Initial Evaluation for Suspected Pituitary Adenoma

  1. Context for Evaluation:
    • The type of pituitary adenoma (e.g., acromegaly, prolactinoma, Cushing's disease) dictates the specific laboratory studies based on clinical features.
  2. Sellar Mass Assessment:
    • For a sellar mass without clear signs of hormone excess, studies aim to identify the tumor type and check for hypopituitarism.
  3. Initial Hormonal Evaluation:
    • Basal prolactin (PRL):To check for prolactinoma.
    • Insulin-like growth factor (IGF)-1:Used to screen for acromegaly.
    • 24-hour urinary free cortisol (UFC) and/or overnight oral dexamethasone suppression test:Used to assess for Cushing's syndrome.
    • α-subunit, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH):To evaluate other pituitary functions.
    • Thyroid function tests:To check thyroid axis involvement.
  4. Additional Evaluation:
    • Further hormonal tests may be required based on initial findings.
  5. Hypopituitarism Assessment:
    • In cases where hypopituitarism is suspected, further tests such as a menstrual history, testosterone levels, 8 a.m. cortisol levels, and thyroid function tests help identify deficiencies needing hormone replacement before further intervention.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with reduced consciousness, severe hypothermia measured at 23°C (74°F), Bradycardia and a history of poorly managed hypothyroidism. She also has a history of recent pneumonia and congestive heart failure exacerbation. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Myxedema Coma

  1. Mortality Rate and Prognosis:
    • Myxedema coma has a high mortality rate of 20-40%, and outcomes are not dependent on T4 and TSH levels.
  2. Clinical Features:
    • Includes significantly reduced level of consciousness, potential for seizures, and typical hypothyroid features such as severe hypothermia, which can reach as low as 23°C (74°F).
  3. Risk Factors and Precipitating Events:
    • Common in elderly patients and often precipitated by factors that impair respiration like sedatives, anaesthetics, and antidepressants.
    • Other factors include pneumonia, congestive heart failure, myocardial infarction, gastrointestinal bleeding, cerebrovascular accidents, and exposure to cold.
  4. Pathogenesis:
    • Characterized by hypoventilation leading to hypoxia and hypercapnia.
    • Associated complications include hypoglycemia and dilutional hyponatremia.
  5. Treatment Strategy:
    • Initial management includes administering LT4 intravenously or via nasogastric tube if IV preparations are not available.
    • Supplementing with liothyronine (T3) is considered due to impaired T4 to T3 conversion, with careful monitoring for potential arrhythmias.
    • Supportive therapies address metabolic disturbances, with careful warming strategies and administration of parenteral hydrocortisone to support adrenal function.
    • LT4 can initially be administered as a single IV bolus of 200-400 μg, which serves as a loading dose, followed by a daily oral dose of 1.6 μg/kg per d, reduced by 25% if administered IV. If suitable IV preparation is not available, the same initial dose of LT4 can be given by nasogastric tube (although absorption may be impaired in myxedema). Because T4 → T3 conversion is impaired in myxedema coma, there is a rationale for adding liothyronine (T3) intravenously or via nasogastric tube to LT4 treatment, although excess liothyronine has the potential to provoke arrhythmias. An initial loading dose of 5-20 μg liothyronine should be followed by 2.5-10 μg every 8 h, with lower doses chosen for smaller or older patients and those at cardiovascular risk.
  6. Supportive Care:
    • Includes treatment of any underlying precipitating factors, potential use of broad-spectrum antibiotics, ventilatory support, and careful fluid management.
    • Avoidance or careful use of sedatives and other medications due to altered metabolism in profound hypothyroidism.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs increase the risk of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)?
questions.solution: Sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, empagliflozin) work by preventing glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in urine. While they are effective for managing type 2 diabetes, they are associated with an increased risk of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), particularly in certain conditions such as dehydration, infection, surgery, or low insulin states. This risk arises because SGLT2 inhibitors can reduce insulin levels and increase glucagon, promoting ketogenesis even when blood glucose levels are not extremely high (a condition sometimes called "euglycemic DKA").

questions.text: According to the WHO definition, osteoporosis is defined based on which T-score?
questions.solution:
1. Measurement Technique Limitations:
    • DXA (dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry) is a two-dimensional scanning technique that cannot estimate the depth or length of the bone. This limitation can affect accuracy, especially in small, slim individuals.
  2. Comparison and Standardization:
    • Since DXA devices vary between manufacturers, T-scores are used to standardize results by comparing them to a young adult reference population that is matched for race and sex. Z-scores compare individual results to an age and gender-matched reference population.
  3. Definition of Osteoporosis:
    • Osteoporosis is defined as having a T-score of less than -2.5 at the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or total hip.

Must know Recommended Drugs for Osteoporosis

  1. Bisphosphonates
    • Examples: Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, Zoledronic acid
    • Mechanism of Action:Inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, thereby increasing bone mineral density.
  2. Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators (SERMs)
    • Example: Raloxifene
    • Mechanism of Action:Mimics estrogen's beneficial effects on bone density without some of the risks associated with estrogen therapy, such as breast cancer.
  3. Calcitonin
    • Example: Salmon calcitonin
    • Mechanism of Action:Directly inhibits osteoclast activity, which reduces bone resorption.
  4. Parathyroid Hormone Analogs
    • Example: Teriparatide
    • Mechanism of Action:Stimulates osteoblast activity, which enhances bone formation.
  5. RANK Ligand (RANKL) Inhibitor
    • Example: Denosumab
    • Mechanism of Action:Binds to RANKL, preventing it from activating RANK on the surface of osteoclasts and thereby reducing bone resorption.
  6. Sclerostin Inhibitor
    • Example: Romosozumab
    • Mechanism of Action:Inhibits sclerostin, a protein involved in bone metabolism that inhibits bone formation. This promotes bone formation and decreases bone resorption.

choices.text: The incubation period is short as compared to naturally acquired infection.
There are no relapses of P. vivax and P. ovale infections in transfusion malaria.
Clinical features and management are the same as for naturally acquired infections.
Longer duration of Primaquine is needed

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about malaria transmitted through blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Malaria Transmission through Non-Vector Routes

  1. Modes of Transmission:
    • Malaria can be transmitted via blood transfusion, needlestick injuries, or organ transplantation. These methods bypass the typical vector-borne transmission through mosquito bites.
  2. Incubation Period:
    • The incubation period for malaria acquired through these non-vector routes is often short. This shortened period is because the parasite is introduced directly into the blood, skipping the pre-erythrocytic stage that normally occurs in the liver when transmitted by mosquitoes.
  3. Absence of Relapses:
    • In cases of malaria caused by P.vivax and P. ovale transmitted through transfusion or similar methods, there are no relapses. This is due to the absence of the hypnozoite stage, which in natural infections resides in the liver and can cause relapses by reactivating.
  4. Clinical Features and Management:
    • The clinical presentation and treatment of malaria acquired through transfusion or other non-vector routes are consistent with those of malaria contracted through mosquito bites. The management protocols do not differ significantly, ensuring a familiar approach for healthcare providers.
  5. Specific Treatment Considerations:
    • Primaquine, which is typically used to clear liver stages of P.vivax and P. ovale infections, is not required in transfusion-related cases. This is because the parasite does not undergo a liver stage, eliminating the possibility of dormant liver forms that could cause later relapses.

questions.text: Which of the following feature differentiate overactive bladder from bladder pain syndrome?
questions.solution:
A) Increased daytime frequency

This feature is common in both Overactive Bladder (OAB) and Bladder Pain Syndrome (BPS). Both conditions can cause increased daytime frequency of urination, so this does not differentiate them..

B) Nocturia

Nocturia, or waking up at night to urinate, is also a symptom shared by both OAB and BPS. Both conditions can cause this, so it doesn't serve as a distinguishing factor..

C) Suprapubic pain

This is the key differentiating feature. Suprapubic pain, particularly related to bladder filling, is a hallmark symptom of BPS. OAB does not typically involve pain. BPS is characterized by bladder-related pain that increases with bladder filling and is often relieved after voiding. Suprapubic pain is unique to BPS and is not a feature of OAB.

D) Absence of proven urinary infection

Both OAB and BPS are diagnosed in the absence of a urinary tract infection (UTI), so this feature does not help differentiate them. A lack of infection is common to both conditions, but it doesn't provide enough distinction.

Key Takeaway: The main distinguishing feature between Overactive Bladder (OAB) and Bladder Pain Syndrome (BPS) is suprapubic pain, which is present in BPS but not in OAB.

questions.text: All of the following are arterial supply of testis except;
questions.solution:
• There are three arterial supplies to the testis: the testicular (internal spermatic) artery, the artery of the vas deferens (deferential artery), and the cremasteric (external spermatic) artery (Harrison and Barclay, 1948). The testicular artery is the main blood supply to the testis, and its diameter is greater than the deferential and cremasteric arteries combined.
  • The testicular artery arises from the abdominal aorta and descends in the intermediate stratum of the retroperitoneum to enter the internal inguinal ring. From its aortic origin, it crosses the psoas muscle and the ureter to reach the inguinal ring to enter the spermatic cord. As the testicular artery descends toward the testis, it branches into an internal artery and an inferior testicular artery and into a capital artery to the caput epididymis.

questions.solution:
Bassler Sign - Sharp pain created by compressing the appendix between the abdominal wall and iliacus


Ten Horn sign - Pain caused by gentle traction of the right testicle

Ilio Psoas sign - Elevation of the extended leg against resistance is painful

Aaron sign - Pain or pressure in the epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to McBurney point

Key takeaway point:

choices.text: It is a benign tumor with malignant potential
Syndromic Desmoid tumors have equal male & female incidence
R0 resection is not the goal in managing desmoid tumors
Adjuvant therapies are essential to prevent recurrence

questions.text: Identify the true statement about desmoid tumor
questions.solution:
Desmoid tumors, also known as aggressive fibromatosis, are rare fibroblastic neoplasms with infiltrative behavior but no metastatic potential. They are most commonly found in the abdominal wall but can occur anywhere in the body. While these tumors are benign, they are known for their aggressive local growth and frequent recurrence after treatment. The management of desmoid tumors can be challenging, especially when associated with syndromes like familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

  • Option A: "It is a benign tumor with malignant potential"
    Incorrect. Desmoid tumors are indeed benign, but they do not have malignant potential, meaning they do not metastasize. While they can aggressively infiltrate local tissues, they do not spread to distant organs.
  • Option B: "Syndromic desmoid tumors have equal male & female incidence"
    Correct. Syndromic desmoid tumors, such as those associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), Gardner syndrome, and Turcot syndrome, show an equal male-to-female ratio. In sporadic cases, however, there is a female predominance.
  • Option C: "R0 resection is not the goal in managing desmoid tumors"
    Incorrect. R0 resection, which refers to the complete removal of the tumor with negative margins, is typically the goal in treating desmoid tumors. While recent debates suggest that positive margins may not always necessitate re-resection, complete microscopic resection is still generally preferred.
  • Option D: "Adjuvant therapies are essential to prevent recurrence"
    Incorrect. While adjuvant therapies such as radiation may have a role, they cannot reliably prevent recurrence. The focus is on surgery, and recurrence is common even after complete resection, making careful follow-up important.

Key Takeaway: Desmoid tumors are benign but locally aggressive, often linked to genetic syndromes like FAP. Surgical excision with wide margins is the standard treatment, though recurrence is common. Adjuvant therapies cannot prevent recurrences, and male-to-female incidence is equal in syndromic cases, unlike sporadic cases, where females are more commonly affected.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with a 6-month history of slowly progressive swelling on the left side of her face, associated with intermittent pain radiating to the ear and numbness in the lower lip. On physical examination, a firm, fixed mass is palpable in the left parotid region, with no signs of facial nerve paralysis. MRI shows a 4 cm mass in the left parotid gland with perineural invasion. Based on the clinical history, examination, and imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a basaloid tumour made up of epithelial and myoepithelial cells, presenting in tubular, cribriform, or solid patterns. It is typicallyneurotrophic exhibiting centrifugal spread, with the most common symptom being slow- growing mass with pain caused by perineural invasion. Although it appears indolent, it exhibits aggressive long-term behaviour with persistent growth, recurrence, and late-onset metastasis, often leading to a fatal outcome.

A well-defined lobulated multiloculated soft tissue mass of the left parotid gland involving mainly the deep lobe.


Option (a) Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumour composed of epidermoid, mucus, and intermediate cells, often showing a cystic pattern (hallmark). It is classified into low, intermediate, and high grades based on differentiation. While perineural invasion can occur in high-grade tumours, it is not a characteristic feature of this malignancy.

Option (c) Pleomorphic adenoma

Pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign salivary gland tumour, typically occurs in the superficial lobe of the parotid gland and is more frequent in females. It grows slowly, remains confined to the gland, and unlike malignant tumours, does not exhibit perineural invasion.

Option (d) Adenocarcinoma

Adenocarcinoma is an infiltrative salivary gland carcinoma marked by architectural diversity and cytologic uniformity (hallmark), typically more aggressive than adenoid cystic carcinoma, with earlier metastasis to lymph nodes and distant organs but lacking adenoid cystic carcinoma’s neurotrophic spread

Reference:

Subramaniam N, Murthy SP, Vidhyadharan S. Tumours of the salivary glands.

Comprehensive management of head and neck cancer. New Delhi: Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers (P) Ltd; 2021. p. 245-8.

questions.text: Ephelis is also known as?
questions.solution:
Choice A - Melanocytes migrate from the neural crest to the basal epidermis during embryogenesis. When melanocytes aggregate in the dermis or at the dermoepidermal junction, they are called naevus cells

Choice B - A freckle is an area of skin that contains a normal number of melanocytes, producing an abnormally large number of melanin granules. Also known as ephelis

Choice C -A junctional naevus is a dermoepidermal proliferation of naevus cells, visible as deeply pigmented macules or papules that occur commonly in childhood or adolescence, usually progressing to form compound or intradermal naevi with advancing age. Benign mucosal lesions tend to be junctional naevi

Choice D - This is a maculopapular, pigmented lesion that becomes most prominent during adolescence. It represents a junctional proliferation of naevus cells, with nests and columns in the dermis

Key takeaway - Ephelis is another name for freckle which is an area of skin with normal number of melanocytes producing abnormally large number of melanin granules

questions.text: All types of shock show systemic vasoconstriction except?
questions.solution:
Choice B - Distributive shock describes the pattern of cardiovascular responses characterising a variety of conditions, including septic shock, anaphylaxis and spinal cord injury. Inadequate organperfusion is accompanied by vascular dilatation with hypotension, low systemic vascular resistance, inadequate afterload and a resulting abnormally high cardiac output

Choice A - Cardiogenic shock is due to primary failure of the heart to pump blood to the tissues. Evidence of venous hypertension with pulmonary or systemic oedema may coexist with the classical signs of shock. As preload and afterload decrease, there is a compensatory baroreceptor response, resulting in increased sympathetic activity and release of catecholamines into the circulation. This results in tachycardia and systemic vasoconstriction

Choice C - Hypovolaemic shock is due to a reduced circulating volume and may be due to haemorrhagic or nonhaemorrhagic causes. As preload and afterload decrease, there is a compensatory baroreceptor response, resulting in increased sympathetic activity and release of catecholamines into the circulation. This results in tachycardia and systemic vasoconstriction

Choice D - In obstructiveshock there is a reduction in preload owing to mechanical obstruction of cardiac flling. There is reduced flling of the left and/or right sides of the heart, leading to low cardiac output.As preload and afterload decrease, there is a compensatory baroreceptor response, resulting in increased sympathetic activity and release of catecholamines into the circulation. This results in tachycardia and systemic vasoconstriction

Key Takeaway - Inadequate organ perfusion along with vascular dilatation causes low systemic vascular resistance, inadequate afterload causing high cardiac output

choices.text: Systemic hyperfibrinolysis, low fibrinogen levels, platelet dysfunction
Systemic hypofibrinolysis, high fibrinogen levels, thrombocytosis
Systemic hyperfibrinolysis, low fibrinogen levels, thrombocytopenia

questions.text: Acute traumatic coagulopathy is characterized by?
questions.solution:
Choice A - In trauma and surgery, the combination of tissue trauma and hypovolaemic shock leads to the development of an endogenous coagulopathy called acute traumatic coagulopathy (ATC). Up to 25% of all trauma patients develop ATC within minutes of injury and it is associated with a fourfold increase in mortality. ATC is characterised by systemic hyperfbrinolysis, low fbrinogen levels and platelet dysfunction.

Choice B - ATC is not characterized by Systemic hypofibrinolysis, high fibrinogen levels, thrombocytosis

Choice C - ATC is not characterized by Systemic hyperfibrinolysis, low fibrinogen levels, thrombocytopenia

Choice D - ATC is characterized by features seen in Choice A

Key Takeaway - Tissue trauma + hypovolaemic shock result in endogenous coagulopathy called ATC which is characterized by systemic hyperfibrinolysis, low fibrinogen levels and platelet dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following short chain fatty acids is essential for mucosal integrity?
questions.solution:
Choice B - Bacterial fermentation is essential for two major reasons: (1) support of the normal flora of the gut lumen, which prevents colonization and subsequent infection (e.g., Clostridium difficile), and (2) production of acetoacetate, propionate, and butyrate (a short-chain fatty acid). Butyrate appears to be the preferred fuel of colonic mucosa cells and is essential for mucosal integrity

Choice A - Propionate is a fatty acid, produced by bacterial fermentation but does not play any role in maintaining mucosal integrity

Choice C - Acetoacetate is a fatty acid, produced by bacterial fermentation but does not play any role in maintaining mucosal integrity

Choice D - Malonate does not play any role in mucosal integrity

KeyTakeaway: Butyrate is essential for maintaining the integrity of the colonic mucosa by providing energy to colonocytes and supporting barrier function. Its role underscores the importance of dietary fiber and gut microbiota in promoting intestinal health.

questions.text: For ongoing hypertrophy of linear scars, intralesional corticosteroid is injected in which layer?
questions.solution:
Choice C - Since hypertrophic scars contain islands composed of aggregates of fibroblasts, small vessels, and collagen fibres throughout dermis, ongoing hypertrophy may be treated with intralesional corticosteroids (triamcinolone acetonide, 10 to 40 mg/mL) injected into the papillary dermis every 2 to 4 weeks until flat

Choice A - Since hypertrophic scars contain islands composed of aggregates of fibroblasts, small vessels, and collagen fibres throughout dermis, corticosteroid injection in the subcutaneous tissue is of no advantage

Choice B - Since hypertrophic scars contain islands composed of aggregates of fibroblasts, small vessels, and collagen fibres throughout dermis, ongoing hypertrophy may be treated with corticosteroid injection, but not into the reticular dermis

Choice D - Since hypertrophic scars contain islands composed of aggregates of fibroblasts, small vessels, and collagen fibres throughout dermis, corticosteroid injection in the epidermis is of no advantage

Key Takeaway - Ongoing hypertrophy may be treated with intralesional corticosteroids (triamcinolone acetonide, 10 to 40 mg/mL) injected into the papillary dermis every 2 to 4 weeks until flat

questions.text: Most common organism responsible for early PVE is________
questions.solution:
Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) can occur early after valve implantation or at any point throughout the valve's lifetime. In early PVE, the infection is typically introduced during surgery or through indwelling catheter lines during the perioperative period, leading to bacterial migration to the prosthetic valve. Risk factors for early PVE include native valve infective endocarditis, intravenous drug use, male gender, and prolonged cardiopulmonary bypass time.

Early PVE is defined as occurring within the first 12 months after valve placement, and the most common organism responsible is Staphylococcus epidermidis. The infection often results from contamination during surgery or from the use of catheters.

Late PVE occurs more than a year after valve placement and is more similar to native valve endocarditis (NVE), with pathogens like Streptococcus viridans and Staphylococcus aureus commonly involved. Late PVE often arises from transient bacteremia, such as after dental procedures.

The clinical presentation of PVE mirrors that of NVE, though cardiac complications—such as new murmurs due to valve dehiscence or abscess formation—are more common in PVE and may necessitate urgent surgical intervention.

In the immediate postoperative period, blood cultures showing staphylococci or yeast likely indicate true PVE, whereas gram-negative bacteremia is more likely to be related to an indwelling catheter. Blood cultures in patients with late PVE caused by staphylococci or streptococci are typically positive if the patient is not receiving antibiotics.

Strep. PneumoniA is not typically associated with PVE. It is more commonly a cause of pneumonia and other respiratory infections.

Key Takeaway: Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common organism causing early PVE, while late PVE more closely resembles NVE in terms of the organisms involved. Urgent surgical intervention may be required in the presence of cardiac complications, and empiric treatment should cover common pathogens such as Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and streptococci.

choices.text: Square root sign in PA catheter

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of Constrictive pericarditis?
questions.solution:
Constrictive pericarditis is a condition in which the pericardium becomes thickened and fibrotic, restricting the heart's ability to expand during diastole. This impairment leads to characteristic hemodynamic and physical exam findings, which are critical for diagnosis.

CHOICE A.Kussmaul Sign: This is a prominent sign of constrictive pericarditis. It refers to an increase in jugular venous pressure (JVP) during inspiration, which is typically seen due to impaired filling of the right atrium as it is constrained by the thickened pericardium. This finding is also seen in other conditions like right ventricular failure, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and acute pulmonary embolism, but it is a key diagnostic clue in constrictive pericarditis.

CHOICE B.Square Root Sign in PA Catheter: This is another hallmark of constrictive pericarditis. It refers to a characteristic dip in the diastolic pressure waveform of both the right and left ventricles, representing rapid filling followed by a sharp deceleration due to the restrictive pericardial constraint. The square root sign is pathognomonic for constrictive pericarditis.

CHOICE C.Pulsus Parvus: This is the correct answer because it is not a typical feature of constrictive pericarditis. Pulsus parvus, characterized by a weak and delayed pulse, is more commonly associated with conditions like aortic stenosis or severe heart failure, rather than constrictive pericarditis.

CHOICE D.Prominent Y-Descent in CVP: This is a classic sign of constrictive pericarditis. It refers to the sharp drop in the central venous pressure (CVP) during diastole as blood rapidly fills the atrium after the right ventricle stops filling due to pericardial restriction.

Key Takeaway: The most distinguishing features of constrictive pericarditis include the Kussmaul sign, square root sign in the PA catheter, and prominent y-descent in CVP. Pulsus parvus is not typically associated with constrictive pericarditis but rather with conditions like aortic stenosis. Recognizing these signs helps differentiate constrictive pericarditis from other causes of heart failure or restrictive cardiac conditions.

questions.text: Which is most commonly tool nowadays used to diagnose lymphatic related abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Lymphatic abnormalities are commonly diagnosed using lymphoscintigraphy, which has largely replaced older techniques like lymphangiography. This technique involves injecting a radiolabeled sulfur colloid (technetium 99m sulfur colloid) into the subdermal region of the affected limb. The transport of the lymphatic fluid is then tracked using a whole-body gamma camera to visualize major lymphatics and nodes.

  • CHOICE D. Scintigraphy: This is the correct answer. Lymphoscintigraphy allows for detailed functional imaging of the lymphatic system, making it the most common and preferred tool for diagnosing lymphatic disorders like lymphedema.
  • CHOICE A. Duplex ultrasound: While duplex ultrasound is useful for evaluating vascular abnormalities like venous insufficiency or deep vein thrombosis, it is not typically used for diagnosing lymphatic system issues.
  • CHOICE B. CT scan: CT scans are more commonly used for structural imaging of various organs but are not the gold standard for diagnosing lymphatic abnormalities. It may help in certain situations, such as detecting lymphadenopathy or masses, but it doesn't provide detailed functional lymphatic evaluation.
  • CHOICE C. Lymphangiography: Lymphangiography was previously used to visualize the lymphatic system but has largely been replaced by lymphoscintigraphy due to the latter's non-invasive nature and greater accuracy in assessing lymphatic function.

Key Takeaway: Lymphoscintigraphy is the most commonly used diagnostic tool for identifying lymphatic abnormalities, offering a non-invasive and accurate method to assess lymphatic function and visualize related issues like delayed transport or obstruction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation presents for her routine prenatal checkup. Her blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg, and urine dipstick shows 2+ proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for the 28-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation, presenting with hypertension (150/95 mmHg) and proteinuria (2+ on dipstick), is preeclampsia.

  • Preeclampsia is typically diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation and is characterized by new-onset hypertension (≥140/90 mmHg) and proteinuria (≥300 mg/24 hours or 2+ on dipstick). Although it is most commonly diagnosed after 20 weeks, early-onset preeclampsia can occur, and it is associated with increased risk of complications for both the mother and fetus. In this case, although she is 14 weeks pregnant, her elevated blood pressure and proteinuria point toward a preeclamptic state developing earlier than usual.
  • Chronic hypertension occurs when a woman has elevated blood pressure before pregnancy or before 20 weeks of gestation. Since the woman in this case is only 14 weeks pregnant, and her blood pressure is elevated at this time, it is unlikely to be chronic hypertension without any prior history.
  • Gestational hypertension is diagnosed when a woman develops hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation without proteinuria. Since this woman already has proteinuria, it rules out gestational hypertension.
  • HELLP syndrome (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count) is a severe form of preeclampsia, but it usually presents with more severe symptoms like epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting rather than just hypertension and proteinuria at 14 weeks.

Topic: Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 203: Gestational Hypertension and Preeclampsia.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is not typically used for the diagnosis of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS)?
questions.solution:
• A) Anticardiolipin antibodies (aCL): These antibodies are commonly used for the diagnosis of APS. Elevated levels of anticardiolipin antibodies are one of the diagnostic criteria for APS.
  • B) Anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies (anti-β2GPI): Anti-β2GPI antibodies are another crucial marker used in the diagnosis of APS. Their presence, along with clinical symptoms, confirms the diagnosis.
  • C) Lupus anticoagulant (LA): The presence of lupus anticoagulant, identified through clotting tests, is a hallmark of APS. It is another key antibody for the diagnosis.
  • D) Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): ANA testing is primarily used to diagnose systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and is not specific to APS. Although some APS patients may test positive for ANA, it is not a diagnostic criterion for APS.

Therefore, ANA is not typically used for the diagnosis of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS), which relies on anticardiolipin antibodies (aCL), anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies (anti-β2GPI), and lupus anticoagulant (LA).

Topic: APLA syndrome

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation is admitted for preterm labor. After initial management with fluids and corticosteroids, nifedipine is administered. Which of the following is a potential side effect of nifedipine in this setting?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker commonly used to manage preterm labor by inhibiting uterine contractions. A common side effect of nifedipine is maternal hypotension, as it causes vasodilation and decreases peripheral vascular resistance. This can lead to a drop in blood pressure, particularly when administered in high doses. Other side effects may include dizziness and flushing, but hypotension is the most clinically significant in this context.

Option wise Explanation:

  • A) Hyperkalemia: Not typically associated with nifedipine. Hyperkalemia may occur with certain medications (e.g., potassium-sparing diuretics), but not with nifedipine.
  • B) Maternal hypotension: Correct answer. Nifedipine can cause maternal hypotension due to its vasodilatory effect, leading to decreased blood pressure.
  • C) Hyperglycemia: This is more commonly seen with corticosteroid use (e.g., in preterm labor) rather than with nifedipine.
  • D) Tachycardia: Nifedipine can cause reflex tachycardia, but hypotension is a more prominent side effect and a more immediate concern in preterm labor management.

Topic: Preterm labour

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to the use of tranexamic acid in managing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?
questions.solution:
• A) Active thromboembolic disease: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that works by inhibiting fibrinolysis (the breakdown of blood clots). In patients with active thromboembolic disease, there is an increased risk of forming unwanted blood clots. By inhibiting fibrinolysis, tranexamic acid could exacerbate this condition and increase the risk of further thrombotic events such as deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, or stroke. Therefore, tranexamic acid is contraindicated in these cases.
  • B) Severe anemia: Tranexamic acid does not worsen anemia directly, and it can be used in patients with anemia, particularly in cases of heavy bleeding. However, it should not be relied upon as the sole treatment for blood loss-patients may still need blood transfusions.
  • C) Hypertension: Tranexamic acid does not have a significant direct effect on blood pressure. Hypertension is not an absolute contraindication to its use, but careful monitoring is recommended.
  • D) Coagulation disorders: Coagulation disorders are not an absolute contraindication to tranexamic acid, as it can be used to manage bleeding in patients with mild or moderate clotting disorders. However, in patients with severe clotting disorders (e.g., hemophilia), other treatments may be preferred. Tranexamic acid might be used cautiously in these cases after careful consideration of risks.

Topic: Medical Management of PPH

Reference: World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines on the prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (2012)

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for obstetric anal sphincter injury (OASIS) except:
questions.solution:
• A) Forceps-assisted delivery: Forceps-assisted delivery is a well-established risk factor for OASIS. The forceps application places traction on the fetal head, which can increase the risk of trauma to the perineum and anal sphincter.
  • B) Macrosomia: A large fetal birth weight (greater than 4000g) is another significant risk factor for OASIS. A larger fetus can stretch the perineum more during delivery, often requiring operative assistance such as forceps or vacuum, increasing the risk of sphincter injury.
  • C) Use of epidural anesthesia: Epidural anesthesia itself is not considered a direct risk factor for OASIS. While epidural anesthesia can reduce pain and potentially prevent the need for forceps or vacuum, its use has not been consistently associated with an increased risk of OASIS. However, epidural anesthesia can potentially delay the second stage of labor and reduce the urge to push, which may increase the likelihood of interventions that could lead to OASIS. But, it is not a direct risk factor like other conditions listed.
  • D) Primiparity: First-time mothers (primiparas) are at a higher risk for OASIS. The perineum in primiparas is often less elastic, and the lack of prior vaginal deliveries can increase the likelihood of needing interventions, such as episiotomy or operative delivery, which increase the risk of OASIS.

Topic: Obstetric Anal Sphincter Injury

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 165: Obstetric Anal Sphincter Injury Prevention and Management

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of primary infertility for 3 years. His semen analysis shows a low sperm count, poor motility, and normal morphology. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Varicocele (A): The most common cause of male infertility, leading to impaired spermatogenesis due to heat stress and venous congestion.
  • Klinefelter syndrome (B): A chromosomal abnormality (47,XXY) that causes low sperm count and small testes but typically has abnormal morphology.
  • Obstructive azoospermia (C): Caused by blockages in the male reproductive tract, leading to no sperm in the ejaculate.
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (D): Results in low testosterone levels but would show low FSH/LH levels, not a semen analysis finding.

Topic: Male infertility

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a family history of cystic fibrosis presents for genetic counseling. Both she & her partner are carriers for cystic fibrosis. What is the risk of this couple having a child with cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder. If both partners are carriers of the cystic fibrosis gene, the risk of having an affected child is 25% with each pregnancy

  • Cystic fibrosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene must be mutated for the individual to have the disease.
  • In this scenario:
    • Each parent contributes one allele for the CFTR gene to their offspring.
    • The possible combinations for their child are:
      • 25% chance of inheriting two normal alleles (not a carrier, not affected).
      • 50% chance of inheriting one normal allele and one mutated allele (carrier, like the parents).
      • 25% chance of inheriting two mutated alleles (affected with cystic fibrosis).

Thus, the couple has a 25% risk of having a child with cystic fibrosis.


Topic: Autosomal recessive disorders

Ref: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) Carrier screening for cystic fibrosis 2020

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a painless lump in the right breast. On examination, the lump is firm, mobile, and well-defined. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
A fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor, typically presenting as a firm, mobile, and painless lump. It is most commonly found in women under 30 years of age.

Explanation:

A) Fibroadenoma (Correct Answer):

  • Fibroadenoma is the most likely diagnosis for this patient. It is the most common benign breast tumor, typically found in young women, particularly those under 30 years of age.
  • These lumps are usually painless, firm, mobile, and well-defined, which matches the clinical description in the question.
  • Fibroadenomas are composed of glandular and stromal tissue and can vary in size. They are typically round or oval in shape and are freely movable within the breast tissue, which makes them feel mobile on examination.
  • Ultrasound or mammography is often used for further evaluation, and in many cases, biopsy is done to confirm the diagnosis.

B) Breast cancer:

  • Breast cancer often presents with a firm, non-mobile lump that may be fixed to surrounding tissues. It is typically more irregular in shape, and although it can be painless, it is more likely to be associated with other symptoms such as skin changes (e.g., dimpling), nipple discharge, or axillary lymphadenopathy.
  • Breast cancer can occur in women of all ages, but the presentation of a firm, mobile, well-defined, painless lump is less characteristic of malignant tumors, especially in younger women.

C) Cystosarcoma phyllodes:

  • Cystosarcoma phyllodes is a rare fibroepithelial tumor that can present with a rapidly growing, painless, and firm lump, which can also be mobile.
  • However, phyllodes tumors are typically larger than fibroadenomas and can show rapid growth. They can also have a more irregular shape compared to fibroadenomas.
  • While benign forms exist, malignant phyllodes tumors are aggressive and often associated with larger tumors and other concerning features.

D) Mastitis:

  • Mastitis is an infection of the breast, usually occurring in lactating women (though it can occur in non-lactating women as well).
  • It typically presents with pain, redness, warmth, and swelling in the breast, often with fever and flu-like symptoms. A painless lump is not characteristic of mastitis, which tends to be associated with inflammation and infection.
  • Mastitis is less likely in a 30-year-old woman with a well-defined, painless lump, especially if she is not breastfeeding.

Topic: Benign breast masses

Reference: American Cancer Society Breast Cancer: Early Detection and Diagnosis 2020

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge, vaginal itching, and discomfort during urination. On examination, there is erythema of the vaginal mucosa, and a "strawberry cervix" is noted. Which of the following is the most sensitive diagnostic method for trichomoniasis?
questions.solution:
• OPTION C: Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is the most sensitive and specific method for diagnosing trichomoniasis. It detects the genetic material of Trichomonas vaginalis with high accuracy.
  • OPTION A: Wet mount microscopy can identify motile trichomonads but has low sensitivity (~50-70%).
  • OPTION B: Culture is more sensitive than wet mount but less commonly used due to longer turnaround time.
  • OPTION D: Gram stain is not a reliable method for diagnosing trichomoniasis as T. vaginalis is not easily visualized.

Topic: Diagnosis of Trichomoniasis

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with irregular periods, hirsutism, and infertility is diagnosed with PCOS. The serum testosterone is elevated, and her ultrasound reveals bilateral polycystic ovaries. Which of the following is the most common metabolic complication associated with PCOS?
questions.solution:
Option-wise Explanation:

A) Hypothyroidism:

  • While hypothyroidism can be associated with menstrual irregularities, it is not the most common metabolic complication of PCOS. The primary metabolic concern in PCOS is insulin resistance and its downstream effects.

B) Diabetes mellitus type 2 (Correct):

  • Insulin resistance, often found in PCOS, leads to an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Women with PCOS are at a 7-fold increased risk of type 2 diabetes, especially if they have additional risk factors such as obesity.

C) Hyperthyroidism:

  • Hyperthyroidism is not typically associated with PCOS. Thyroid dysfunction can cause menstrual irregularities, but it is not a metabolic complication of PCOS.

D) Hypertension:

  • Although women with PCOS may have a slightly increased risk of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 2 is the most common metabolic complication associated with the syndrome.

Key Points:

  • PCOS and Insulin Resistance: Insulin resistance is a central feature of PCOS, contributing to increased risk of type 2 diabetes and other metabolic disorders like dyslipidemia.
  • Metabolic Complications: In addition to diabetes, women with PCOS may also experience dyslipidemia, obesity, and hypertension, but type 2 diabetes is the most prevalent.
  • Management: Lifestyle interventions like diet modification, regular exercise, and weight management are key in managing insulin resistance in PCOS. Medications like metformin are also used to improve insulin sensitivity.

Topic: Diagnosis of PCOS

questions.text: All of the following are features of prematurity in a neonate, except
questions.solution:
• The ears in a premature neonate are soft and flat with ear cartilage being deficient and pliant (and not thick)
  • Features of prematurity in a Neonate :
    • Baby is small in size usually less than 47 cm long.
    • Head is relatively large, sutures are widely separated and fontanelle are large
    • Face is small and buccal pad of fat is minimal
    • Skin is thin and pinkish and appears shiny due to generalized edema.
    • Skin is covered with abundant lanugo and there is little vernix caseosa.
    • Subcutaneous fat is reduced
    • The breast nodule is less than 5 mm wide
    • The ears are soft and flat with ear cartilage being deficient and pliant
    • Testes are not descended into scrotal sac. (Empty scrotum)
    • Scrotal sac is poorly pigmented and has less rugosities.
    • In females labia majora appears widely separated, exposing the labia minora and the clitoris.
    • Deep creases are not well developed in the sole. (There may be a single deep crease over the anterior one third of the sole)
    • Neonatal reflexes such as Moro, Suckling & Swallowing are sluggish.
    • There is hypotonia with a poor recoil of flexed forearm when extended.

questions.text: All of the following are characteristic features of Tricuspid Atresia except
questions.solution:
• Atresia of the tricuspid valve results in the absence of a communication between the right atrium and right ventricle therefore the right ventricle is underdeveloped the inflow portion being absent.
  • The only exit for systemic venous blood coming to the right atrium is by way of Atrial Septa! defect. Through this the blood goes to left atrium from where it enters left ventricle.
  • A ventricular septal defect provides communication between the left ventricle and the outflow portion of the right ventricle. The left ventricle therefore maintain both the systemic as well as the pulmonary circulation thus there is hypertrophy of the left ventricle which is reflected by left axis deviation in ECG.
  • The pulmonary blood flow is dependent on the size of the ventricular defect, the smaller the VSD, the lesser the pulmonary blood flow.
  • 90% patients of Tricuspid Atresia have diminished pulmonary blood flow.
  • Auscultatory finding in case of Tricuspid Atresia: S1 -Normal S2 - Single Murmur grade II to grade III / VI.
